headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Archer Daniels Midland Company Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's call, Christ
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Archer Daniels Midland Company Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's call, Christina Hahn, Vice President, Investor Relations for Archer Daniels Midland Company. Ms. Hahn, you may begin.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to ADM's Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. Starting tomorrow, a replay of today's call will be available at adm.com.For those following the presentation, please turn to Slide 2, the company's safe harbor state
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to ADM's Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. Starting tomorrow, a replay of today's call will be available at adm.com.
For those following the presentation, please turn to Slide 2, the company's safe harbor statement, which says that some of our comments constitute forward-looking statements that reflects management's current views and estimates of future economic circumstances, industry conditions, company performance and financial results. These statements are based on many assumptions and factors that are subject to risks and uncertainties. ADM has provided additional information in its reports on file with the SEC concerning assumptions and factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in this presentation, and you should carefully review the assumptions and factors in our SEC report. To the extent permitted under applicable law, ADM assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements as a result of new information or future events.
On today's call, our Chief Executive Officer, Juan Luciano, will provide an overview of the quarter. Our Chief Financial Officer, Ray Young, will review financial highlights and corporate results. Then Juan will review the drivers of our operations' performance in the quarter and provide an update on actions that are improving returns. And then, they will take your questions. 
Please turn to Slide 3. And I'll now turn the call over to Juan.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christina. Good morning, everyone. Thank you, all, for joining us today. This morning, we reported adjusted earnings per share of $1 and adjusted segment operating profit of $1.1 billion. Our net earnings for the fourth quarter were $701 millio
componenttext:
Thank you, Christina. Good morning, everyone. Thank you, all, for joining us today. This morning, we reported adjusted earnings per share of $1 and adjusted segment operating profit of $1.1 billion. Our net earnings for the fourth quarter were $701 million or $1.08 per share. Segment operating profit was $1.3 billion. 
For the calendar year, we achieved adjusted earnings of $3.20 per share, up 37% from last year's $2.33. And importantly, adjusted ROIC of 9% was 260 basis points above our cost of capital. 
In the fourth quarter, the Agricultural Services team executed well to capitalize on the strong conditions, while international merchandising continued to show year-over-year recovery. In North America and Europe, Oilseeds showed strong year-over-year growth, offset by weaker results in South America. Looking ahead in North America and Europe, solid crush margins and export opportunities have carried into the first quarter. Market conditions in South America Oilseeds should improve with the large harvest, and we're working towards higher returns throughout 2015 in this key geography. 
While U.S. ethanol demand was seasonally strong, boosted by the domestic response to lower gasoline prices, high industry production has built excess inventories. Margins in this industry should remain challenged until supplies are better aligned with demand. We will continue our work to optimize cost and product mix in the Corn business to maximize profitability. 
Also, during the fourth quarter, we were busy preparing for the January 1 launch of the WILD Flavors and the Specialty Ingredients business unit, working on synergies, preparing to move new businesses and align teams. In view of our continued strong performance and our positive outlook, our Board of Directors has voted to increase our quarterly dividend from $0.24 to $0.28. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Ray.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Juan, and good morning, everyone. Slide 4 provides some financial highlights for the quarter. Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $1 a share, up 5% from the $0.95 last year. Excluding specified items and also excluding net timing effects, adjusted se
componenttext:
Thanks, Juan, and good morning, everyone. Slide 4 provides some financial highlights for the quarter. Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $1 a share, up 5% from the $0.95 last year. Excluding specified items and also excluding net timing effects, adjusted segment operating profit was $1.1 billion, up $88 million or more than 8% from last year. The effective tax rate for the fourth quarter was 29% compared to 39% in the fourth quarter of the prior year. For the calendar year, our effective tax rate was 28%, lower than last year's 33% tax rate, which was negatively impacted by valuation allowances taken on certain significant deferred tax assets. 
Looking into calendar year 2015, we expect our effective tax rate to be in the 28% to 30% range. Our trailing fourth quarter average adjusted ROIC of 9% improved from the 8.5% at the end of the third quarter and also significantly improved by 240 basis points from the 6.6% at the end of the fourth quarter last year. The 9% adjusted ROIC is above our 6.4% annual WACC for 2014 as well as our long-term WACC of 8.0%, as reflected in the graph on Slide 19 in the appendix. Our objective remains to earn 200 basis points over our WACC. 
In the fourth quarter, our trailing fourth quarter adjusted EVA was $670 million based upon adjusted earnings and annual WACC, up $315 million from 2013. On Chart 17 in the appendix, you can see the reconciliation of our reported quarterly earnings of $1.08 per share to the adjusted earnings to $1 a share. For this quarter, LIFO represented $16 million pretax credit or $0.01 per share after-tax. We also recorded net gains on sales of assets of about $135 million pretax or $0.14 per share after-tax, primarily related to the sales of our South American fertilizer business. 
We incurred about $33 million of WILD related charges, we're about $0.03 per share related to transactions closing cost as well as restructuring cost during the quarter. We incurred a $98 million noncash pretax U.S. pension settlement charge related to selling some of our retired reliabilities with lump sums. In our GAAP statements, this charge is included in our SG&A expense line. There were approximately $41 million of pretax impairment charges or $0.04 per share from various assets. 
And finally, we adjusted our fourth quarter results down by $52 million or $0.09 per share for U.S. biodiesel tax benefits attributable to the earlier 3 quarters. This breakdown is roughly $0.01 a share in Q1, $0.03 a share in Q2 and $0.05 a share in Q3. 
Slide 5 provides an operating profit summary and the components of our corporate line. Before Juan goes into the operating results, I like to highlight some of the unique items impacting our quarterly results. In Oilseeds, I just talked about the South American fertilizer gain and the other pure benefits of the biodiesel tax credits. We will also continue to have our cocoa and chocolate business as part of our segment reporting results in Oilseeds, until which time we have closed on the sales, some time in the first half of 2015. They are not treated as discontinued operations in our financial statements. There are also various asset impairment charges in all 3 segments in corporate to sum up to about $41 million pretax. 
In the other processing line, we've included the initial results of both WILD Flavors and Specialty Commodities Inc. There were about $33 million of transaction closing and restructuring charge in the fourth quarter. In addition, included in the negative $13 million number in other processing is about $23 million of purchase price amortization charges relate to inventories and $3 million of additional depreciation expenses. Excluding these amounts, WILD and SCI earned about $13 million in the fourth quarter. 
Effective January 1, the results of WILD and SCI will be included in our new fourth business segment called WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients, or WFSI for short, which also includes certain specialty ingredients businesses from our other 3 segments. To assist you with your analysis for 2015, we have included in the appendix a pro forma of our 2014 quarterly results adjusted for the ADM business lines that would be part of the fourth business unit. 
In the corporate lines, net interest expense was down due to significantly lower debt levels. Unallocated corporate cost were higher due to various special project costs, including our ERP project that was initiated earlier in 2014. Other charges for the fourth quarter are primarily related to our $98 million noncash U.S. pension settlement charge. 
In addition, I want to point out that currency translation effects on our earnings, while negative, we're not material for the fourth quarter nor for the calendar year as much of our global merchandising and processing trade flows are either U.S. dollar functional or U.S. dollar linked, providing some insulation to our financial results against fluctuations of the U.S. dollar or the euro. 
I would also like to comment on our GAAP net revenue number that can be found in the appendix. GAAP net revenues for the quarter were $20.9 billion, down from last year's $24 billion. The significant reduction was driven by large declines in commodity prices that impact our revenues. But this decline also impacts our cost of goods sold as our input costs are lower. So the key for us is managing the spread between revenues and cost of goods sold, which is core competency of our teams. This dynamic makes operating profit much more relevant when analyzing ADM. 
Turning to cash flow statement on Slide 6. We present here the cash flow statement for the year ended December 31, 2014, compared to the prior year. We generate just over $2.7 billion from operations before working capital changes in the year ended 2014, slightly higher than last year. Working capital changes were a source of $2.3 billion this year compared to a source of $2.9 billion last year. 
Total capital spending for the year was about $0.9 billion, compared to the prior year -- comparable to the prior year and in line with our reduced CapEx target. We completed acquisitions of $3 billion in equity, which included WILD and SCI, but net of cash assumed amounted to $2.7 billion. We also received proceeds of divestures from the South American fertilizer business of $350 million. 
For 2015, we are estimating capital spending in the range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion. This range is higher than our our $0.9 billion spending in 2014, which you may recall, we reduced after the WILD acquisition to assess capital spend avoidance opportunities. As a result, some 2014 spending shifted into 2015. We also have some additional spending for our ERP program and cost reduction projects as well as the ramp-up of our specialty protein project spending in Brazil, our Fibersol projects in China and U.S., our lecithin projects in Germany and India. 
In February 2014, our $1.15 billion convertible debt matured. We paid down this debt contributing to our overall debt reduction. For the year, we spent about $1.2 billion to repurchase about 25 million shares and we paid out $0.6 billion in common dividends. So for the year, we returned about $1.8 billion to shareholders. We ended the year with about 643 million shares on a fully diluted basis. 
Slide 7 shows the highlights of our balance sheet as of the end of both '14 and '13. Cash on hand was approximately $1.6 billion, down $1.9 billion from last year. Our operating working capital of $7.8 billion was down $3.1 billion from the year-ago period. This decrease was comprised of about $1.3 billion related to lower inventory prices and about $0.7 billion related to lower inventory quantities and a decrease of about $1.1 billion in other working capital, primarily related to reclassification of working capital of our global cocoa and chocolate businesses, which are treated under a held for sale accounting as well as additional trade receivables sold during the calendar year. 
Total debt was about $5.7 billion resulting in net debt balance that is debt less cash of $4.1 billion, up slightly from the 2013 net debt level, in part reflecting the fourth quarter cash outflows related to the acquisitions of WILD and SCI. Our shareholders' equity of $19.6 billion is $0.6 billion lower than the level last year, with a cumulative translation account down about $0.9 billion due to the strength of the U.S. dollar. We had $6.6 billion in available global credit capacity at the end of December. If you add the available cash, we have access to almost $8 billion of short-term liquidity. 
In view of our strong liquidity position and forward outlook, the Board of Directors approved increasing our quarterly dividend from $0.24 per share to $0.28 per share, a 17% increase. This would translate to an annualized cash outflow of about $0.7 billion. In addition, with a strong balance sheet and forecast generation of cash, we expect to repurchase anywhere between $1.5 billion to $2 billion of ADM shares, subject to any strategic requirements that may occur over the course of this calendar year. So we expect to return anywhere from $2.2 billion to $2.7 billion of cash to shareholders this year, again, subject to any strategic requirements. 
With the forecast CapEx spend of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion in 2015, we believe we are again providing a balanced approach towards capital allocation, consistent with the intentions we outlined on the Investor Day in December. 
Next, Juan will take us through an operational review of the quarter. Juan?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ray. Let's turn to Slide 8. I'll start with segment operating profit and then move on to discuss the 3 major segments. Our underlying segment operating profit improved sequentially every quarter this year. In the fourth quarter, it increased 20% f
componenttext:
Thanks, Ray. Let's turn to Slide 8. I'll start with segment operating profit and then move on to discuss the 3 major segments. Our underlying segment operating profit improved sequentially every quarter this year. In the fourth quarter, it increased 20% from the third quarter. On a year-over-year basis, the significant improvement in Ag Services drove an overall increase of 8%. In all 4 quarters of this year, the team delivered year-over-year improvements in segment operating profit. For the calendar year, we earned $3.7 billion of operating profits excluding specified items, up 25% from the year before. 
2014 was another solid year from our Oilseeds business, demonstrating the strength and diversity of the portfolio in delivering consistent results. The Corn business showed the value of managing the business for overall results. In 2014, they delivered their best operating profit ever. And Ag Services demonstrated a strong recovery from the prior year, aided by a turnaround of international merchandising results and good execution by the team to fully capitalize on a more favorable environment. I am very proud of all the team was able to accomplish this year. 
Now I'll walk you through our fourth quarter results. Starting on Slide 9, the Oilseeds team delivered a strong quarter. It is worth noting that last year's fourth quarter was exceptionally strong, driven by strong performances across all regions. In the fourth quarter, good capacity utilization and margins drove strong soybean crushing results in Europe and North America, with the North American team delivering an all-time record quarter amid a strong global demand and low input costs. Both North American and European crushing results were better than the same period last year. 
South American results were down significantly compared to a very strong fourth quarter last year. Origination and transportation were impacted by lower Brazilian corn production, reduced exports and a slow farmer selling relative to last year and losses on basis on board crush positions. In Paraguay, a lower quality crop hurt export opportunities. In addition, South American results were negatively impacted by fertilizer as we transition this business for the close of the sale in mid-December. 
In Europe, overcapacity pressured biodiesel margins. And in North America, the retroactive U.S. biodiesel tax credit improved margins on gallons blended in the quarter, though demand was down seasonally. Also, our results in Asia were consistent with last year were much improved compared to the earlier quarters in 2014, driven by Wilmar results. 
Please turn to Slide 10. Corn Processing results declined in the quarter. In the year-ago period, sweeteners and starches benefited from a steep decline in net corn costs. This fourth quarter, conditions were more challenging as net corn costs rose during the quarter. In addition, our results in the fourth quarter were negatively impacted by hedge losses on coproduct sales, an increase in bad debt reserves and the start-up costs related to our new sweetener facility in Tianjin, China. For the fourth quarter, absent these unique factors, sweeteners and starches results would have been about $100 million. 
Good execution, the combined management of production and merchandising drove a significant improvement in bioproducts results. And animal nutrition results improved on better margins and solid demand. 
Slide 11, please. In the fourth quarter, Ag Services results improved significantly from last year when market conditions were challenged following the droughts of 2011 and '12. In the U.S., the team put on a strong soybean export program during harvest, moving beans at a record pace. This allowed great throughput of our origination and transportation networks, as you can see reflected in those results. The international merchandising team continued their turnaround. The fourth quarter was the first quarter in which we coordinated our worldwide trade flows through our new global merchandising desk. I'm particularly proud of our international merchandising team's work in 2014, as they integrated the top for trading operation and led an operational and financial turnaround. 
In transportation, the strong U.S. bean export program, replenishment of fertilizer and salt inventories and great river conditions allowing large tows, deep thrust, combined with great execution to deliver an outstanding performance. And our Midland results were strong as the business of solid merchandising and blending opportunities in the quarter. 
Now on Slide 12, we wanted to briefly update you on our actions that are driving improved returns. We focused, as you know, those efforts in a few areas: Strengthening the business, managing our portfolio and growing the business. In the area of strengthening the business. We exceeded our target of $400 million in run rate cost savings by the end of 2014. During our December Investor Day, we outlined our target for $350 million in further cost savings related to operational excellence and process improvements. We also highlighted $200 million in incremental purchasing savings. So we are targeting a total of $550 million in additional run rate cost savings over the next 5 years. 
In the area of managing our portfolio following the WILD acquisition, we are well on our way to achieving our targeted EUR 100 million in synergies over the next 3 years. The commercial and technical teams are focused on realizing the benefits of the combined businesses and have had over 100 customer engagements so far. We have already recognized synergy wins within our first 3 months and are actively building a pipeline of opportunities for new business. 
Cost synergy activities are also underway. We are addressing redundancies and eliminating overlapping corporate SG&A. In December, we announced our additional IT center will be located in existing space at WILD's facility in Erlanger, Kentucky. 
We reached an agreement in December to sell our global cocoa business to Olam for $1.3 billion. We expect to close that sale in mid-2015. We remain on track to close the sale of our global chocolate business to Cargill for $440 million in the first half of 2015. We closed the $350 million sale of our South American fertilizer business in December. And in an example of the asset-light approach that we have mentioned before, I'm pleased to announce that we have reached an agreement to sell a 50% stake in our export terminal in Northern Brazil to Glencore. Combined with the plan to quadruple that facility's capacity, we are strengthening a strategically located asset in a cost and capital efficient way. 
Our efforts to improve returns also involve investing to grow the business. In November, we begun production of our sweetener plant in Tianjin, China. Construction continues in our fiber plant in Tianjin, China, our feed pre-mix plant in Nanjing, China and our specialty protein complex in Campo Grande, Brazil. The expansion of our Fibersol production capacity at Clinton, Iowa is on schedule to be operational midyear. And our non-GMO lecithin projects in Hamburg, Germany and Latur, India should be operational in March and July, respectively. We continue to take actions to further improve the business. And as you can see, that's reflected in our returns. 
Before we take your questions, I wanted to offer some additional perspectives as we look forward. Our Ag Services results showed how our larger and more efficient U.S. network can perform with a big clock. As the South American harvest continues, we'll see the seasonal decline in North American soybean exports. We also expect to see corn exports pickup starting with the Pacific Northwest and then moving to the Gulf. Continued North American mill exports should support crush margins well into Q1. And the large South American harvest should drive exports and improve crush margins. 
In sweeteners and starches, we expect 2015 volumes and margins to be similar to the 2014. Ethanol demand should improve in the coming quarter as low gasoline prices and the change in weather should support increased driving miles. And in this margin environment, we would expect many producers to run for yield rather than volume, which should improve alignment of supply and demand. Across the Corn business, we continue our work to optimize our product and customer mix. 
In our new WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients business unit, we expect the benefit from new wins and increased customer engagements. We are working to deliver a compelling portfolio of ingredients and services that will allow us to better serve our customers. We are adding geographic scale to our business with capital projects ongoing in China, Brazil, India, Germany and the U.S. And we are expanding the scope of our portfolio by adding the basic healthy ingredients of Specialty Commodities as well as pursuing new products such as texturized protein, non-GMO lecithin and Omega-3s. 
We expect that many of our businesses that did not perform that well in 2014 will have more favorable results in 2015. South American results should improve. We expect our international merchandising business to continue its improvement. We have disposed of, or are disposing of, our poorer performing business such as South American fertilizer, chocolate and cocoa. And we have a list of other businesses for which we are targeting improved profitability of returns in 2015. So a strong finish to 2014, good conditions for the year ahead and continued improvements in our portfolio of businesses. Overall, we feel very good about our position for 2015. 
To recap a few new items we announced on today's call. We are targeting an additional $550 million in run rate cost savings within the next 5 years. We have agreed to sell 50% of our core facility in Northern Brazil to Glencore. And together, we will be quadrupling capacity of the port. We are targeting up to $2 billion of stock buybacks for the calendar year and the board has increased our quarterly dividend from $0.24 to $0.28. 
With that, operator, please open the line for questions.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Evan Morris with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Evan Morris with Bank of America.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to talk a little bit more about ethanol. And obviously, fourth quarter came in better than what I was looking for. But your commentary regarding the margins being challenged suggest, I guess, it's more of a production issue than just a broader
componenttext: I just want to talk a little bit more about ethanol. And obviously, fourth quarter came in better than what I was looking for. But your commentary regarding the margins being challenged suggest, I guess, it's more of a production issue than just a broader environment with lower prices. And can you kind of talk a little bit about that? And if that is the case, how long does the oversupply usually take to correct to come back in line with demand?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan. So really, we are not seeing a change in demand. Actually, if anything, has been an improvement because of reduced gasoline prices that have increased our consumption in the United States. We have seen an excess in production that is driven mos
componenttext: Yes, Evan. So really, we are not seeing a change in demand. Actually, if anything, has been an improvement because of reduced gasoline prices that have increased our consumption in the United States. We have seen an excess in production that is driven mostly by the very good margins we enjoyed in the November time frame. So how long will it take for that to correct? Difficult to say. We're going to see a combination as we go into the first quarter of progressively higher driving miles. And then some of the refineries get into maintenance as they go into March, stay prepared for the high driving season. So we managed, as I said in my prepared remarks, the business for the overall. So we tried to manage the overall product mix and we look for when margins are very good, we run for volume. When margins are declining, we run a little bit more prudently for yield. So that's the way -- so we see this is a relatively immature industry, but these low margins will correct itself, the supply issue, and we expect increase in margins as we go into the later part of Q1.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just with that and just -- I know ethanol is not a huge part of the business, but it seems to be your stock is trading on this change in oil prices. But when you talk about margins remaining challenged, I mean, that's sort of a pretty ambiguous
componenttext: Okay. And just with that and just -- I know ethanol is not a huge part of the business, but it seems to be your stock is trading on this change in oil prices. But when you talk about margins remaining challenged, I mean, that's sort of a pretty ambiguous term. Can you give a little bit more color around that? Are you expecting early on to not make any money in the early part of the quarter? I mean, you have really strong operating profit per gallon as we exited the year. So if you could just put a little bit of context around what you mean by challenged? Where do you expect margins to kind of settle out more broadly? And where do we kind of head as the year progresses?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Of course. If you look at the story in Q4, you see the high volatility that are in ethanol prices. So it's very hard to predict with any precision. We continue, Evan, that's why we continue with our efforts on our cost improvements and we highlight that a
componenttext: Of course. If you look at the story in Q4, you see the high volatility that are in ethanol prices. So it's very hard to predict with any precision. We continue, Evan, that's why we continue with our efforts on our cost improvements and we highlight that all the time. And you heard me that we have exceeded our stretch call of $400 million because a big part of that is in that Corn business. The other leg of the stool that we look at is the flexibility and the introduction of new products that allow us to shift production to the products that are growing the most or having less margin pressure. I would say, Evan, overall, we expect probably about -- margins in ethanol to be a little bit lower than 2014, but better than current levels.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just last question for you. Given the operating environment and all the puts and takes, I mean, do you think in 2015 that you'll be able to hit your medium-term ROIC target of 10%?
componenttext: Okay. And just last question for you. Given the operating environment and all the puts and takes, I mean, do you think in 2015 that you'll be able to hit your medium-term ROIC target of 10%?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have the impact of WILD in 2015, that's a 7.7 percentage...
componenttext: Well, we have the impact of WILD in 2015, that's a 7.7 percentage...

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: About 70 basis points.
componenttext: About 70 basis points.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: 70 basis points. So listen, I mean, you heard that at the Investor Day 2 years ago with this strategy based on the returns. And as you see in the graph that I showed in my slide, that strategy continues to deliver, and we feel very good about that. Obviou
componenttext: 70 basis points. So listen, I mean, you heard that at the Investor Day 2 years ago with this strategy based on the returns. And as you see in the graph that I showed in my slide, that strategy continues to deliver, and we feel very good about that. Obviously, every now and then, as we have a big acquisition like WILD, we pause a little bit in that trajectory. But all of our programs are working, and we are very optimistic about our trajectory towards 10%.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Farha Aslam with Stephens.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Farha Aslam with Stephens.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm looking at crushing and origination. Could you just breakdown that segment a little bit for us? Juan, in any given year, how much should we expect from kind of North American crush versus South America, versus international merchandising, roughly?
componenttext: I'm looking at crushing and origination. Could you just breakdown that segment a little bit for us? Juan, in any given year, how much should we expect from kind of North American crush versus South America, versus international merchandising, roughly?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let's see. International merchandising is reported into Ag Services, so let's separate that further, yes. So certainly, North America is much bigger than South America proportionately. I will say -- but you're probably wondering because of the offse
componenttext: Well, let's see. International merchandising is reported into Ag Services, so let's separate that further, yes. So certainly, North America is much bigger than South America proportionately. I will say -- but you're probably wondering because of the offsetting effect this quarter of the South American result. We have a combination of issues there. First of all, as you recall, in South America, we report also origination efforts. So farmer selling has been very poor in South America, and we are comparing, again, a very strong quarter in 2013 so it's a very tough comp. But origination results were down because of farmer selling. Crushing margins were normally -- we would expect it to be relatively low in Q4 because of lack of beans and -- at the end of the season. But we have to be honest, I mean, in a tough environment like that with poor farmer selling a low crushing margins, we also didn't help ourselves much. And on top of that, we have the transition of the fertilizer business. That business was discontinued, we transferred some of our operations to Mosaic. We have bad results coming out of that. As you can understand, it's a very volatile business, low margins and it's difficult to manage in normal operations much more in a transition. So I would say those are the impacts that we have in South America in Q4. That makes us optimistic for Q1 because we think that farmer selling will come back, crush margins have already expanded, both in Brazil and in Paraguay. And certainly, we will not have the issue of fertilizer and we have the new Port of Barcarena fully operational. So all in all, we think that, that South American results was an issue that will stay in that Q4, and we don't expect it to be repeated.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So looking out into the first quarter, North American crusher remained strong, South America recovers, so we should see a nice pick up in the crushing origination going to the first quarter.
componenttext: So looking out into the first quarter, North American crusher remained strong, South America recovers, so we should see a nice pick up in the crushing origination going to the first quarter.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Farha, directionally, we expect Q1 to be stronger than Q4 for Oilseeds, that's correct.
componenttext: Farha, directionally, we expect Q1 to be stronger than Q4 for Oilseeds, that's correct.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just moving to your Ag Services business. Clearly, you had a very strong quarter in the fourth quarter largely driven by exports. Do you anticipate the first quarter export volume out of North America to remain the same or to grow? And impo
componenttext: Okay. And then just moving to your Ag Services business. Clearly, you had a very strong quarter in the fourth quarter largely driven by exports. Do you anticipate the first quarter export volume out of North America to remain the same or to grow? And importantly, how do you think basis will work out in North America first quarter versus fourth quarter? Did you capture a harvest basis in the fourth quarter? Or will you stil have more to capture in the first quarter?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Fourth quarter was very close to perfection, Farha. We have perfect harvest weather, with the exception of maybe 10 days. Weather conditions were very favorable to us because of our very strong transportation businesses. So when freight and rail and
componenttext: Yes. Fourth quarter was very close to perfection, Farha. We have perfect harvest weather, with the exception of maybe 10 days. Weather conditions were very favorable to us because of our very strong transportation businesses. So when freight and rail and all that get complicated, obviously, we'll profit from that in our transportation -- in barge transportation business that really excelled in Q4. Obviously -- and we were able to capture good basis, to be honest, during Q4. So we were very happy with that. As we roll into Q1, obviously, the soybean export programs kind of declined as South America becomes -- to pick up the pace there. We expect corn program to pick up during the quarter as the U.S. corn becomes more competitive against European destinations or Argentina. So all-in-all, we've seen steady demand. Not maybe a spectacular demand, but not weak demand, steady demand. So we're looking at the execution of a good book, execution of a good -- good execution margins in the interior, good storage margins, still good transportation P&L as still we would see a lot of Northbound freight being used. An we see decent carries in both corn and hard wheat. So all-in-all not as spectacular as Q4, but strong performance in Q1 for Ag services, yes.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that the -- I'm trying to figure out corn processing for 2015. You have a good set up, I would think, in sweeteners and starches. I understand there have been some pretty significant price increases in high-fructose corn syrup. Obviously, the biop
componenttext: I think that the -- I'm trying to figure out corn processing for 2015. You have a good set up, I would think, in sweeteners and starches. I understand there have been some pretty significant price increases in high-fructose corn syrup. Obviously, the bioproducts line is very difficult to forecast. Is it possible to isolate sweeteners and starches in your outlook here, Juan? Can this be a pretty significant improvement versus 2014 given the pricing? And then, in addition, would you expect more of the grind to switch to sweeteners away from ethanol as you try to help the industry manage inventories?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rob. So let me give you some perspective. So our expectations for sweeteners and starches for 2015 are pretty much in line to 2014. We expect moderate or relatively stable corn prices. And so as such, margins will be approximately comparable to 2014.
componenttext: Yes, Rob. So let me give you some perspective. So our expectations for sweeteners and starches for 2015 are pretty much in line to 2014. We expect moderate or relatively stable corn prices. And so as such, margins will be approximately comparable to 2014. On relatively -- for liquid sweeteners, relatively a stable volume in that sense. We have other products we have shifted demand that are growing a little bit faster. We have other geographies, especially Southeast Asia, where it's also growing a little bit faster. We're still going to have a very insipient contribution of our high fructose courtesy of new investment in Tianjin, which is more, like, for a longer term, not just that much 2015. So the way we are thinking, although we did better than our plan in 2014 for sweeteners and starches, we're thinking something comparable to 2014 in general.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Why wouldn't it be better? I mean, I thought that there was some pretty good price increases taken, at least in HFCS. Why couldn't it be better?
componenttext: Why wouldn't it be better? I mean, I thought that there was some pretty good price increases taken, at least in HFCS. Why couldn't it be better?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's good, Rob. I'm just thinking about when we look at the pricing season, we probably have about half of the -- we have 2014 with some pressure in pricing on margins. And probably, the first half of our negotiating period was under those conditions. And
componenttext: It's good, Rob. I'm just thinking about when we look at the pricing season, we probably have about half of the -- we have 2014 with some pressure in pricing on margins. And probably, the first half of our negotiating period was under those conditions. And then probably the later half, conditions become a little bit better, industry a little bit planned to be more balanced. So I will have -- we have a little bit of that, but also a little bit of the past in our 2015 margins negotiation. So all-in-all, I think it's mostly comparable effects to 2014.

componenttext: Obviously, we have a set of units that are different. So we have some dry mills and we have some wet mills. I would say, overall, they are slightly positive.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm just -- I'm curious as to how you think about your business, particularly merchandising going forward in an environment of a stronger dollar and weaker other currencies. Do you change the way you do business anywhere? Or the way you think about mercha
componenttext: I'm just -- I'm curious as to how you think about your business, particularly merchandising going forward in an environment of a stronger dollar and weaker other currencies. Do you change the way you do business anywhere? Or the way you think about merchandising globally?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not really, Ann. I think that, obviously, the U.S. is -- currency is getting stronger again most of the other currencies, but that tend to end up adjusting the prices of the commodity to find their own equilibrium. At the end of the day, you may shift a l
componenttext: Not really, Ann. I think that, obviously, the U.S. is -- currency is getting stronger again most of the other currencies, but that tend to end up adjusting the prices of the commodity to find their own equilibrium. At the end of the day, you may shift a little bit the timing of some of those exports, but at the end of the day, the balances are the balances. The import nations got to import some of the exporting nations. Those are the ones that have the excessive. So our teams adjust, obviously, to that. But I would say, that's something that they do on a normal course of business as we have international teams that they adjust for all the other currencies as they move all the time as well. So no exception for the U.S. team. I wouldn't read that much into that.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And there is a lot of talk about corn exports from the U.S. and how they might be competitively disadvantaged versus maybe Brazil, where perhaps we get more corn planted than we anticipated, and they compete for the export markets, but you're not an
componenttext: Okay. And there is a lot of talk about corn exports from the U.S. and how they might be competitively disadvantaged versus maybe Brazil, where perhaps we get more corn planted than we anticipated, and they compete for the export markets, but you're not anticipating any event?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We see some of that, but the U.S. have come back in its competitiveness and we expect that to climb -- that to increase during Q1 as it develops, yes.
componenttext: We see some of that, but the U.S. have come back in its competitiveness and we expect that to climb -- that to increase during Q1 as it develops, yes.

componenttext: I would just refer to the USDA numbers at this point. I'm sure my guys have an opinion, but we will keep it to ourself.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate. And just a real quick follow up on ethanol. Ethanol benefited from very significant exports last year. I guess, the same question. With the strong dollar, would you expect exports of ethanol to decline given where oil prices are and th
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate. And just a real quick follow up on ethanol. Ethanol benefited from very significant exports last year. I guess, the same question. With the strong dollar, would you expect exports of ethanol to decline given where oil prices are and the strength of the dollar?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. At this point in time, we expect ethanol exports to be in the range of $800 million for 2015. We're seeing that demand pretty stable. We have shared with most of the countries and our customers and we don't see that. Ethanol continues to be the cheape
componenttext: No. At this point in time, we expect ethanol exports to be in the range of $800 million for 2015. We're seeing that demand pretty stable. We have shared with most of the countries and our customers and we don't see that. Ethanol continues to be the cheapest oxygenate out there, and we monitor very closely all the other types. And at this point in time, we feel very strongly about this $800 million per year being there in 2015.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Juan, I'm having trouble kind of reconciling what you actually think '15 is going to be like versus '14. I see a bunch of puts and takes. So I'm just trying to circle back to -- in the past, you guys would talk about -- you were about to have -- the busin
componenttext: Juan, I'm having trouble kind of reconciling what you actually think '15 is going to be like versus '14. I see a bunch of puts and takes. So I'm just trying to circle back to -- in the past, you guys would talk about -- you were about to have -- the business was going to break out and we were going to get well through the sort of $3 threshold, which -- I'm just trying to figure out, is that -- your commentary today is very focused on getting the returns up, and I understand that, but I'm also trying to understand whether do you think '15 over '14 is really going to finally be that big year where the earnings actually break out.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vince, we feel very strongly about '15. I think that if you look at what we have done and with all the puts and takes that you described that we face every year. To be honest, every year, we face conditions that are negative in one side and positive
componenttext:
Yes, Vince, we feel very strongly about '15. I think that if you look at what we have done and with all the puts and takes that you described that we face every year. To be honest, every year, we face conditions that are negative in one side and positive in the other side, but the overall is we have improved our portfolio. So there's going to be a lot of business that gave us trouble in 2014 that will not in 2015. There are a lot of units that, without major divestiture, that we are in the process improvement, that gives us hope and good expectations for 2015, that some of those results will be better. We have proven that with a tougher integration and -- which is halfway or maybe 2/3 of the way, but it needs to continue, and there are other things that we continue to improve. So we feel good about that as well. 
And we feel very good. We have shown to everybody and to ourselves how Ag Services can perform in an environment of a good growth that we haven't seen over the last 2 years. So we feel good about how the business executes, but also how the business can run all those assets. And we continue to add to our cost improvements and operational efficiencies, and that continues to rose to the bottom line. When you put on top of that, that we expect WILD to continue to be as we expected, contributing maybe accretive $0.10 to $0.15 during 2015, we feel very good about the combination of all those factors. Will they be surprised during '15? Of course, every year, and we adjust to those. But overall, we continue to see our plan unraveling very positively.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015

componenttext: Yes, we did some proxy hedges on that using corn and it didn't turn out the way we would have like it, so that impacted some of our sweeteners and starches results in the fourth quarter.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Piken with Cleveland Research.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just wanted to circle back to Ag Services here for a minute. And you specifically -- in the past, you talked about $200 million to $250 million in EBIT as a relatively run line to use. I mean, in line of what you did in 4Q, do you think there were
componenttext: Yes, I just wanted to circle back to Ag Services here for a minute. And you specifically -- in the past, you talked about $200 million to $250 million in EBIT as a relatively run line to use. I mean, in line of what you did in 4Q, do you think there were some push-forward in terms of some of the 2015 earnings? Or is that the right run rate to use? Or with this record harvest, should we be using a higher number?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's difficult between -- obviously, in the last quarter, you have some things shifting from one quarter to the other, sometimes in one direction or the other. I would say the range that we're thinking about it for 2015 is something in the range of $850 m
componenttext: It's difficult between -- obviously, in the last quarter, you have some things shifting from one quarter to the other, sometimes in one direction or the other. I would say the range that we're thinking about it for 2015 is something in the range of $850 million to $950 million. You have to think that when this realignment that we have of divisions of businesses is within the division, Ag Services have lost basically $50 million of annual profit that have been transferred to other businesses. So considering that transfer, we are thinking that the range you should consider is something about between $850 million to $950 million per year.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's really helpful. And then with respect to the kind of the WILD Flavors, Specialty Ingredients, I know you would sort of target $0.10 to $0.15 accretion for this year, I think. Can you give us some sort of flavor for how quickly that can ramp u
componenttext: Okay, that's really helpful. And then with respect to the kind of the WILD Flavors, Specialty Ingredients, I know you would sort of target $0.10 to $0.15 accretion for this year, I think. Can you give us some sort of flavor for how quickly that can ramp up? You've, at your Analyst Day, gave out revenue target, but what should we be thinking sort of in the outer years?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We provided the guidance when we announced the acquisition back in July. First full year, $0.10 to $0.15 per share accretion. We're still on track towards that particular range, Mike. I mean, as we kind of work through our plans, we see that in the n
componenttext: Yes. We provided the guidance when we announced the acquisition back in July. First full year, $0.10 to $0.15 per share accretion. We're still on track towards that particular range, Mike. I mean, as we kind of work through our plans, we see that in the numbers. Actually, there may be a little bit of risk towards the downside just because of currency translation impacts, particularly on WILD's European business. But overall, we still feel good about that range for calendar year 2015.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, finally, last question is on the $550 million in cost savings that you're targeting over the next 5 years, can you give us some sort of breakdown by segment where you would expect to see the majority of that benefit?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, finally, last question is on the $550 million in cost savings that you're targeting over the next 5 years, can you give us some sort of breakdown by segment where you would expect to see the majority of that benefit?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say, to be honest, I don't have it at the top of my head by segment. We have -- internally, we have a pipeline of like 10 categories. Some of those categories include things like margin from new products as we fight for the grind. We have categori
componenttext: I would say, to be honest, I don't have it at the top of my head by segment. We have -- internally, we have a pipeline of like 10 categories. Some of those categories include things like margin from new products as we fight for the grind. We have categories about maintenance reduction or improvements. We have categories such like Energy Efficiency. I would say, corn tends to have the bulk sometimes of that, probably in the range of maybe 40% to 50% just because of the size of the assets. Ag Services had a little bit less because you have less fixed assets and more maybe transportation assets. So I would say, if I got to give a guess, but I don't have it, it's something like 50% Corn, maybe 35% Oilseeds and maybe 15% Ag Services, give or take.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Tiberio with Miller Tabak.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Tiberio with Miller Tabak.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Juan, I guess looking at oilseed demand, there's been a lot of focus in the questioning around farmer selling and utilization between North America and South America, but we have seen a little bit more commentary in the trade press around just a more unce
componenttext: Juan, I guess looking at oilseed demand, there's been a lot of focus in the questioning around farmer selling and utilization between North America and South America, but we have seen a little bit more commentary in the trade press around just a more uncertain environment around incremental oilseed demand in Asia. Just wanted to kind of get your sense as to how you're seeing that frame-up on a full year basis and then from the first half to the second half.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So at this point in time, we're seeing still a good export demand in the U.S., where we have it for January and February. We expect it's going to be a little bit of a shift to that in March in the South America. When we're looking to China, we see Ch
componenttext: Yes. So at this point in time, we're seeing still a good export demand in the U.S., where we have it for January and February. We expect it's going to be a little bit of a shift to that in March in the South America. When we're looking to China, we see China seed demand a little bit down at this point in time. Profitability for farmers to raise pigs or chicken is not great at this point in time, part is the slowdown in the economy, part is the government's anti-graft campaign because we do some consumption there. But we expect that, as I talk to my colleagues in China, to increase, to improve during the year. So right now, it's a little bit soft.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is there any other regions that could potentially offset China? I know there's been some talk about India potentially liberalizing their imports, tax regime on oilseeds. Is that kind of factored into your outlook? Or is that just so difficult to
componenttext: Okay. And is there any other regions that could potentially offset China? I know there's been some talk about India potentially liberalizing their imports, tax regime on oilseeds. Is that kind of factored into your outlook? Or is that just so difficult to handicap at this point?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I will say, you will continue to see poultry consumption growing per capita basis in India, so that's also, obviously, bullish since there are, like, 1.4 billion people. I will say overall, we continue to see mill demand growing 3% to 4% year-over-year, a
componenttext: I will say, you will continue to see poultry consumption growing per capita basis in India, so that's also, obviously, bullish since there are, like, 1.4 billion people. I will say overall, we continue to see mill demand growing 3% to 4% year-over-year, and we feel good about that. So I think China have these ups and downs, but we don't foresee a slowdown in demand. At this point in time, for 2015, we still believe 3% to 4% up in mill demand.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just shifting gears back to the WILD Flavors. I know there was a lot of talk at your Investor Day that, really, the next stage is taking this platform and really proliferating it out to a lot of your CPG relationships. Can you just kind of
componenttext: Great. And then just shifting gears back to the WILD Flavors. I know there was a lot of talk at your Investor Day that, really, the next stage is taking this platform and really proliferating it out to a lot of your CPG relationships. Can you just kind of talk, I know it's still early days, but how is the win rates looking with a lot of your large CPG clients? Any notable wins in the quarter? How is that progress tracking to your expectations?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question, Tim. Listen, the first thing that I would like to say about WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients is that I'm pleased to report that we're getting the people equation right. In this case, it's the capability. So obviously, a
componenttext:
Yes, that's a great question, Tim. Listen, the first thing that I would like to say about WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients is that I'm pleased to report that we're getting the people equation right. In this case, it's the capability. So obviously, are there -- both were successful companies individually in their on rights and ingredients so the capabilities are intact. But the issue is, can you combine the people until you get that? And I'm pleased to report that, that's doing -- going extremely well. So we're very confident we're going to hit our 2015 synergy targets. 
In terms of customer, we have had more than 100 customer engagements so far, and we have recorded -- I was checking with the team late last week. I have every Friday a meeting with them to check this. We have more than 355 ideas with actual efforts behind for each customer. So I wouldn't disclose any specific customer, obviously, for confidentiality reasons. There -- these are all innovations that we will keep to ourselves, and hopefully, you will see it reflected in revenue growth, but we're very enthusiastic about how customers are responding to the combined capabilities of both companies.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi. Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zaslow with DMO.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi. Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zaslow with DMO.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can -- I just want to go back to the ethanol. This gives -- I'm puzzled by it a little bit. So how does the ethanol margins actually go higher in this current oil and corn environment? You said corn is relatively stable and surely, the corn -- oil stays s
componenttext: Can -- I just want to go back to the ethanol. This gives -- I'm puzzled by it a little bit. So how does the ethanol margins actually go higher in this current oil and corn environment? You said corn is relatively stable and surely, the corn -- oil stays stable. If supply gets cut at the prices you need to trade it at a premium to GAAP, is that a sustainable situation? I guess, that's where I'm kind of having a hard time with the ethanol margin recovery.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think, listen, I see -- we see driving miles of gasoline consumption going up and we see a stable exports out there. So -- but the issue is if we produce that 15 billion gallons, I mean, it is -- we're not going to have excellent margins. So at the e
componenttext: So I think, listen, I see -- we see driving miles of gasoline consumption going up and we see a stable exports out there. So -- but the issue is if we produce that 15 billion gallons, I mean, it is -- we're not going to have excellent margins. So at the end of the day, it would require some rationalization of capacity. We expect some of this low margins that we're having right now, giving people some -- giving people in the high part of the cost curve some problems. And that's why we continue to emphasize our cost position, and that's all we can drive. What we can drive is our cost position, our fight for the grind and the way we commercially play between produced gallons and purchased gallons. So other than that, it's all speculation, to be honest.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you think that gas can trade at a premium ethanol and know the demand will be met. Is that fair?
componenttext: Okay. So you think that gas can trade at a premium ethanol and know the demand will be met. Is that fair?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, we think so. Yes.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, we think so. Yes.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the...
componenttext: Okay. On the...

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Remember that you have a $0.70 range at this point in time. And I think that we can go 10% higher and we can still be a very competitive oxygenator there.
componenttext: Remember that you have a $0.70 range at this point in time. And I think that we can go 10% higher and we can still be a very competitive oxygenator there.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair. I -- obviously, my confusion is trying figuring that out. I appreciate it. On Ag Services, the $850 million to $950 million is roughly $200 million per quarter basis. Over the next 2 years to 3 years, as you make these improvements that
componenttext: Okay. That's fair. I -- obviously, my confusion is trying figuring that out. I appreciate it. On Ag Services, the $850 million to $950 million is roughly $200 million per quarter basis. Over the next 2 years to 3 years, as you make these improvements that you've been talking about at the Analyst Day, and it seems like maybe there's even some cost-cutting there, will that go up to, say, $250 million to $300 million per quarter? Like, how does that shift? It seems like you have very changeable gains to be had here, and I'm just trying to put a number on that. Is that fair point to say about $250 million to $300 million after all these adjustments are made?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tim, the way I think about Ag Services is we believe Ag Services will continue to go up hopefully in that range. It's difficult for me to quantify, and I'd tell you why. In other businesses, we can add some of the cost improvements. In Ag Services, it bec
componenttext: Tim, the way I think about Ag Services is we believe Ag Services will continue to go up hopefully in that range. It's difficult for me to quantify, and I'd tell you why. In other businesses, we can add some of the cost improvements. In Ag Services, it becomes a little bit more based on whether we had an investment that did -- that increases our origination or our transportation, or we do something like we did with Dubfor [ph] in which it would -- we combine in a global trade desk or we move more into destination marketing and we capture a bigger part of the margin there. So our plans and our expectation at that range is going to evolve over time. It's a little bit more difficult to say exactly the number at this point, and I wouldn't venture that, but we are looking to build to increase margins and our share in Ag Services.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And my final question is, at the Analyst Day, you had said that there was a level of preparedness. I like that word that you used for Ag Services, and obviously, that generated a very, very significant return during the quarter. Do you feel like in the sa
componenttext: And my final question is, at the Analyst Day, you had said that there was a level of preparedness. I like that word that you used for Ag Services, and obviously, that generated a very, very significant return during the quarter. Do you feel like in the same preparedness that you had in the third quarter -- for the fourth quarter, you all have for the first quarter?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, absolutely. We are very well-prepared to handle this first quarter. It will be, as I said, a different quarter. When I was saying the preparedness, it's because, obviously, this team was so looking forward to show what their acid base and thei
componenttext: Absolutely, absolutely. We are very well-prepared to handle this first quarter. It will be, as I said, a different quarter. When I was saying the preparedness, it's because, obviously, this team was so looking forward to show what their acid base and their capabilities could do in a full crop because of the 2 very bad years in the previous crop. But absolutely, they are the same level of preparedness for Q1.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just maybe clear up a couple of points on ethanol. I think you said in a previous comment that you thought you would see -- I think you said you felt very strongly about 800 million gallons of ethanol exports. Is that correct?
componenttext: I wanted to just maybe clear up a couple of points on ethanol. I think you said in a previous comment that you thought you would see -- I think you said you felt very strongly about 800 million gallons of ethanol exports. Is that correct?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And so then if you add to that somewhere 13.7 billion to 14 billion gallons of E10, why would you not feel confident that we're not going to see a very tight balance in 2015 on ethanol supply and demand?
componenttext: Yes. And so then if you add to that somewhere 13.7 billion to 14 billion gallons of E10, why would you not feel confident that we're not going to see a very tight balance in 2015 on ethanol supply and demand?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I do feel confident that we will see a tight balance. As I said, I don't think that all the plans will run at the rate that they will run in November on a full year basis. So the problem with ethanol, David, and this is the problem to model and the uncert
componenttext: I do feel confident that we will see a tight balance. As I said, I don't think that all the plans will run at the rate that they will run in November on a full year basis. So the problem with ethanol, David, and this is the problem to model and the uncertainty sometimes around ethanol is that it moves during the year because of the gasoline consumption is -- has a season. And obviously, our ability also to produce some max rate have a season as well. So sometimes, those things, we -- plants can produce at higher rates when people can drive less. And that produced a little bit of a spike of a margin in the summer and a little bit of a drop of a margin as we get to the end of the year. But we continue to be positive about the overall balances in ethanol rate in here.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just my final question. And you answered this a little bit before, but I just want to just be clear on something. This interaction between North American crush margin results and South American crush margin results, are you trying to draw a
componenttext: Okay. And then just my final question. And you answered this a little bit before, but I just want to just be clear on something. This interaction between North American crush margin results and South American crush margin results, are you trying to draw a parallel here by saying that North American fourth quarter crush margins were particularly strong in part due to the weakness in South American farmer selling, exports, et cetera. Are these 2 factors interrelated? Is kind of one gives to the other? Or was there specific issues in your South American unit that are isolated, such that in a future period, we could see both good results simultaneously in both geographies?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me split that question in 2. On the impact of South America, maybe not a lot of slow farmer selling or being a little bit delayed. We felt -- we feel it 2 ways: One, in better soy crush margins in Europe, not in North America. And we tried to
componenttext: Yes. So let me split that question in 2. On the impact of South America, maybe not a lot of slow farmer selling or being a little bit delayed. We felt -- we feel it 2 ways: One, in better soy crush margins in Europe, not in North America. And we tried to shift during Q4 more crush from rapeseed into soy just because we didn't see that much meal coming to compete in Europe from South America. So you saw it that way. And also, you could see it by having a longer export program in Q1 in North America. That's the way you see it. And to the second point of your question, is absolutely, we can see times in which both are doing very well. As I said, we've had a lot of issues on our own in South America. In this quarter, not only the farm-selling, but we have fertilizers and some other issues that we have there as well. So absolutely, you could see both doing very well in the other quarters.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And hopefully, David, you saw that last year. Last year's fourth quarter, you actually saw South America do extremely well and North America do extremely well. This year, we saw see North America do extremely well. South America did not do as well, and fr
componenttext: And hopefully, David, you saw that last year. Last year's fourth quarter, you actually saw South America do extremely well and North America do extremely well. This year, we saw see North America do extremely well. South America did not do as well, and frankly, a lot of things that occurred in South America was our own doing. So when I kind of look at the results, I look at South America just to comparison of fourth quarter this year versus last year, just directionally, there's about a $100 million swing in South America just because of factors that, frankly, we didn't help ourselves with. And so that just gives you an order of magnitude in terms of what the delta was in Q4 here as it relates to South America.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, guys, to tie it together, what you said in the press release, in the, I don't know, second to third paragraph, was that you expect South American oilseeds will have higher returns in totality in 2015 versus 2014, correct?
componenttext: And then, guys, to tie it together, what you said in the press release, in the, I don't know, second to third paragraph, was that you expect South American oilseeds will have higher returns in totality in 2015 versus 2014, correct?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that sets up to be a very good year in Oilseeds, and maybe this fourth quarter issue in South America is not what we should focus on, but rather the bigger picture of good, strong, tight balances within oilseed processing.
componenttext: So that sets up to be a very good year in Oilseeds, and maybe this fourth quarter issue in South America is not what we should focus on, but rather the bigger picture of good, strong, tight balances within oilseed processing.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015

componenttext: You got it. Yes.

componenttext: A lot of ground has been covered today, but I want to -- one question on the cost savings. I'm thinking about that 2015 bridge. How should I think about the year-on-year increment of savings realized in '15 versus where you actually flowed through the P&L in '14?

componenttext: Yes. I think you should expect from these programs about $100 million going into '15.

componenttext: That's a general comment. I mean, when we try to assign that $100 million, I hope it applies, but don't hold me to it. I may update you later on that. And also, you have to offset some inflation, obviously, that we have every year. So -- but yes, about $100 million should roll into 2015 out of our cost saving programs.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then can you just help us think with WILD and the new business unit, the Specialty Ingredient business unit total, how the reporting there is going to look, and then thinking about metrics. I mean, this is -- I mean, revenue
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then can you just help us think with WILD and the new business unit, the Specialty Ingredient business unit total, how the reporting there is going to look, and then thinking about metrics. I mean, this is -- I mean, revenues for your company historically have not been a particularly meaningful metric. I think for Ag business unit, it actually will. Can you help us think about the organic growth of volume and price mix that you would kind of think about on a run rate basis for that unit going forward?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been working on that, Adam. Because as you said so correctly, sometimes, for ingredients, you should see revenue growth. But on the other hand, remember that this division is composed by $1 billion of WILD, which reacts like you described. But
componenttext: Yes, we've been working on that, Adam. Because as you said so correctly, sometimes, for ingredients, you should see revenue growth. But on the other hand, remember that this division is composed by $1 billion of WILD, which reacts like you described. But also $1.5 billion from products that we contributed, that some of them are soy proteins that when soy comes down, sometimes we expand margins, but actually, revenue goes down. So we're trying to come up with a good set of measurements that actually reflect the performance of the business without getting -- without misleading people on that. So I think for a while, it will be a combination of a strong revenue growth, a strong gains in some customers on maybe volumes and also returns, obviously. Margins are relatively healthy in that industry. So just percentage margins are not important at that point. It's more about winning businesses.

componenttext: Yes. I think that, obviously, Brazilians are trying to help the sugar mills in general and so more is going to be used internally at the same time that they're increasing gasoline prices. So we don't expect Brazil to be a competitor for exports out there and it may be recipients of some of the U.S. exports. And so certainly, we don't see Brazil at this point in time as a big threat.

Or this year, excuse me, in 2015?
