componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Piken with Cleveland Research.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just wanted to circle back to Ag Services here for a minute. And you specifically -- in the past, you talked about $200 million to $250 million in EBIT as a relatively run line to use. I mean, in light of what you did in 4Q, do you think there were
componenttext: Yes, I just wanted to circle back to Ag Services here for a minute. And you specifically -- in the past, you talked about $200 million to $250 million in EBIT as a relatively run line to use. I mean, in light of what you did in 4Q, do you think there were some push-forward in terms of some of the 2015 earnings? Or is that the right run rate to use? Or with this record harvest, should we be using a higher number?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's difficult between -- obviously, in the last quarter, you have some things shifting from one quarter to the other, sometimes in one direction or the other. I would say the range that we're thinking about it for 2015 is something in the range of $850 m
componenttext: It's difficult between -- obviously, in the last quarter, you have some things shifting from one quarter to the other, sometimes in one direction or the other. I would say the range that we're thinking about it for 2015 is something in the range of $850 million to $950 million. You have to think that when this realignment that we have of divisions of businesses within the division, Ag Services have lost basically $50 million of annual profit that has been transferred to other businesses. So considering that transfer, we are thinking that the range you should consider is something about between $850 million to $950 million per year.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's really helpful. And then with respect to the kind of the WILD Flavors, Specialty Ingredients, I know you had sort of targeted $0.10 to $0.15 accretion for this year. I mean, can you give us some sort of flavor for how quickly that can ramp up
componenttext: Okay, that's really helpful. And then with respect to the kind of the WILD Flavors, Specialty Ingredients, I know you had sort of targeted $0.10 to $0.15 accretion for this year. I mean, can you give us some sort of flavor for how quickly that can ramp up? You've, at your Analyst Day, gave Airtel Afric [ph] revenue target, but what should we be thinking sort of in the outer years?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We provided the guidance when we announced the acquisition back in July. First full year, $0.10 to $0.15 per share accretion. We're still on track towards that particular range, Mike. I mean, as we kind of work through our plans, we see that in the n
componenttext: Yes. We provided the guidance when we announced the acquisition back in July. First full year, $0.10 to $0.15 per share accretion. We're still on track towards that particular range, Mike. I mean, as we kind of work through our plans, we see that in the numbers. Actually, there may be a little bit of risk towards the downside just because of currency translation impacts, particularly on WILD's European business. But overall, we still feel good about that range for calendar year 2015.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, finally, last question is on the $550 million in cost savings that you're targeting over the next 5 years, can you give us some sort of breakdown by segment where you would expect to see the majority of that benefit?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, finally, last question is on the $550 million in cost savings that you're targeting over the next 5 years, can you give us some sort of breakdown by segment where you would expect to see the majority of that benefit?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say, to be honest, I don't have it at the top of my head by segment. We have -- internally, we have a pipeline of like 10 categories. Some of those categories include things like margin from new products as we fight for the grind. We have categori
componenttext: I would say, to be honest, I don't have it at the top of my head by segment. We have -- internally, we have a pipeline of like 10 categories. Some of those categories include things like margin from new products as we fight for the grind. We have categories about maintenance reduction or improvements. We have categories such as Energy Efficiency. I would say, corn tends to have the bulk sometimes of that, probably in the range of maybe 40% to 50% just because of the size of the assets. Ag Services had a little bit less because you have less fixed assets and more maybe transportation assets. So I would say, if I got to give a guess, but I don't have it, it's something like 50% Corn, maybe 35% Oilseeds and maybe 15% Ag Services, give or take.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Tiberio with Miller Tabak.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Tiberio with Miller Tabak.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Juan, I guess looking at oilseed demand, there's been a lot of focus in the questioning around farmer selling and utilization between North America and South America, but we have seen a little bit more commentary in the trade press around just a more unce
componenttext: Juan, I guess looking at oilseed demand, there's been a lot of focus in the questioning around farmer selling and utilization between North America and South America, but we have seen a little bit more commentary in the trade press around just a more uncertain environment around incremental oilseed demand in Asia. Just wanted to kind of get your sense as to how you're seeing that frame-up on a full year basis and then from the first half to the second half.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So at this point in time, we're seeing still good export demand in the U.S., where we have it for January and February. We expect it's going to be a little bit of a shift to that in March to South America. When we're looking to China, we see China se
componenttext: Yes. So at this point in time, we're seeing still good export demand in the U.S., where we have it for January and February. We expect it's going to be a little bit of a shift to that in March to South America. When we're looking to China, we see China seed demand a little bit down at this point in time. Profitability for farmers to raise pigs or chicken is not great at this point in time, part is the slowdown in the economy, part is the government's anti-graft campaign because we do some consumption there. But we expect that, as I talk to my colleagues in China, to increase, to improve during the year. So right now, it's a little bit soft.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is there any other regions that could potentially offset China? I know there's been some talk about India potentially liberalizing their imports, tax regime on oilseeds. Is that kind of factored into your outlook? Or is that just so difficult to
componenttext: Okay. And is there any other regions that could potentially offset China? I know there's been some talk about India potentially liberalizing their imports, tax regime on oilseeds. Is that kind of factored into your outlook? Or is that just so difficult to handicap at this point?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I will say, you will continue to see poultry consumption growing per capita basis in India, so that's also, obviously, bullish since there are, like, 1.4 billion people. I will say overall, we continue to see mill demand growing 3% to 4% year-over-year, a
componenttext: I will say, you will continue to see poultry consumption growing per capita basis in India, so that's also, obviously, bullish since there are, like, 1.4 billion people. I will say overall, we continue to see mill demand growing 3% to 4% year-over-year, and we feel good about that. So I think China has these ups and downs, but we don't foresee a slowdown in demand. At this point in time, for 2015, we still believe 3% to 4% up in mill demand.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just shifting gears back to the WILD Flavors. I know there was a lot of talk at your Investor Day that, really, the next stage is taking this platform and really proliferating it out to a lot of your CPG relationships. Can you just kind of
componenttext: Great. And then just shifting gears back to the WILD Flavors. I know there was a lot of talk at your Investor Day that, really, the next stage is taking this platform and really proliferating it out to a lot of your CPG relationships. Can you just kind of talk, I know it's still early days, but how is the win rates looking with a lot of your large CPG clients? Any notable wins in the quarter? How is that progress tracking to your expectations?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question, Tim. Listen, the first thing that I would like to say about WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients is that I'm pleased to report that we're getting the people equation right. In this case, it's the capability. So obviously, a
componenttext:
Yes, that's a great question, Tim. Listen, the first thing that I would like to say about WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients is that I'm pleased to report that we're getting the people equation right. In this case, it's the capability. So obviously, are there -- both were successful companies individually in their own rights and ingredients so the capabilities are intact. But the issue is, can you combine the people and can you get that? And I'm pleased to report that, that's doing -- going extremely well. So we're very confident we're going to hit our 2015 synergy targets. 
In terms of customer, we have had more than 100 customer engagements so far, and we have recorded -- I was checking with the team late last week. I have every Friday a meeting with them to check this. We had more than 355 ideas with actual efforts behind for each customer. So I wouldn't disclose any specific customer, obviously, for confidentiality reasons. There -- these are all innovations that we will keep to ourselves, and hopefully, you will see it reflected in revenue growth, but we're very enthusiastic about how customers are responding to the combined capabilities of both companies.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi. Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zaslow with BMO.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi. Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zaslow with BMO.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can -- I just want to go back to the ethanol. This gives -- I'm puzzled by it a little bit. So how does the ethanol margins actually go higher in this current oil and corn environment? You said corn is going to stay relatively stable and assuming  that co
componenttext: Can -- I just want to go back to the ethanol. This gives -- I'm puzzled by it a little bit. So how does the ethanol margins actually go higher in this current oil and corn environment? You said corn is going to stay relatively stable and assuming  that corn -- that oil stays stable. If supply gets cut at the prices you need to trade it at a premium to GAAP, is that a sustainable situation? I guess, that's where I'm kind of having a hard time with the ethanol margin recovery.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think, listen, I see -- we see driving miles of gasoline consumption going up and we see a stable exports out there. So -- but the issue is if we produce that 15 billion gallons, I mean, it is -- we're not going to have excellent margins. So at the e
componenttext: So I think, listen, I see -- we see driving miles of gasoline consumption going up and we see a stable exports out there. So -- but the issue is if we produce that 15 billion gallons, I mean, it is -- we're not going to have excellent margins. So at the end of the day, it would require some rationalization of capacity. We expect some of this low margins that we're having right now, giving people some -- giving people in the high part of the cost curve some problems. And that's why we continue to emphasize our cost position, and that's all we can drive. How we can drive is our cost position, our fight for the grind and the way we commercially play between produced gallons and purchased gallons. So other than that, it's all speculation, to be honest.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you think that gas can trade at a premium to ethanol and know the demand will remain. Is that fair?
componenttext: Okay. So you think that gas can trade at a premium to ethanol and know the demand will remain. Is that fair?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, we think so. Yes.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, we think so. Yes.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the...
componenttext: Okay. On the...

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Remember that you have a $0.70 range at this point in time. And I think that we can go 10% higher and we can still be a very competitive oxygenator there.
componenttext: Remember that you have a $0.70 range at this point in time. And I think that we can go 10% higher and we can still be a very competitive oxygenator there.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair. I -- obviously, my confusion is trying figuring that out. I appreciate it. On Ag Services, the $850 million to $950 million is roughly $200 million per quarter basis. Over the next 2 years to 3 years, as you make these improvements that
componenttext: Okay. That's fair. I -- obviously, my confusion is trying figuring that out. I appreciate it. On Ag Services, the $850 million to $950 million is roughly $200 million per quarter basis. Over the next 2 years to 3 years, as you make these improvements that you've been talking about at the Analyst Day, and it seems like maybe there's even some cost-cutting there, will that go up to, say, $250 million to $300 million per quarter? Like, how does that shift? It seems like you have very changeable gains to be had here, and I'm just trying to put a number on that. Is that a fair point to say about $250 million to $300 million after all these adjustments are made?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tim, the way I think about Ag Services is we believe Ag Services will continue to go up hopefully in that range. It's difficult for me to quantify it, and I'd tell you why. In the other businesses, we can add some of the cost improvements. In Ag Services,
componenttext: Tim, the way I think about Ag Services is we believe Ag Services will continue to go up hopefully in that range. It's difficult for me to quantify it, and I'd tell you why. In the other businesses, we can add some of the cost improvements. In Ag Services, it becomes a little bit more based on whether we add an investment that did -- that increases our origination or our transportation, or we do something like we did with Dubfor [ph] in which -- we combine in a global trade desk or we move more into destination marketing and we capture a bigger part of the margin there. So our plans and our expectation at that range is going to evolve over time. It's a little bit more difficult to say exactly the number at this point, and I wouldn't venture that, but we are continuing to build to increase margins and our share in Ag Services.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And my final question is, at the Analyst Day, you had said that there was a level of preparedness. I like that word that you used for Ag Services, and obviously, that generated a very, very significant return during the quarter. Do you feel like you need
componenttext: And my final question is, at the Analyst Day, you had said that there was a level of preparedness. I like that word that you used for Ag Services, and obviously, that generated a very, very significant return during the quarter. Do you feel like you need the same preparedness that you had in the third quarter -- for the fourth quarter, that you'll have for the first quarter?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, absolutely. We are very well-prepared to handle this first quarter. It will be, as I said, a different quarter. When I was saying the preparedness, it's because, obviously, this team was so looking forward to show what their asset base and the
componenttext: Absolutely, absolutely. We are very well-prepared to handle this first quarter. It will be, as I said, a different quarter. When I was saying the preparedness, it's because, obviously, this team was so looking forward to show what their asset base and their capabilities could do in a full crop because of the 2 very bad years in the previous crop. But absolutely, they are the same level of preparedness for Q1.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just maybe clear up a couple of points on ethanol. I think you said in a previous comment that you thought you would see -- I think you said you felt very strongly about 800 million gallons of ethanol exports. Is that correct?
componenttext: I wanted to just maybe clear up a couple of points on ethanol. I think you said in a previous comment that you thought you would see -- I think you said you felt very strongly about 800 million gallons of ethanol exports. Is that correct?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And so then if you add to that somewhere 13.7 billion to 14 billion gallons of E10, why would you not feel confident that we're not going to see a very tight balance in 2015 on ethanol supply and demand?
componenttext: Yes. And so then if you add to that somewhere 13.7 billion to 14 billion gallons of E10, why would you not feel confident that we're not going to see a very tight balance in 2015 on ethanol supply and demand?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I do feel confident that we will see a tight balance. As I said, I don't think that all the plans will run at the rate that they were running in November on a full year basis. So the problem with ethanol, David, and this is the problem to model and the un
componenttext: I do feel confident that we will see a tight balance. As I said, I don't think that all the plans will run at the rate that they were running in November on a full year basis. So the problem with ethanol, David, and this is the problem to model and the uncertainty sometimes around ethanol is that it moves during the year because of the gasoline consumption is -- has a season. And obviously, our ability also to produce some max rate have a season as well. So sometimes, those things, we -- plants can produce at higher rates when people can drive less. And that produced a little bit of a spike of a margin in the summer and a little bit of a drop of a margin as we get to the end of the year. But we continue to be positive about the overall balances in ethanol rate in here.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just my final question. And you answered this a little bit before, but I want to just be clear on something. This interaction between North American crush margin results and South American crush margin results, are you trying to draw a para
componenttext: Okay. And then just my final question. And you answered this a little bit before, but I want to just be clear on something. This interaction between North American crush margin results and South American crush margin results, are you trying to draw a parallel here by saying that North American fourth quarter crush margins were particularly strong in part due to the weakness in South American farmer selling, exports, et cetera. Are these 2 factors interrelated? Is kind of one gives to the other? Or was there specific issues in your South American unit that are isolated, such that in a future period, we could see both good results simultaneously in both geographies?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me split that question in 2. On the impact of South America, maybe not a lot of slow farmer selling or being a little bit delayed. We felt -- we feel it 2 ways: One, in better soy crush margins in Europe, not in North America. And we tried to
componenttext: Yes. So let me split that question in 2. On the impact of South America, maybe not a lot of slow farmer selling or being a little bit delayed. We felt -- we feel it 2 ways: One, in better soy crush margins in Europe, not in North America. And we tried to shift during Q4 more crush from grapeseed into soy just because we didn't see that much meal coming to compete in Europe from South America. So you saw it that way. And also, you could see it by having a longer export program in Q1 in North America. That's the way you see it. And to the second point of your question, is absolutely, we can see times in which both are doing very well. As I said, we've had a lot of issues on our own in South America. In this quarter, not only the farmer selling, but we have fertilizers and some other issues that we have there as well. So absolutely, you could see both doing very well in other quarters.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: In fact, David, you saw that last year. Last year's fourth quarter, you actually saw South America do extremely well and North America do extremely well. This year, we saw North America do extremely well. South America did not do as well, and frankly, a l
componenttext: In fact, David, you saw that last year. Last year's fourth quarter, you actually saw South America do extremely well and North America do extremely well. This year, we saw North America do extremely well. South America did not do as well, and frankly, a lot of things that occurred in South America was our own doing. So when I kind of look at the results, I look at South America just to comparison of fourth quarter this year versus last year, just directionally, there's about a $100 million swing in South America just because of factors that, frankly, we didn't help ourselves with. And so that just gives you an order of magnitude in terms of what the delta was in Q4 here as it relates to South America.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, guys, to tie it together, what you said in the press release, in the, I don't know, second to third paragraph, was that you expect South American oilseeds will have higher returns in totality in 2015 versus 2014, correct?
componenttext: And then, guys, to tie it together, what you said in the press release, in the, I don't know, second to third paragraph, was that you expect South American oilseeds will have higher returns in totality in 2015 versus 2014, correct?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So then it sets up to be a very good year in Oilseeds, and maybe this fourth quarter issue in South America is not what we should focus on, but rather the bigger picture of good, strong, tight balances within oilseed processing.
componenttext: So then it sets up to be a very good year in Oilseeds, and maybe this fourth quarter issue in South America is not what we should focus on, but rather the bigger picture of good, strong, tight balances within oilseed processing.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: You got it. Yes.
componenttext: You got it. Yes.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been working on that, Adam. Because as you said so correctly, sometimes, for ingredients, you should see revenue growth. But on the other hand, remember that this division is composed by $1 billion of WILD, which reacts like you described. But
componenttext: Yes, we've been working on that, Adam. Because as you said so correctly, sometimes, for ingredients, you should see revenue growth. But on the other hand, remember that this division is composed by $1 billion of WILD, which reacts like you described. But also $1.5 billion from products that we contributed, that some of them are soy proteins that when soy comes down, sometimes we expand margins, but actually, revenue goes down. So we're trying to come up with a good set of measurements that actually reflect the performance of the business without getting -- without misleading people on that. So I think for a while, it will be a combination of strong revenue growth, a strong gains in some customers on maybe volumes and also returns, obviously. Margins are relatively healthy in that industry. So just percentage margins are not that important at that point. It's more about winning businesses.

componenttext: Yes. I think that, obviously, Brazilians are trying to help the sugar mills in general and so more is going to be used internally at the same time that they're increasing gasoline prices. So we don't expect Brazil to be a competitor for exports out there and it may be recipients of some of the U.S. exports. And so certainly, we don't see Brazil at this point in time as a big threat.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think so. Listen, I mean, I -- you can see the strength of the way our team played with this condition. Last year, we made it more into the summer. And this year, we had a great performance now into the winter. So every year, there is a peaking which yo
componenttext: I think so. Listen, I mean, I -- you can see the strength of the way our team played with this condition. Last year, we made it more into the summer. And this year, we had a great performance now into the winter. So every year, there is a peaking which you make the profit given the market conditions, and I think that the team adjusts to that. But we see no reason for which not being able to repeat this next Q4.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one quick follow-up on all of that. Looking forward, talking about overall demand and looking at demand into next year, is there is sufficient demand to, let's say, if you had a normal crop year, to reduce our carryovers in crops next
componenttext: Okay. And then just one quick follow-up on all of that. Looking forward, talking about overall demand and looking at demand into next year, is there is sufficient demand to, let's say, if you had a normal crop year, to reduce our carryovers in crops next year? Or should we gradually see a little bit of a build here in our corn and soybean carryovers, given the strength of the U.S. dollar, particularly? And I guess, the only offsetting factor particularly, like in corn, there's always talks of China could be a 20 million to 25 million metric tonne buyer, it comes -- crops up all the time. Any comments on the demand side on that function? And it seems to me that the general direction of corn and maybe soybeans over the next 12 months, a year from now, I would expect those complexes to be lower. But I'm interested in your thoughts.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think demand -- I mean, if you looked at trendlines in demands, they continue to be very positive, whether it be corn, soybean or meal around the world. So nothing fundamentally has changed in terms of our long-term assessment of continued demand g
componenttext: Yes, I think demand -- I mean, if you looked at trendlines in demands, they continue to be very positive, whether it be corn, soybean or meal around the world. So nothing fundamentally has changed in terms of our long-term assessment of continued demand growth for these agricultural products. As you know, we've actually had a pretty favorable supply conditions over the past couple of years and as you know, weather is a factor. So when you ask a question about what carryovers in the future will be, we feel pretty good about the demand side. In the supply side, there could be weather aberrations somewhere around the world which will impact the supply side and that will have an impact on carryover. But generally speaking, we feel that we're in a pretty good environment right now in terms of just general global supply-demand balances and in, frankly, subdued commodity prices in the soft goods.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: But if you look, Eric, also, if you look at the overall production and planted area around the world, it continues to grow, and it's been growing for a while. And it will have to continue to grow as we need to feel the growing population. So we continue t
componenttext: But if you look, Eric, also, if you look at the overall production and planted area around the world, it continues to grow, and it's been growing for a while. And it will have to continue to grow as we need to feel the growing population. So we continue to see the 3%, 4% increase that Ray have just described. And I think that we will have to come with a favorable weather to continue with this, but we foresee stable crop prices, let's say, going forward.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Stable crop prices, okay. And is there any window for China to be a 25 million metric tonne buyer anytime soon of U.S. corn?
componenttext: Okay. Stable crop prices, okay. And is there any window for China to be a 25 million metric tonne buyer anytime soon of U.S. corn?

componenttext: Hard to say, Eric. I don't know if I can answer with any -- I mean, it is just a speculation, to be honest, at this point, so...
