headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Archer Daniels Midland Company First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like introduce your host for today's call, Mark Schweitzer, Vice P
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Archer Daniels Midland Company First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like introduce your host for today's call, Mark Schweitzer, Vice President, Investor Relations for Archer Daniels Midland Company. Mr. Schechter, you may begin.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to ADM's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Starting tomorrow, a replay of today's call will be available at adm.com.For those following the presentation, please turn to Slide 2, the company's safe ha
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to ADM's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Starting tomorrow, a replay of today's call will be available at adm.com.
For those following the presentation, please turn to Slide 2, the company's safe harbor statement, which says that some of our comments constitute forward-looking statements that reflects management's current views and estimates of future economic circumstances, industry conditions, company performance and financial results.
These statements are based on many assumptions and factors that are subject to risks and uncertainties. ADM has provided additional information in its reports on file with the SEC concerning assumptions and factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in this presentation, and you should carefully review these assumptions and factors in our SEC report. To the extent permitted under applicable law, ADM assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements as a result of new information or future events.
On today's call, our Chief Executive Officer, Juan Luciano, will provide an overview of the quarter. Our Chief Financial Officer, Ray Young, will review financial highlights and corporate results. Then Juan will review the drivers of our performance in the quarter and provide an update on our scorecard, and then they will take your questions. Please turn to Slide 3. I'll now turn the call over to Juan.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marc. Good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today. This morning, we reported adjusted earnings per share of $0.77, that's 40% higher than the year ago period. For adjusted operating segment profit was $883 million. Adjusted ROIC
componenttext:
Thank you, Marc. Good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today. This morning, we reported adjusted earnings per share of $0.77, that's 40% higher than the year ago period. For adjusted operating segment profit was $883 million. Adjusted ROIC of 9.5% was 290 basis points above our cost of capital. 
In the first quarter, the ADM team demonstrated their ability to leverage the strength of our diversified business model. The oilseed team capitalized on favorable market conditions and delivered outstanding results with strong performances in each region.
In Ag Services, our recently created global trade desk, or GTD platform, drove higher merchandise volumes. Our new WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients business went off to a great start towards achieving the cost and revenue synergies we identified last year. Together, these performance has helped deliver a good quarter overall even as slower industry ethanol margins limited earnings in corn and the strong dollar limited U.S. grain exports.
We have continued to advance the strategic plan we shared at our December Investor Day. In the area of optimizing the core, we announced the acquisition of a Belgian oil bottling business, helping us reach out wider customer base and creating a new output for our European crushing assets. 
And the WSs site team has been working with customers as they develop and launch new products using SCI, WILD and ADM ingredients. We have more than 200 joint customer engagements, building a pipeline of more than 400 projects, resulting already in more than 30 revenue synergy wins across a number of regions and businesses unit in Q1 alone.
In the area of driving operational efficiencies, we have already identified more than $200 million in run rate savings opportunities toward our goal of $550 million in 5 years. And in the area of strategic expansion, the corn processing business expanded in high growth geographies with the acquisition of the remaining stake of corn wet mills in Bulgaria and Turkey and an increased stake in our facility in Hungary.
I'll provide more detail on our scorecard progress later in the call. Now I'll turn the call over to Ray.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Juan, and good morning, everyone. Slide 4 provides some financial highlights for the quarter. Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $0.77, up 40% from the $0.55 last year. Excluding specified items and also, excluding net timing effects, adjusted
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Juan, and good morning, everyone. Slide 4 provides some financial highlights for the quarter. Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $0.77, up 40% from the $0.55 last year. Excluding specified items and also, excluding net timing effects, adjusted segment operating profit was $883 million, up $94 million.
The effective tax rate for the first quarter was 29% compared to 27% in the first quarter of the prior year. For calendar year 2015, we expect our effective tax rate to be in the 28% to 30% range. Our trailing 4-quarter average adjusted ROIC of 9.5% improved from the 9.0% at the end of the fourth quarter and also significantly improved by 250 basis points from the 7.0% at the end of the first quarter last year.
The 9.5% adjusted ROIC is above our 6.6% annual WACC for 2015, as well as our long-term WACC of 8.0%, as reflected on the graph on Slide 19 in the appendix. Our objective remains to earn 200 basis points over our WACC. In the first quarter, our trailing 4-quarter average Economic Value Added, or EVA, was $742 million based upon adjusted earnings in the annual WACC, up $581 million from 2014.
On Chart 18 in the appendix, you can see the reconciliation of our reported quarterly earnings of $0.77 per share to the adjusted earnings of $0.77 per share. For this quarter, LIFO represented a $2 million pretax credit or less than $0.01 per share after-tax. There are no other adjustments for the quarter.
Slide 5 provides an operating profit summary in the components of our corporate line. Before Juan discusses the operating results, I'd like to highlight some of the unique items that impacted our quarterly results. 
Corn Processing adjusted operating profit, $127 million, excludes approximately $14 million hedge in the effectiveness charges, split relatively evenly amongst file products and sweeteners and starches. In oilseeds, adjusted operating profit, $483 million, excludes approximately $14 million of Cocoa hedged time effects in this quarter. As a reminder, we will also continue to have our cocoa and chocolate businesses as part of our segment reporting results in oil seeds until we have closed on the sales some time later in 2015. They are not treated as discontinued operations in our financial statements due to the lack of materiality of the operations to our overall results. 
Our new forward business segment, WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients, or WFSI for short, is reported to add its own segment for the first time this quarter. The segment includes the 2 businesses we acquired in 2014, WILD Flavors and Specialty Commodities Inc. or SCI, as well as certain specialty ingredients businesses that were previously recorded in ADM's 3 other segments. For purposes of comparison to prior year results, the year ago quarter segment operating profit for Ag Services, corn and oilseeds removed the earnings of the businesses now reported in the WFSI segment. To assist with your analysis, we concluded a chart in the appendix that we cast 2014 segment quarterly results to the new segments.
In the corporate lines, net interest expense was down due to lower interest rates. Unallocated corporate costs were due to or higher due to increased GAAP pension expenses related to changes in discount rates and mortality tables and increased investments in our ERP program, as well as very strategic projects and M&A and divestment activities.
In addition, I want to point out that the strong U.S. dollar and weakness in other currencies, such as the euro and the Brazilian real, did not have a material impact on ADM's overall first quarter net earnings.
On one hand, the strong U.S. dollar did have the negative impact on the competitiveness of our U.S. export programs. And our WFSI segment also had a negative impact in terms of export competitiveness and earnings translation from Europe. On the other hand, the weaker euro, NKR, have a positive impact on our fixed costs around the world relative to revenue streams we're receiving. Also, the weaker motivated Brazilian farmers to sell, thereby, benefiting our origination business in Brazil. So on balance, with the puts and the takes, the net impact was not material. Going forward, we do not expect the currency impact to have a material impact on our overall results for the rest of the year.
I would also like to comment on our GAAP net revenue number that can be found in the appendix. GAAP net revenues for the quarter were $17.5 billion, down from last year's $20.7 billion. The significant reduction is driven by large declines in commodity prices that impact our revenues. But this decline also impacts our cost of goods sold as our input costs are lower. So the key for us is management spread between the revenues and cost of goods sold, which is a core competency of our teams. This dynamic makes operating profit much more relevant when analyzing ADM.
I also want to highlight that the GAAP statements in the prior year do not include the revenues and the cost of WILD and SCI, which transaction closed in the fourth quarter of last year.
Turning to cash flow statement on Slide 6, which shows the cash flows for the 3 months ending March 31, 2015, compared to the same period the prior year. We generated $577 million from operations before working capital changes in the quarter, significantly higher than Q1 last year. Total capital spending for the quarter was $244 million, up from the prior year.
For 2015, we are estimating capital spending in the range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion. This range is higher than our $0.9 billion spending in 2014, which you may recall we reduced the asset of WILD acquisition to assess capital spend avoidance opportunities. As a result, some 2014 spending shifted into 2015. We also have some additional spending for our ERP program and cost reduction projects, as well as the ramp-up of our specialty protein project spending in Brazil, our Fibersol projects in China and the U.S., our lecithin projects in Germany and India.
During the quarter, we spent $566 million to repurchase about 12 million shares towards our 2015 target of $1.5 billion to $2 billion of share repurchases, subject to strategic capital requirements. Our average share count was 639 million diluted shares outstanding, down approximately 24 million from the 663 million at the same time one year ago. Our total return of capital to shareholders for the quarter, including dividends, was over $700 million.
Our first quarter cash flows are consistent with our 2015 calendar year targets of capital allocations, namely CapEx at $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion, approximately $700 million of dividends and $1.5 billion to $2 billion in share repurchases. And all this is consistent with the balanced capital allocation framework we set forth at our December Investor Day.
Slide 7 shows the highlights of our balance sheet as of March 31 for both 2015 and 2014, which remains very strong. Our operating working capital of a $8.1 billion was down $3.4 billion from the year ago period. This decrease was comprised of about $1.6 billion related to lower inventory prices, including the translation impact; about $1.4 billion related to lower inventory quantities and a decrease of about $0.4 billion in other working capital, primarily related to the reclassification of working capital for global cocoa and chocolate businesses under the held-for-sale accounting.
Total debt was about $6.4 billion, resulting in net debt balance that is debt less cash of $5.1 billion, up from the 2014 net debt level of $4.1 billion, in part reflecting the fourth quarter cash flows related to our acquisitions of WILD and SCI.
Our shareholders equity of $18.8 billion is $1.3 billion lower than the level last year with a cumulative translation account impact about $1.6 billion lower due to the strength of the U.S. dollar. We had $5.7 billion in available global credit capacity at the end of December, if you had available cash with access some billion dollars of short-term liquidity.
Next, Juan will take us through a review of our business performance. Juan?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ray. Let's turn to Slide 8. In the first quarter, we earned $883 million of operating profits, excluding specified items. This 12% year-over-year increase in underlying in segment operating profit demonstrates the strength of our diversified busin
componenttext:
Thanks, Ray. Let's turn to Slide 8. In the first quarter, we earned $883 million of operating profits, excluding specified items. This 12% year-over-year increase in underlying in segment operating profit demonstrates the strength of our diversified business model and the team's ability to leverage that model.
In the first quarter, the team capitalized on great opportunities while they continue to advance our strategic plan. Sequentially, of course, the quarter follows a very strong fourth quarter. And with normal seasonality, underlying segment operating profits decreased.
Now I will review the performance of each segment. Starting on Slide 9. In the first quarter, Ag Services results improved 37% over last year. Merchandising and handling saw limited U.S. export competitiveness more than offset by continued improvement in international merchandising, where we saw the benefit of our GTD with merchandise volumes increasing. 
In Transportation, we saw an increasing demand for northbound U.S. bar freight, which mostly offset the decrease in Southbourne demand. Million and others results improved due to a strong margins for flour, grain and feed.
Please turn to Slide 10. Corn Processing results declined in the quarter. In sweeteners and starches, our underlying North American business is doing well with higher margins and volumes in Q1. This was offset by lower contribution from core products, reduced equity earnings from joint ventures and start-up costs related to the Tianjin sweetener facility. And in bioproducts, earnings were lower due to lower ethanol production volumes and a weaker industry margins.
Supply and demand imbalances challenged industry ethanol margins most of the quarter, though conditions in margins have been improving since late March. Let me explain our corn results a bit further.
We said before that we make decisions that will achieve the best overall results for ADM. This quarter, with low industry margins, we made the decision to run our ethanol operations for margins rather than volumes. That helped our earnings in bioproducts. It also had the effect of reducing our production of core products, which limited our earnings in sweeteners and starches. Bottom line, the impact for our overall Corn business was positive.
Slide 11, please. The oilseeds team delivered an outstanding quarter. Crushing and origination had great performances in each region. In North America, the team demonstrated the value of our strong footprint and our effective destination supply chain. 8 to 10 months ago, they determined Q1 will see an extended North American export window. They got maintenance out of the way and positioned soybean supplies so when the margins arrive, they will able to run hard until the seasonal shift to South America came.
In Europe, the team demonstrated the value of the swing capacity of our crush plants when soybean crush margins were more than double canola crush margins will one [ph] the plant's hard and crush a lot of beans. And in South America, the team prepared our network for the large fast harvest. And with a strong dollar Joe Brazilian farmers to sell their beans, we were ready to handle the crop as strong margins.
In refining, packaging, biodiesel and other, lower biodiesel margins in the North America and weaker European demand limited results. South American biodiesel results improved with B 7 implementation.
And in North America, our Strattera's bottle oil joint venture generated strong results with good volumes. Results from Asia rose primarily on Wilmar's improved performance.
Slide 12, please. In their first reporting quarter, the WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients business unit delivered a great start. As I mentioned earlier, the team has been working with a wide range of customers as they develop products using ingredients from all of ADM's business units. Globally, the flavors business is off to a strong start for the year. 
On a constant currency basis, WILD EMEA business performed particularly well. This is a quarter in which demand is seasonally slower and results were limited by ForEx headwinds. We also had mark-to-market losses on currency hedges for future capital purchases for the specialty protein plant in Brazil. The process itself is benefiting from the weakened real versus the dollar. This is an exciting business with an energetic team and they are off to an absolutely great start.
Now on Slide 13, I'd like to update you on how we're strengthening and growing our company. This is the scorecard we presented at the Investor Day in December. It lists the actions we are taking to help grow our business, our earnings and our returns. We highlighted some of the areas in which we made significant progress in the quarter. I'll discuss a few.
In Ag Services, we launched our Arco, having a wide range of services to our Arco barge operations. With ADM's logistical expertise and global reach, we provide the customers along the lower Mississippi range of services that nobody else offers. As I mentioned, we saw the benefit of our GTD platform that we developed following the Toepfer acquisition. 
And today, we are announcing that we have agreed to acquire full ownership of our joint venture complexes at Constanza, Romania, a black seed [indiscernible] of the Danube. This acquisition builds on the investments we have made in our Danube briefer network since 2011 and further strengthens our origination and transportation capabilities in Eastern Europe.
In corn, we sold our lactic acid business, exiting the business for which we didn't see a fast to acceptable resumes in a reasonable timeframe. And we acquired the remainder of the Bulgarian and Turkish wet mills and expanded our stake in the Hungary plant, positioning our selves well for when EU sugar production folded are lifted.
We continue the structure of our feed premix plant in Nanjing. And this morning, we are announcing plans to build the fourth seed plant in China in Sanso, as well as one in Minnesota. 
In oilseeds, we're working with Cardinal Nola on the divestures series of our chocolate and cocoa businesses. We are targeting closing both in Q3 subject to final approvals and completion of transitional activities. We agreed to acquire an oil bottling business in Belgium. This acquisition will provide another demand stream for our oilseed processing operations, reducing our reliance on biodiesel and growing our package oil business. And as we mentioned on the last call, we are creating a joint venture to quadruple the size of our corn in Northern Brazil, improving our ability to export from this increasingly productive region.
In WSSI, related to the WILD acquisition, we remain on track to deliver $100 million in synergies over the next 3 years, and we are on track for $0.10 to $0.15 accretion in 2015, although this will likely be in the lower end of the range due to the strong dollar.
And we continue to advance our construction project in Brazil, China, Germany, India and the U.S. And in the area of driving operational efficiencies, as I mentioned, we have identified more than $200 million in run rate savings towards our goal of $550 million in 5 years. As part of this effort, we launched a global improvement initiative involving colleagues across all regions and businesses in evaluating every aspects of our business for improvement opportunities.
In the first quarter, we implemented project that will achieve about $60 million in annual run rate savings. We'll update you on our scorecard each quarter. And over time, you should expect to see the results of these actions improve earnings and returns.
So before we take your questions, I wanted to offer some additional perspective as we look forward. We continue to be excited about 2015. We came into the year with a lot of positive momentum, which we expect to continue through the year. Good early planting progress and long-term weather forecast suggests a good likelihood for excellent U.S. crops. A large harvest combined with big carryouts of corn, soybean and wheat could give us opportunities for very good carriers at the end of the year. Those, combined with expected solid global demand point to very high utilization of our storage, transportation and processing assets in North America and Europe later this year.
U.S. gasoline consumption continues to improve. That will translate into stronger domestic demand for ethanol. These, combined with a strong exports, will keep our assets running hard, especially as we move through the summer driving season.
Demand for sweeteners and flavors will benefit from the seasonal decap in Northern Hemisphere beverage consumption. The WSCI team is off to a great start. They will continue to deliver synergies, and we are confident they will meet the 2015 accretion goals.
We are also excited by our customer engagements. Every business unit has been working with existing customers, as well as new customers. We are collaborating across the organization more than ever before, working on new types of projects, delivering wins, improving margins. And the team will continue to deliver our clear and aggressive strategic plan, the pla that is already contravening to our bottom line, a plan that returned 9.5% this quarter, the plan that will continue to grow our EVA. 
With that, operator, please open the line for questions.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Evan Morris with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Evan Morris with Bank of America.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just the first question on ethanol. Just -- you talked about the margin outlook improving since late March. A lot of the work that we do on it, the conversations that we had, suggest, I guess, that the industry is running at operating profit per gallon in
componenttext: Just the first question on ethanol. Just -- you talked about the margin outlook improving since late March. A lot of the work that we do on it, the conversations that we had, suggest, I guess, that the industry is running at operating profit per gallon in sort of that mid 20s right now. And just, I guess, one to give a sense as to what you're seeing. Is that consistent with where ADM is running now? And just sort of your based on the information that you have and your outlook, where do you see margins tracking and sort of maybe for the full year on average or exiting the year? Just a little bit more context about where you are now and where you see it going over the next quarter or 2.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. We are constructive on ethanol margin. If you think about it, April has been a relatively big month for shutdowns as people saw some of the margins were relatively low in March, some people anticipated some of the seasonal shutdowns. So we
componenttext: Yes, thank you. We are constructive on ethanol margin. If you think about it, April has been a relatively big month for shutdowns as people saw some of the margins were relatively low in March, some people anticipated some of the seasonal shutdowns. So we've seen margins improving since the late part of March. We see this with optimism. We see demand in the U.S. growing due to low gasoline prices, about 2% to 3% per year. That will put the industry around 138 billion, 140 billion gallons of gasoline. That and the increased export, we exported very well in Q1. If you look at January and February export estimates, they are annualized at around 1 billion gallon because we spotted in those 2 months 152 million gallons. But if you take the last week of April, that export annualized was around also in the 1 billion range. So we see export for the year between 800 and maybe a little bit north of that for the year, plus maybe 13.8 billion to 14 billion gallons of domestic gasoline demand. We see very high capacity utilization. So we face this season with a lot of optimism in regards to ethanol.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: But are you -- is what you're seeing with ethanol margins in the industry right now, it seems to be around that mid-20s. Is that $0.20 per gallon on an operating profit basis? Is that pretty consistent with what you're seeing right now within ADM?
componenttext: But are you -- is what you're seeing with ethanol margins in the industry right now, it seems to be around that mid-20s. Is that $0.20 per gallon on an operating profit basis? Is that pretty consistent with what you're seeing right now within ADM?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's in the ballpark. It's moving, but it's in the ballpark.
componenttext: It's in the ballpark. It's moving, but it's in the ballpark.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second, you kind of touched on it a little bit. But just wondering if you can put just a little bit more context around -- you have the record crop in North America last year. South America looks strong. Early commentary the North American
componenttext: Okay. And then second, you kind of touched on it a little bit. But just wondering if you can put just a little bit more context around -- you have the record crop in North America last year. South America looks strong. Early commentary the North American planting suggest another big crop. So I mean -- I know there's a lot of things that can change industry dynamics pretty quickly. But you talked about sort of the positive outlook in the fourth quarter, given some of these dynamics -- or through the fourth quarter, given the -- some of these dynamics. But can you put some context on, as you sit here today and you take a look how the rest of the year shapes up, can you give us some context as to do you anticipate this going to be like a much bigger year than last year? Just to -- I mean, I know things are heading the right direction. But if you can put some context around sort of the magnitude and how strong this year could be.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, obviously, we started the year strong with Ag Services delivering 37% more profit than the same quarter last year. And as we see the good planting, as you described, and plentiful of crops and the stocks around the world, we see a good transition to
componenttext: Yes, obviously, we started the year strong with Ag Services delivering 37% more profit than the same quarter last year. And as we see the good planting, as you described, and plentiful of crops and the stocks around the world, we see a good transition to the next crop with plentiful of inventories that will provide carries opportunity. And there is a lot of business to do ahead of us. So the Ag Services theme, the grain team, is preparing for all that, is preparing our assets, is preparing commercially to do these. And we expect the second half to be very strong for them.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Samuelson with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Samuelson with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe first on oilseeds, which was truly a tremendous quarter. Can we talk through the forward outlook there? I mean, as we wind down the North American crush, how much of that can shift to South America? And I mean, presumably, there is a bit of a one-ti
componenttext: Maybe first on oilseeds, which was truly a tremendous quarter. Can we talk through the forward outlook there? I mean, as we wind down the North American crush, how much of that can shift to South America? And I mean, presumably, there is a bit of a one-time kind of exceptional beat. But thoughts about how sustainable the oilseed outlook is as you move through the balance of the year, considering kind of where softseeds margin are in Europe and to your South American exposures.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say, Adam, the oilseed team, as you described, had an outstanding performance. But not everything was hitting in 8 cylinders. If you describe, soft seed was kind of not very profitable and biodiesel had some headwinds as well. So most of the
componenttext: Yes, I would say, Adam, the oilseed team, as you described, had an outstanding performance. But not everything was hitting in 8 cylinders. If you describe, soft seed was kind of not very profitable and biodiesel had some headwinds as well. So most of the profits were concentrated in soybean that's helped very high capacity utilization around the world. As you described, the shift starts from North America to South America. So South America, crushing margins still are good. And we crush a lot of soybeans in Europe, taking advantage of our swing capacity. And we're going to see a little bit of a softening of that as we see every year, which is a normal seasonality of that. But the business is running very, very well. The implemented a lot of improvements, and we're seeing those improvements coming through in the P&L. So overall, in the year, we continue to feel very strongly about the year that oilseed is going to have.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And within that, specifically, your port in South America origination business in oilseeds that you talked about a strong March as the real weakened and since appreciated and all through April. Has farmer selling continued in South America? Or are you see
componenttext: And within that, specifically, your port in South America origination business in oilseeds that you talked about a strong March as the real weakened and since appreciated and all through April. Has farmer selling continued in South America? Or are you seeing that slow? And maybe the same comment on farmer selling in the U.S.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, slightly different situations. In the U.S., the farmer in concentrating in planting right now and rightfully. So there has been a little commercialization. In South America, it's the dynamic you described and I think Ray explained in his commentary,
componenttext: Yes, slightly different situations. In the U.S., the farmer in concentrating in planting right now and rightfully. So there has been a little commercialization. In South America, it's the dynamic you described and I think Ray explained in his commentary, which is very much dependent on the real dollar relationship. And it's been very volatile this last couple of weeks. So it just changes as the farmer see an opportunity to sell, given the real. So I would say we'll continue to be volatile at this point.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I can squeeze one more just on biodiesel. U.S. and Europe, any thoughts or signs that could improve as you go through the balance of the year expectations for that business moving forward?
componenttext: If I can squeeze one more just on biodiesel. U.S. and Europe, any thoughts or signs that could improve as you go through the balance of the year expectations for that business moving forward?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the -- normally, as we get into the summer rather, we see a little bit more activity, obviously. Brazil was good with the B 7 that's helped our profitability a little bit there. And in the U.S., it all that's on the expectation on June
componenttext: Well, I think that the -- normally, as we get into the summer rather, we see a little bit more activity, obviously. Brazil was good with the B 7 that's helped our profitability a little bit there. And in the U.S., it all that's on the expectation on June 1 and RBOs and all that announcement. So at this point in time, both businesses are challenged.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you dig in a little bit deeper into your revenue synergies, the WILD flavor side? You said the 30  revenue synergy wins in the quarter. Just go us some examples of what those actually are.
componenttext: Could you dig in a little bit deeper into your revenue synergies, the WILD flavor side? You said the 30  revenue synergy wins in the quarter. Just go us some examples of what those actually are.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's difficult in this area to provide concrete examples. And because, obviously, we respect the confidentiality of our customers, and all these are innovations for them to increase their revenue and differentiate themselves. But we're excited about
componenttext: Yes, it's difficult in this area to provide concrete examples. And because, obviously, we respect the confidentiality of our customers, and all these are innovations for them to increase their revenue and differentiate themselves. But we're excited about it because we got 2 pipelines here going on. One is in the pipeline that we inherited from WILD themselves, but it was very robust that they continue to grow earnings and revenue every year. And then the synergy pipeline that we got by mixing basically the ingredients that ADM provided. Remember, we contributed $1.5 billion of revenue worth of ingredients into this new division. And then the product that SCI brings and also, the product that WILD. So we handle -- we had several conferences for innovation where we had customer teams working together with their customers. And that's where we generated this pipeline that I described. Again, we measured it in terms of engagements. And obviously, we measure in terms of potential revenue and margin. This is the first quarter, obviously, of this business running. So the best -- the first order of business, obviously, is to make sure that we keep our customer momentum so all the team is very much divided in 2 sets of people: The people that are working on their cost revenue or the cost synergy, and the people that are continuing to be engaged with customers. We're very happy with our engagement with the customers. Our combined culture, if you will, the combination of SCI and WILD and ADM has been very, very good. People are working together seamlessly. And I think customers have seen only benefits from these. So we wanted to report on that. Off to a great start, customers seeing the opportunities, and we're seeing the opportunities to be more of our products to our solutions.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then switching gears a little bit. Could you comment on the railcar standards? I know that your ethanol non-Jack of a deal P10 1 11 [ph] probably don't need to be retrofitted until 2023. But does the slowdown and the speed or any of the other rails ha
componenttext: And then switching gears a little bit. Could you comment on the railcar standards? I know that your ethanol non-Jack of a deal P10 1 11 [ph] probably don't need to be retrofitted until 2023. But does the slowdown and the speed or any of the other rails have any impact on your ethanol business in the near-term?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, obviously, this is a recent proposal. And so we continue to study. At this point, although this did not conform exactly with our public position, we are pleased that we appear to have a little bit more of a longer timeline than maybe crude oil. We ar
componenttext: Yes, obviously, this is a recent proposal. And so we continue to study. At this point, although this did not conform exactly with our public position, we are pleased that we appear to have a little bit more of a longer timeline than maybe crude oil. We are a little bit concerned about this reduction in speed because, not only will speed just transportation of oil and ethanol, but will slow down the whole system. So hopefully, we're still going to have some discussions with the government about this area.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And when would you expect a decision to be made or an outcome from those discussions?
componenttext: Okay. And when would you expect a decision to be made or an outcome from those discussions?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I really don't know, Ann. I will be venturing. At this point, I don't know.
componenttext: I really don't know, Ann. I will be venturing. At this point, I don't know.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask about the oilseed crush margins again. Juan, right now, we're seeing CBOT crush margins around $0.69 per bushel. That's down from like well over $1. Put into perspective just how good the Q1 margins were on crush? And then what I'm really tr
componenttext: Wanted to ask about the oilseed crush margins again. Juan, right now, we're seeing CBOT crush margins around $0.69 per bushel. That's down from like well over $1. Put into perspective just how good the Q1 margins were on crush? And then what I'm really trying to get after is, it feels like we should be down, ADM should be down quite substantially in the second quarter on oilseed processing simply because moving from Northern Hemisphere to Southern Hemisphere. And just Q1 was just a remarkable result on the crash side. Can you give me your comments?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say the thing that we noticed, I mean, you notice the strength of the crush margins in North American. Our team played very well. But I think what also happened.Is that thermally, during March, you see a transitional already to South America.
componenttext: Yes, I would say the thing that we noticed, I mean, you notice the strength of the crush margins in North American. Our team played very well. But I think what also happened.Is that thermally, during March, you see a transitional already to South America. And I think in this case, what we have is probably the full March that you see here in the North American results. So yes, there is a shift that we normally see, and we're going to see a little bit of a slowdown in the earnings of oilseeds in the second quarter after we shift to South America. South American, both Paraguay and Brazil, we don't have crushing in Brazil and Argentina. But Paraguay and Brazil continue to be good crushing margin. So -- and then, we're going to have, we're going to pick up a little bit of exports from the grain origination part that we'll report in oilseeds. So I will say, yes, the normal seasonality from Q1 to Q2, not a significant, a spectacular decline, I would say.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just to follow on that. Q4 last year and Q1 this year were terrific because of how tight the conditions are in oilseed crush. Is there any reason that wouldn't reoccur in the fourth quarter of this year and first quarter of next year on just the
componenttext: And then just to follow on that. Q4 last year and Q1 this year were terrific because of how tight the conditions are in oilseed crush. Is there any reason that wouldn't reoccur in the fourth quarter of this year and first quarter of next year on just the basic assumption that the crops are good? So assuming the crops are good, the crush margin that we saw these last couple of quarters were terrific. But I would expect those to repeat. Is that a reasonable thought process?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. I think that there is a tight capacity. I mean, this industry continues to grow and there hasn't been much capacity at it. So you will continue to see those dynamics, which when we got to export a lot and we have a very robust domestic demand,
componenttext: Yes, David. I think that there is a tight capacity. I mean, this industry continues to grow and there hasn't been much capacity at it. So you will continue to see those dynamics, which when we got to export a lot and we have a very robust domestic demand, that presents very good crush margin. This is a global demand story. It continues to grow the protein consumption. And also, don't forget that -- as we were exporting a lot of GTGs to China, that basically increase the domestic demand for soybean meal. So crushing went very, very well. And we think that we'll continue over the year.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: On ethanol, can you discuss how much of your ethanol business has been hedged in the second quarter?
componenttext: On ethanol, can you discuss how much of your ethanol business has been hedged in the second quarter?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I normally tell you that we hedge, as a matter of principle, something between 25% and 75%, depending on how we see the conditions. I would say that we are constructive in margins and margins has been recovering. So that probably indicates that, as you ca
componenttext: I normally tell you that we hedge, as a matter of principle, something between 25% and 75%, depending on how we see the conditions. I would say that we are constructive in margins and margins has been recovering. So that probably indicates that, as you can understand, we're probably in the soft side of that. But I don't want to disclose that much, our tactics going into Q2.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: In that's very helpful. To kind of same question related to Q3 and Q4 on ethanol. They have much visibility on margins there? Or is it kind of same story? It's only just improving now so you would be kind of on the lower side of normal hedge patterns.
componenttext: In that's very helpful. To kind of same question related to Q3 and Q4 on ethanol. They have much visibility on margins there? Or is it kind of same story? It's only just improving now so you would be kind of on the lower side of normal hedge patterns.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say we like the prospects through the summer. We like the way exports are reacting. Ethanol continues to be, clearly, by a big margin, the lowest octane enhancer around the world. And that continues to bring export markets to the U.S. The U.S. is
componenttext: I would say we like the prospects through the summer. We like the way exports are reacting. Ethanol continues to be, clearly, by a big margin, the lowest octane enhancer around the world. And that continues to bring export markets to the U.S. The U.S. is a reliable supplier. So we continue to be optimistic about that. We know that plants run a little bit softer during the summer and the driving season is upon us. So we have several months ahead of us with potentially good margins.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then one last question. In Ag Services, do you think that we'll see kind of better North American flow because farmers have been, I think, a little bit reluctant to sell some of their crop, particularly corn? Bottom line is, is there a corn portfolio
componenttext: And then one last question. In Ag Services, do you think that we'll see kind of better North American flow because farmers have been, I think, a little bit reluctant to sell some of their crop, particularly corn? Bottom line is, is there a corn portfolio expected in the second quarter that will be kind of a little bit larger than normal?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know it's in Q2. But we are optimistic about the second half. We believe that we have a lot of business ahead of us, both in South America and in North America.
componenttext: I don't know it's in Q2. But we are optimistic about the second half. We believe that we have a lot of business ahead of us, both in South America and in North America.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Massoud with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Massoud with Stifel.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you talk a little bit more about ethanol exports. You had mentioned that FX gave you some troubles as far as the grain exports out of the U.S. But the number that you gave annualized was close to 1 billion gallons. Before, your talk abo
componenttext: I was wondering if you talk a little bit more about ethanol exports. You had mentioned that FX gave you some troubles as far as the grain exports out of the U.S. But the number that you gave annualized was close to 1 billion gallons. Before, your talk about flat, now it seems that you're implying a year-over-year increase. I mean, at some point, do you start to see strong U.S. dollar, weak oil pricing having any kind of impact on U.S. exports on ethanol?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I described it before, Paul, that ethanol continues to be by a big margin, a big -- the cheapest of there. If you think ethanol in the range of $1.60 to $1.70, the next transition is about $2.50. So there is still a big incentive out there. So we ha
componenttext: Well, I described it before, Paul, that ethanol continues to be by a big margin, a big -- the cheapest of there. If you think ethanol in the range of $1.60 to $1.70, the next transition is about $2.50. So there is still a big incentive out there. So we haven't seen, even with all the strength of the dollar and the reduction in our exports of ethanol. So at this point in time, we continue to look at 800 million gallons this year. I just was reflecting on the numbers that were posted on the January and February exports. And that happens to be annualized to $1 billion. We continue to be somewhere in that range. Obviously, we look at -- we continue to look at new markets. And there are several mandates around the world that are being implemented and there is like more than 3 billion gallons of MTBE that needs to be replaced. So we are optimistic about that. And that's, over the last 2 years, have been a very strong market for us, and we seem to continue to grow. Q2 exports, they probably going to be larger than Q1. So...

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the -- switching gears just a little bit over to WILD Flavors, EUR 100 million and synergies that you talked about. I believe you said in the past you're expecting that over 3 years. Was just wondering with FX headwinds might delay some of the material
componenttext: On the -- switching gears just a little bit over to WILD Flavors, EUR 100 million and synergies that you talked about. I believe you said in the past you're expecting that over 3 years. Was just wondering with FX headwinds might delay some of the material delays to say, years 2 and 3. Or do you expect to see some accretion and maybe year 1?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do expect accretion year 1. The synergies, normally, in this case, is a lot of that you get the cost synergies of front because that's when the integration happens. And then at the same time, you start working with customers in qualifying products
componenttext: Yes, we do expect accretion year 1. The synergies, normally, in this case, is a lot of that you get the cost synergies of front because that's when the integration happens. And then at the same time, you start working with customers in qualifying products and developing new products and then they go to shelflife testing and all that. So the revenue synergies are more back-end loaded and the cost synergies are more front end loaded in these projects. But at this point in time, we were probably running at all are a little bit ahead of schedule in that.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And my last question is just on the Brazilian strike, the transport strike that we saw in the first quarter. I mean, it didn't look like you had any material impacts in your numbers. But were there any effects? And do you see anything lingeri
componenttext: Okay, great. And my last question is just on the Brazilian strike, the transport strike that we saw in the first quarter. I mean, it didn't look like you had any material impacts in your numbers. But were there any effects? And do you see anything lingering into the second quarter from that?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, this time, the Brazilian strike have been almost a little bit ahead of the harvest, if you will. So it didn't have a material impact to us. We had a little bit of an attempt last week again that brought a little bit of an issue in Mato Grosso, bu
componenttext: Yes. No, this time, the Brazilian strike have been almost a little bit ahead of the harvest, if you will. So it didn't have a material impact to us. We had a little bit of an attempt last week again that brought a little bit of an issue in Mato Grosso, but nothing significant that we can report. No impact, I would say.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question on Argentina and, I guess, Brazil as well. My understanding is that there's grain elevators, it's like a point of delivery system, whereby, originators such as yourself will test soybeans to see if there biotech. And they are, you collect
componenttext: Just a question on Argentina and, I guess, Brazil as well. My understanding is that there's grain elevators, it's like a point of delivery system, whereby, originators such as yourself will test soybeans to see if there biotech. And they are, you collect a royalty seed that than a share with the biotech seed manufacturer. I think there may be problems with this Brazil in the past. But I've been reading the there are issues with it in the Argentina. So could you just talk a bit about growth those dynamics are? Is very meaningful amount of earnings for you? And are you having any discussions with the Argentine government about this or just sort state the play is?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, Vince, yes, I'm aware of the issue. And this is just a matter of putting the grain industry in a position to have to collect royalties, if you will, or licenses. So it doesn't have a margin impact on us. But yes, it's a little bit of a domestic d
componenttext: Yes. No, Vince, yes, I'm aware of the issue. And this is just a matter of putting the grain industry in a position to have to collect royalties, if you will, or licenses. So it doesn't have a margin impact on us. But yes, it's a little bit of a domestic dispute. And since there are other companies on the other side involved in this, I'd rather, don't comment and let the guy solve it themselves in Argentina.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Farha Aslam with defense.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: One, could you share with us your global trade desk, how you're merchandising volumes differently and how it actually did help you increase volumes? And is that volume increase sustainable?
componenttext: One, could you share with us your global trade desk, how you're merchandising volumes differently and how it actually did help you increase volumes? And is that volume increase sustainable?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's -- as you recall, I was and we were as a team, unhappy with the performance we were having with Toepfer. And we needed to fix that. That was, not only providing recurrence, but a lot of volatility the with our nice with where running i
componenttext: Yes, I think that's -- as you recall, I was and we were as a team, unhappy with the performance we were having with Toepfer. And we needed to fix that. That was, not only providing recurrence, but a lot of volatility the with our nice with where running it. Part of that was created by inefficiencies between the interface between Toepfer and ADM, part of that it was because of a blow to the structure, if you will, that was increasing our fixed cost. So what we brought -- when we bought the 20% of Toepfer, we bought -- we brought both companies together, and we move some of the people to role to Geneva that allowed us to, first of all, have a more conservative view of the market, more coordinated view of the market between the origination and the destination that Toepfer provided. We had better utilization of our infrastructure, our logistics. And certainly, reviews the cost of the whole operation. So it's a more profitable operation that they have as many fixed cost. So I think that overall, we improve the volumes because we have better coverage, but we also increase the margins out of that since we have lower cost. So I think the overall end-to-end supply chain that you hear me talking from origination to the destination market, that's what the GTD has brought to us. And we should continue to see improvements into these. And you see this is a very true reflection. Our services with North America not being able to export that much because of the strong dollar still grew earnings 37% year-over-year, which is a significant improvement. And a lot of that is because of these implementation.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so is this improvement captured in that $550 million improvement target? Is that kind of the types of projects that'll be in that $550 million number?
componenttext: And so is this improvement captured in that $550 million improvement target? Is that kind of the types of projects that'll be in that $550 million number?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I will say, that's probably a different bucket. The $550 million are more operational improvements. This is more like a strategic portfolio management. We will count it in another bucket. So I will say only maybe a tiny bit maybe in the $550 million.
componenttext: No, I will say, that's probably a different bucket. The $550 million are more operational improvements. This is more like a strategic portfolio management. We will count it in another bucket. So I will say only maybe a tiny bit maybe in the $550 million. But you shouldn't deduct from the $550 million this. I think were going to be deliver $550 million without counting this.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then you announced several small divestitures and acquisitions. Notably, many of them were either greater ownerships supports or expansion reports. Could you help us frame kind of what earnings you drive from ports and how we should think
componenttext: Okay, great. And then you announced several small divestitures and acquisitions. Notably, many of them were either greater ownerships supports or expansion reports. Could you help us frame kind of what earnings you drive from ports and how we should think about your investments in ports?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ports are a strategic points. They are, at times, if they become a choking point, they can be a big source of either your earnings or your losses, depending if you're earning or you don't. What were trying to do, if you think some of the announcement
componenttext: Yes. Ports are a strategic points. They are, at times, if they become a choking point, they can be a big source of either your earnings or your losses, depending if you're earning or you don't. What were trying to do, if you think some of the announcement we made, we made the announcement of Eaststarch, for example, where we have more ownership now of Eastern Europe in assets. And then we announced this morning also the Port of Constanza, where we take full ownership of that. This is to continue to complement our value chain and being charge of all those different targets, price of the value chain that allow us to make small margins in many, many points as we touch the grain here all the way from the origination to the processing. So we control many, many ports around the world. And as I said before, I think at times, they become the bottleneck and you don't want to be hostage -- to be held hostage to somebody else owning that and having to puzzle the profits. So to the extent that it makes capital sense because obviously, they are expensive, we try to in places where we have the full supply chain. We try to own them.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So your investment will smooth out your earnings, accelerate earnings, kind of how should we think about that?

componenttext: Yes, the Argentinians have been selling a little bit more as well. But yes, a lot of people expect that if there is a change in government in Argentina, they may come evaluation and they may prompt a little bit more aggressive farmer selling. At one point in time, we will feel the soybean from Argentina, obviously, more probably in Europe than in other ways for us. So start to speculate on the result and an election to be honest, Farha. But that will be one of the potential scenarios.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that would be more 2016 event?
componenttext: So that would be more 2016 event?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the election in Argentina, Farha, I think they happen in October. I think the government change like in December, that debt or something like that. So whether the government decide evaluation at some remove it into '16, it will probably more on '16 i
componenttext: Yes, the election in Argentina, Farha, I think they happen in October. I think the government change like in December, that debt or something like that. So whether the government decide evaluation at some remove it into '16, it will probably more on '16 impact.

componenttext: I just wanted to go back to your comment you made about how your speeding starches results were impacted by running the ethanol at a lower rate during the quarter. Just wondering, in the past, you talked about shifting buying capacity. But this that rushed down or the wet mill?

componenttextpreview: Yes, will look at the overall full of facets that we have. And so I'm not going to disclose granularity around what assets we take down or not. But I think, as I said, I think it's important for you to consider that we always going to look at both to maxi
componenttext: Yes, will look at the overall full of facets that we have. And so I'm not going to disclose granularity around what assets we take down or not. But I think, as I said, I think it's important for you to consider that we always going to look at both to maximize the margin coming out of every a bushel that we grind. So sometimes, that benefits, bioproducts of the detriment of sweeteners and starches like of this case, this and happen this often. But in this case, we thought it was materially enough that we should mention it.

But I mean, any within wet mill process like how much of the grind could be shifted to your from ethanol toward [indiscernible] for some other type of product?

componenttext: That's a very strategic and important number that I'd rather don't disclose, Michael. We have the ability to produce between 20 and 30 products, but how much can we shift from 1 extreme to the other is a very strategic number. I'd rather don't disclose it.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: One of your competitors had described the specialty protein market in U.S. of a bit more competitive in the first half. Would you agree with that comment? And is this, I think, a situation where maybe whey protein prices have come down as dairy production
componenttext: One of your competitors had described the specialty protein market in U.S. of a bit more competitive in the first half. Would you agree with that comment? And is this, I think, a situation where maybe whey protein prices have come down as dairy production has increased. Are you seeing increased price competition or flexibility in that space?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tim, let me tell you what happened to us, and I don't know what happened to competitors. But what happened to us is that we use a lot of our North American capacity to supply the rest of the world. And because of the dollar strength and some emerging
componenttext: Yes, Tim, let me tell you what happened to us, and I don't know what happened to competitors. But what happened to us is that we use a lot of our North American capacity to supply the rest of the world. And because of the dollar strength and some emerging market weaknesses, if you will, we exported less. That might have from the volume actually stayed domestically and that might have put some pressure on margin domestically. But the bigger -- the biggest impact we felt, it was we didn't have the pool from exports this quarter. We are working on that, and resulting that. And some of that -- some of that would also customers around the world looking at cyber soybean coming down and decided to go a little bit and allowed to see how long can they become. So we're seeing that turn in a little bit now. But that's the impact we saw, Tim.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then my second question with the buyout of the JV with Tate & Lyle, I know they've talked about that venture requiring more capital investment over time than they were comfortable with. Can you kind of frame up what the addi
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then my second question with the buyout of the JV with Tate & Lyle, I know they've talked about that venture requiring more capital investment over time than they were comfortable with. Can you kind of frame up what the additional CapEx requirements maybe over the next couple of years after you've consolidated that?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tim, the issue is it doesn't require capital investments. Capital investments is a choice if we want to grow that capacity. The reality is, the U.S. uses 92% of our food versus like 8% of sugar for soda, if you will. Eastern Europe uses 28% of high f
componenttext: Yes, Tim, the issue is it doesn't require capital investments. Capital investments is a choice if we want to grow that capacity. The reality is, the U.S. uses 92% of our food versus like 8% of sugar for soda, if you will. Eastern Europe uses 28% of high fructose corn syrup versus 72% of sugar. So the opportunity to grow that is enormous. So sure, if you want to capitalize on that amount unit capacity. You need capacity to expand capacity. But we will only do it on the back of very strong returns that will make that expansion makes sense. So we don't have a must. We can run this for cash flow or for cash as long as we won't until we decide that they wanted spent. Are not going to expand Day 1. Day 1 is all going to be about integrating this to our footprint and taking advantages of we're managing that -- of those assets and the integrating those assets with our grain and our transportation business.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zaslow with Bank of Montreal.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zaslow with Bank of Montreal.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions. One is, can you frame this quarter as a quarter in terms of earnings power because there was a lot of puts and takes? Is this something -- is the return characteristics and the overall performance, is this kind of what you'd be thinking
componenttext: Just 2 questions. One is, can you frame this quarter as a quarter in terms of earnings power because there was a lot of puts and takes? Is this something -- is the return characteristics and the overall performance, is this kind of what you'd be thinking about for a longer-term number? What would be the major changes to enhance your earnings from this type of quarterly rate?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let's say, first quarter is not traditionally a very strong quarter for us, especially from an ethanol perspective, it's a low demand quarter. Certainly, biodiesel didn't run as expected. So I would say we still believe that there is a strong ability for
componenttext: Let's say, first quarter is not traditionally a very strong quarter for us, especially from an ethanol perspective, it's a low demand quarter. Certainly, biodiesel didn't run as expected. So I would say we still believe that there is a strong ability for ADM to improve returns and result from this kind of level. We have not -- we don't think that this is tough. We don't think that this is maximized, not even for oilseeds that you could say that's have outstanding quarter. Some of their divisions, as I said, all the softy side, all Europe, didn't quite perform that well. Biodiesel is not performing great. We couldn't export a lot from North America from a grain perspective. So our earnings from grain was subdued. Certainly, we didn't have any margins in ethanol. So I don't think that this was spectacular quarter from what the market could give us. I think that given what the market could give us, the team executed very, very well. And we continue to be excited about the implementation of our strategic blueprint, our strategic plan. That continues to bring strength because it comes from improving our operations, from having better facilities, from divesting things that we don't like. I announced today, we divested the lactic as a business. I mean, it's not a significant thing, but it continues to show the commitment of management that they are now sacred cows here. Everybody needs to forecast -- needs to present credible forecast in return to be part of the integrated business. And I think, we continue to be excited about the strength of our plan and the way our company is executing with very good consistency, I would say. So I think there is upside from here, Ken, that will be my summary.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my second question is just on more detail is can you give a little bit of outlook on the European crush outlook? What's going well there? When the [indiscernible] was just a little bit more because seems like margins in Europe have been a little
componenttext: Okay. And my second question is just on more detail is can you give a little bit of outlook on the European crush outlook? What's going well there? When the [indiscernible] was just a little bit more because seems like margins in Europe have been a little bit softer. When do they trend? How do you think through that?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Q1, we shifted as much as we could to soybean crushing as were so much better. Obviously, now the market getting a little bit better but also Argentina soybean has started to show up. So now is going to become a little bit tougher. And I think fro
componenttext: Yes. So Q1, we shifted as much as we could to soybean crushing as were so much better. Obviously, now the market getting a little bit better but also Argentina soybean has started to show up. So now is going to become a little bit tougher. And I think from a soft seed perspective, we'd probably need to wait until like July or sometime later on for us to see an improvement there.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let's hear that lactic acids is not a sacred cow. It sounds like a great title for a note. But I wanted to know, HFCS demand certainly, I don't think anyone would say its great domestically. But I think supply has been cut back. And my understanding is th
componenttext: Let's hear that lactic acids is not a sacred cow. It sounds like a great title for a note. But I wanted to know, HFCS demand certainly, I don't think anyone would say its great domestically. But I think supply has been cut back. And my understanding is that, that has tightened up the spot markets quite a bit. You didn't report very strong results, profit-wise, in the quarter. But how do you think this bodes for future periods? Like do you think this will be a -- do you think you can do better in future periods, especially when contracts roll over?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Robert, I think that -- and I think I said it in my remarks. We posted an increase in profitability in their underlying business in sweeteners and starches, driven by good volumes and product margins. It was offset by part of this lack of core produc
componenttext: Yes, Robert, I think that -- and I think I said it in my remarks. We posted an increase in profitability in their underlying business in sweeteners and starches, driven by good volumes and product margins. It was offset by part of this lack of core product because of the decision we made to run ethanol for margins and also decreased earnings from a joint ventures and the one-times from the Tianjin the start-up cost. Think about the Tianjin plant. We have a full plant, a 4 walls scale plant waiting to get approval. So you have all the fixed costs and some of the variable costs that we are making product with no revenue, no cash flow from that plant. So that's impacting the business. But I would say from -- I agree with you, margins for sport business are a little bit tighter and a little bit higher. And we have a combination of contracts, contract that were done before the announcement of some of the shutdowns that were down at previous years margin and some businesses that will perform after that, which are a better numbers. But we expect the profitability of sweeteners and the starches from now on to improve as some of these one-off will be eliminated.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Juan, I didn't think about that. But sweeteners and starches, once you get Eastern Europe, the fall accountability of the profits there and your numbers and then you get China up and running, can you give us a sense of what those 2 products -- projects wo
componenttext: Juan, I didn't think about that. But sweeteners and starches, once you get Eastern Europe, the fall accountability of the profits there and your numbers and then you get China up and running, can you give us a sense of what those 2 products -- projects would add incrementally to your normal kind of run rate? Because I think I and others always think of this division has been kind of North America and that's it.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would rather maybe give you some perspective on that maybe in the next call. We still want to get the feeling of getting all the approvals in China. And we need to get our hands on the Eaststarch, and we didn't get 100% of Eaststarch. So some o
componenttext: Yes. And I would rather maybe give you some perspective on that maybe in the next call. We still want to get the feeling of getting all the approvals in China. And we need to get our hands on the Eaststarch, and we didn't get 100% of Eaststarch. So some of Eaststarch have got to take a low and some to us. And some of us will be sweeteners and starches and some may not. So we need to -- I'd rather get to closing those operations before giving you. But you are correct, that should add to our segment sweeteners and starches on a global basis.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Any it kind of builds to a broader question, Juan and Ray. In your presentation today, we presented a lot of projects. And I think it's kind of hard for us in the street to kind of quantify what incremental benefit of those projects is. And so and more cl
componenttext: Any it kind of builds to a broader question, Juan and Ray. In your presentation today, we presented a lot of projects. And I think it's kind of hard for us in the street to kind of quantify what incremental benefit of those projects is. And so and more clarity you can give the future calls because, as you increase invested capital base, the earnings power should go up, too. So just a comment.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct. And that's of intention. And at this point in time, we were trying to balance both, obviously, the improving earnings per share with improving ROIC, and that's why Ray will describe in EVA is that what we're looking at. But that's the
componenttext: Yes, that's correct. And that's of intention. And at this point in time, we were trying to balance both, obviously, the improving earnings per share with improving ROIC, and that's why Ray will describe in EVA is that what we're looking at. But that's the intention. They are all investments to improve EPS, and you should see that reflected in the bottom line as we go forward.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's fair to say for major transactions, we are going to be very open with you, just like we WILD transaction. We were very open with you in terms of returns and accretion. I think you raise a good point. We've got a lot of smaller bolt-on acquisi
componenttext: I think it's fair to say for major transactions, we are going to be very open with you, just like we WILD transaction. We were very open with you in terms of returns and accretion. I think you raise a good point. We've got a lot of smaller bolt-on acquisitions, which traditionally on these bolt-on acquisitions or small acquisitions, we've never really given it that much guidance on. But the pace of this is probably increasing. So you raised a good point. We made it a like to actually bundle of them off together and give you some direction. So it will help in terms of your modeling.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Archer Daniels Midland Company First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's call, Mark Schw
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Archer Daniels Midland Company First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
