But I think supply has been cut back, and my understanding is that, that has tightened up the spot markets quite a bit. You didn't report very strong results profit-wise in the quarter, but how do you think this bodes for future periods? Like do you think this will be a -- do you think you can do better in future periods, especially when contracts roll over?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Robert, I think that -- and I think I said it in my remarks. We posted an increase in profitability in the underlying business in sweeteners and starches, driven by good volumes and product margins. It was offset by part of this lack of co-product cr
componenttext: Yes, Robert, I think that -- and I think I said it in my remarks. We posted an increase in profitability in the underlying business in sweeteners and starches, driven by good volumes and product margins. It was offset by part of this lack of co-product credits because of the decisions we made to run ethanol for margins and also decrease earnings from the joint ventures and the onetimes from the Tianjin and startup costs. Think about the Tianjin plant. We have a full plant, a full world-scale plant waiting to get approval. So you have all the fixed costs and some of the variable costs, and we're making products with no revenue, no cash flow from that plant. So that's impacting the business. But I would say from -- I agree with you. Margins for spot business are a little bit tighter and a little bit higher. And we have a combination of contracts, contracts that were done before the announcement of some of the shutdowns that were done at previous years' margin on some businesses that were performed after that, which are at better numbers. But we expect the profitability of sweeteners and starches from now on to improve as some of these one-off will be eliminated.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Juan, I didn't think about that. But sweeteners and starches, once you get Eastern Europe -- the full accountability of the profits there in your numbers and then you get China up and running, can you give us a sense of what those 2 projects would add inc
componenttext: Juan, I didn't think about that. But sweeteners and starches, once you get Eastern Europe -- the full accountability of the profits there in your numbers and then you get China up and running, can you give us a sense of what those 2 projects would add incrementally to your normal kind of run rate? Because I think I and others always think of this division as just being kind of North America and that's it.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would rather maybe give you some perspective on that maybe in the next call. We still want to get the feeling of getting all the approvals in China. And we need to get our hands on the Eaststarch, and we didn't get 100% of Eaststarch. So some o
componenttext: Yes. And I would rather maybe give you some perspective on that maybe in the next call. We still want to get the feeling of getting all the approvals in China. And we need to get our hands on the Eaststarch, and we didn't get 100% of Eaststarch. So some of Eaststarch have gone to Tate & Lyle and some to us. And some of that will be in sweeteners and starches and some may not. So we need -- I'd rather get to closing of those operations before giving you, but you are correct, that should add to our segment sweeteners and starches on a global basis.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Any it kind of builds to a broader question, Juan and Ray, is that in your presentation today, you presented a lot of projects. And I think it's kind of hard for us in The Street to kind of quantify what the incremental benefit of those projects is. And s
componenttext: Any it kind of builds to a broader question, Juan and Ray, is that in your presentation today, you presented a lot of projects. And I think it's kind of hard for us in The Street to kind of quantify what the incremental benefit of those projects is. And so any more clarity you can give in future calls? Because as you increase invested capital base, the earnings power should go up, too. So just a comment.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct. And that's the intention, and at this point in time, we're trying to balance both, obviously, the improving earnings per share with improving ROIC. And that's why Ray was describing EVA is that's what we're looking at. But that's the
componenttext: Yes, that's correct. And that's the intention, and at this point in time, we're trying to balance both, obviously, the improving earnings per share with improving ROIC. And that's why Ray was describing EVA is that's what we're looking at. But that's the intention. They are all investments to improve EPS, and you should see that reflected in the bottom line as we go forward.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's fair to say for major transactions, we are going to be very open with you, just like the WILD transaction. We were very open with you in terms of returns and accretion. I think you raised a good point. We've got a lot of smaller bolt-on acqui
componenttext: I think it's fair to say for major transactions, we are going to be very open with you, just like the WILD transaction. We were very open with you in terms of returns and accretion. I think you raised a good point. We've got a lot of smaller bolt-on acquisitions, which -- traditionally, on these bolt-on acquisitions or small acquisitions, we've never really given that much guidance on. But the pace of this is probably increasing. So you raised a good point. We may elect to actually bundle them up together and give you some direction, so it'll help you in terms of your modeling.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: There are no further questions. I'll turn the call back over to Juan Luciano for closing remarks.
componenttext: There are no further questions. I'll turn the call back over to Juan Luciano for closing remarks.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Archer Daniels Midland Company Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference cal
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Archer Daniels Midland Company Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference call, Mark Schweitzer, Vice President, Investor Relations for Archer Daniels Midland Company. Mr. Schweitzer, you may begin.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to ADM's Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Starting tomorrow, a replay of today's call will be available at adm.com.For those following this presentation, please turn to Slide 2, the company's safe
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to ADM's Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Starting tomorrow, a replay of today's call will be available at adm.com.
For those following this presentation, please turn to Slide 2, the company's safe harbor statement, which says that some of our comments constitute forward-looking statements that reflect management's current views and estimates of future economic circumstances, industry conditions, company performance and financial results. These statements are based on many assumptions and the factors that are subject to risks and uncertainties. ADM has provided additional information in its reports on file with the SEC concerning assumptions and factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the presentation, and you should carefully review these assumptions and factors in our SEC reports. To the extent permitted under applicable law, ADM assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements as a result of new information or future events.
On today's call, our Chief Executive Officer, Juan Luciano, will provide an overview of the quarter. Our Chief Financial Officer, Ray Young, will review financial highlights and corporate results, then Juan will review the drivers of our performance in the quarter, provide an update on our scorecard and discuss our forward look. Finally, they will take your questions.
Please turn to Slide 3. I will now turn the call over to Juan.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today. This morning, we reported adjusted earnings per share of $0.60. Our adjusted segment operating profit was $724 million. Adjusted ROIC of 9% was 240 basis points above our cost of
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today. This morning, we reported adjusted earnings per share of $0.60. Our adjusted segment operating profit was $724 million. Adjusted ROIC of 9% was 240 basis points above our cost of capital.
Our second quarter results demonstrate the strength and value of our geographic and business portfolio diversity. In corn, domestic and export demand for ethanol was robust, but record industry production limited margins. This was partially offset by strong results from our corn sweeteners and starches business.
In Oilseeds, good meal demand supported strong North America soybean crushing results. And South American origination and export volumes were up, leading to good throughput at our expanded origination and port network. These, combined with the flexibility of our global crush plants, helped the Oilseeds team deliver another strong performance.
The WILD Flavors and specialty ingredients team had an excellent quarter and continues to make great progress toward achieving the targeted costs and revenue synergies.
Our services earnings were impacted by lower margins and volumes of North American exports, as they were less competitive globally and by a sharp upward movement in commodity prices at the end of the quarter. But within our Ag Services segment, the milling business had record second quarter results.
We continue to advance our strategic plan as improving our ROIC and growing our EVA. Among numerous other actions, we closed the sale of our global chocolate business to Cargill, we closed the Barcarena port transaction with Glencore in June and we remain on track to close both our E starch transaction and the sale of our global Cocoa business later this year. And we're making great progress on our operation and excellence initiatives. I'll provide more detail on our scorecard activities later in the call. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Ray.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Juan. Slide 4 provides some financial highlights for the quarter. Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $0.60, down from the strong $0.79 last year. Excluding specified items and also excluding net timing effects, adjusted segment operating profit was
componenttext:
Thanks, Juan. Slide 4 provides some financial highlights for the quarter. Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $0.60, down from the strong $0.79 last year. Excluding specified items and also excluding net timing effects, adjusted segment operating profit was $724 million. The effective tax rate for the second quarter was 27% compared to 28% in the second quarter of the prior year. Our trailing 4-quarter average ROIC of 9% significantly improved by 120 basis points from the 7.8% at the end of the second quarter last year. The 9% adjusted ROIC is above our 6.6% annual WACC for 2015 as well as our long-term WACC of 8%, as reflected in the graph on Slide 9 in the appendix. Our objective remains to earn 200 basis points over our WACC.
In the second quarter, our trailing 4-quarter average EVA was $610 million based upon adjusted earnings and the annual WACC up $238 million from the second quarter of 2014. 
On Chart 18 in the appendix, you can see the reconciliation of our reported quarterly earnings of $0.62 per share to the adjusted earnings of $0.60 per share. For this quarter, LIFO represented a $0.06 per share after-tax charge. We had some gains on sales or revaluations of assets, primarily related to our Northeast Brazil court and the Romanian court totaling $0.11 per share. We also had some impairment charges totaling $0.04 per share. 
Slide 5 provides an operating profit summary and the components of our corporate line. Before Juan discusses the operating results, I'd like to highlight some of the unique items impacting our quarterly results.
We had some gains and some charges in ag services corn and Oilseeds segments I mentioned in the last chart and are highlighted in our press release. As a reminder, our Cocoa and chocolate business remain part of our segment reporting results in oilseeds until we have closed on the sales, and they're not treated as discontinued operations in our financial statements.
Our new fourth business segment, WILD Flavors and specialty ingredients, or WFSI for short, is reported as own segment for the second time this quarter. This segment includes the 2 businesses we acquired in 2014, WILD Flavors and Specialty Commodities Inc. as well as certain specialty ingredients businesses that was previously reported in ADM's 3 other segments.
For purposes of comparison to prior results, the year-ago quarter's segment operating profit for Ag Services, corn and oilseeds removed the earnings of the businesses that are now reported in the WFSI segment. To assist you with your analysis, we've included a chart in the appendix that recasts 2014 segment quarter results to the new segments.
In the corporate line, net interest expense was about flat, unallocated corporate expenses were $19 million higher due to: one, increased GAAP pension expenses relating to the changes in discount rates and mortality tables; second, increased spending in IT and in our ERP project; third, investments related to strategic business improving projects; and lastly, unique costs related to specific divestiture activities, including the [indiscernible] in Cocoa. We're starting to see some of the benefits of some of the strategic business improvement projects in our results.
Excluding these factors, our run rate in underlying corporate costs are consistent with the prior year, and you should expect our run rate the next few quarters to be between $110 million to $120 million per quarter.
I would also like to comment on our GAAP net revenue number that can be found in the appendix. GAAP net revenues for the quarter were $17.2 billion, down from last year's $21.5 billion. The significant reduction was driven by large declines in commodity prices that impact our revenues, but this decline also impacts our consequence sold as our input costs are lower. So the key is managing the spread between the revenues and cost of goods sold, which is core competency of our teams. This dynamic makes operating profit much more relevant when analyzing us. 
I also want to highlight that the GAAP statements in the prior year do not include the revenues and the costs of WILD and SCI, whose transactions closed in the fourth quarter of last year.
Now turning to the cash flow statement on Slide 6. Here's the cash flow statement for the 6 months ending June 30, 2015, compared to the same period the prior year. We generate $1.2 billion from operations before working capital changes in the 6 months, slightly higher than the prior year. Total capital spending for the 6 months was $540 million, up from the prior year but consistent with our guidance of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion for the calendar year. During the 6 months, we spent $1.2 billion to repurchase about 24 million shares towards our 2015 target of repurchasing $1.5 billion to $2 billion of shares, subject to strategic capital requirements. Our average share count for the first 6 months was 633 million diluted shares outstanding, down 28 million from the 661 million at this time 1 year ago. At the end of the second quarter, we had 621 million shares outstanding on a fully diluted basis. For the first half, our total return of capital to shareholders, including dividends, was over $1.5 billion.
Our 6 months cash flows are consistent with our 2015 calendar year targets of capital allocations, namely CapEx of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion, approximately $700 million of dividends and $1.5 billion to $2 billion in share repurchases. We have been more aggressive in the pace of stock buybacks, taking advantage of the recent weakness in our stock price, and all this is consistent with the balanced capital allocation framework we set forth at our December Investor Day.
Slide 7 highlights our balance sheet as of June 30 for 2015 and 2014. Our balance sheet remains strong. Operating working capital of $8.3 billion was down $2.7 billion from the year-ago period. This decrease was comprised about $2.1 billion related to lower inventory prices, including the translation impact, partially offset about [ph] $0.9 billion related to higher inventory quantities and a decrease of about $1.5 billion in other working capital, primarily related to reclassification of working capital for our global [indiscernible] businesses under a held-for-sale accounting.
Total debt was about $6.9 billion resulting in net debt balance that is debt less cash of $5.7 billion, up from the 2014 net debt level of $3.6 billion, in part reflecting the fourth quarter cash outflows related to our acquisitions of WILD and SCI.
In addition, we raised EUR 1.1 billion in June in the euro debt markets to take advantage of low interest rates and to serve as the net investment hedge for are grown euro asset base following the WILD acquisition. We had paid down $0.8 billion of notional debt in July in a U.S. debt tender settlement, and we may pay out an additional $0.2 billion before the end of the third quarter.
While we will take a pretax charge slightly about $0.2 billion in the third quarter related to debt tender premium, we expect going forward our ongoing annual interest expense to be lower by about $40 million pretax or $0.04 per share after tax through the combination of the U S debt reductions and the euro debt issuances. This U.S. debt tender, euro debt issuance transaction had a very positive NPV benefit for ADM.
Our shareholders' equity of $18.6 billion is $1.7 billion lower than the level last year, with a cumulative translation account down about $0.5 billion due to the strength of the U.S. dollar. We had $5.9 billion available global credit capacity at the end of June. If you add the available cash, we had access to over $7 billion of short-term liquidity.
Next, Juan will take us through a review of our business performance. Juan?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ray. Please turn to Slide 8. In the second quarter, we earned $724 million of operating profits, excluding specified items. Our ROIC of 9% was up 120 basis points over last year's second quarter; and EVA was up $238 million, an increase of more th
componenttext:
Thanks, Ray. Please turn to Slide 8. In the second quarter, we earned $724 million of operating profits, excluding specified items. Our ROIC of 9% was up 120 basis points over last year's second quarter; and EVA was up $238 million, an increase of more than 60% from last year.
First of operating profits were similar to the same period last year despite the decline of more than $200 million in operating profits from the ethanol business. This results demonstrate the power of our business.
Now I will review the performance with each segment. Starting on Slide 9. In the second quarter, our services results declined from last year. Merchandising and handling results reflected a more significant seasonal decline in North American export volumes and margins, while global demand was met by increased South American exports that improved our overall 6 months results. We also saw lower global trade desk margins, as the June 30th USDA report drove an increase in prices of some commodities, which negatively impacted some merchandising positions. While we had this impact at the end of Q2, markets came back a few days after the report.
In transportation, we saw lower total U.S. freight volumes and high water increased our costs. Milling and other results increased due to improvements in product margins, mix and a strong merchandising results. A great quarter for our global milling operations, record second quarter results there.
Please turn to Slide 10. Corn Processing results improved sequentially and declined year-over-year. In sweeteners and starches, overall volumes were up about 3% year-over-year. The tight supply chain from North American sweeteners supported very good margins and volumes. We also saw good demand for livestock feed, and our Mexican joint venture in Mexico and our Eaststarch joint venture in Europe both delivered solid results.
And in bioproducts, ethanol earnings were lower. As I mentioned earlier, demand was robust, with increased exports and record U.S. driving miles, but margins were limited as the industry ran at record volumes. Our ethanol profitability improved from the first quarter, with second quarter ethanol EBITDA margins estimated at around $0.18 per gallon.
Now looking forward, on the demand side, we see continued strong domestic and export demand for ethanol. Driving miles are up more than 3%, which will help domestic ethanol consumption approach 14 billion gallons in 2015. We see annualized net exports running at about 800 million gallons. We expect continued growth of exports to markets that currently use MTVE, and E15 adoption continues to grow, which will also bolster demand long term.
On the supply side  industry production levels will be a function of many factors, including maintenance timing, yields, hot weather, planned and unplanned downtime and the face of industry capacity creep. 
In terms of what we are doing, we're strengthening our efforts to expand E15 adoption in the U.S. and ethanol adoption in markets abroad. We are also investing to further improve ADM's cost position in this business. ADM has invested a lot of effort to drive operational excellence and cost reductions in our mills, which represent about 1.1 billion gallons of nameplate capacity, and that has translated into strong financial results from these facilities, even in challenging environments.
We believe there are still opportunities to improve the cost positions of our large dry mills, which represent about 600 million gallons of nameplate capacity. We're intensifying efforts across a range of areas to drive these cost improvements. 
In summary, we continue to believe there is an important place for ethanol in the global fuel supply, and we expect that our actions will help drive improved results from this business in the near term.
Slide 11, please. Oilseeds have another consistent solid quarter similar to last year. In crushing and origination, large global bean supplies and a strong U.S. mill demand drove great global soy crush results.
In the first half of 2015, we crushed record volumes of soybeans globally. As part of our strategic plan for oilseeds, we've added switch capacity to more of our North American crush plants, and we've profited from our global switch capacity in a weak exhausted margin environment this quarter. 
As I mentioned earlier, our South American origination and port operations, including our Barcarena port, had good throughput at the region's large corn and soy harvest proved the world's most competitive supply. In fact, ADM South American export volumes were up 38% compared to last year's second quarter.
On the soft seed side, concerns about seed supply significantly reduced margin volumes and -- margins and volumes. We're finding packaging by another results declined, mainly on the absence of biodiesel blenders credits we recorded last year. 
In Europe and South America, margins were challenged by regional market conditions. In North America, we saw strong refining margins, and our Stratus joint venture delivered its best quarter yet. Stratus continues to be an industry leader in working with customers to manage the transition away from trans fat.
Results from Asia rose primarily and will help improve performance.
Slide 12, please. In their second reporting quarter, the WILD Flavors and specialty ingredient business unit delivered more than $100 million in earnings, an excellent performance. WILD Flavors had strong results in North America. To provide some context, it's worth noting that in 2014, North America represented slightly more than half of the profits for WILD Flavors globally. And despite microeconomic headwinds, flavor profit in Europe were in line with our plan. And this quarter was one of the best ever for our specialty proteins business. Among other highlights, the customer launched the first refill product with our customized inclusions.
The WFSI business, with products ranging from proteins, specialties to ancient grains to natural flavors, is a key component in ADM's efforts to serve customers with on products to grow their business.
As I mentioned earlier, WFSI team continued working across all ADM businesses to fuel synergy efforts. In terms of revenue synergies, they continue to grow the pipeline and customer base. In the quarter, they added 175 prospects to the pipeline, bringing the total to nearly 600. In the quarter, they worked across all ADM's business units to deliver more than 50 more revenue synergy wins. 
One interesting note here, the SCI team and their customer relationships can prove to be a valuable engine for driving cross-business collaboration nd delivering this wins. So, so far this year, the WFSI team has implemented $24 million in annualized run rate cost synergies. That's more than halfway toward the 3-year target.
We remain confident that the team will deliver EUR 100 million of run rate synergies from the WILD acquisition by the end of year 3, which is 2017. I will still expect the WILD business to deliver $0.10 to $0.15 earning accretion in the first full year of operations, despite some ForEx headwinds.
Now on Slide 13, I would like to update you on how we're strengthening and growing our company. This is the scorecard we presented at Investor Day in December. It lists the actions we are taking to help grow our business, our earnings and our returns. We highlighted some of the areas in which we made significant progress. I'll discuss a few. 
In Ag Services, we expanded our farmer services offering with an investment in Agregol, a leader in on-farm analytical and forecasting tools. We announced the expansion of our port at Port Martini in Argentina, enhancing our export capability from the region. And our port services JV acquired a Brazilian port and shipping agency.
In corn, we are on track to close the EasStar acquisition in the second half of the year. We contributed our liquid feed business into a joint venture to achieve greater scale without additional capital intensity. And in May, we announced an agreement to acquire the small sweetener manufacture in Central China, but unfortunately, that transaction fell through.
In oilseeds, we closed the sale of a 50% stake in our Barcarena port to Glencore. We closed the sale of our global chocolate business to Cargill, and we remain on track to close the global sale to [indiscernible] by the end of the year.
And in WFSI, we acquired a 3-knot [ph] then seed processing facility in California, adding processing to support strong sales growth. We remain on track to deliver synergy and accretion targets, and we continue to advance our construction projects in Brazil, China, Germany, India and the U S. 
And with respect to our operational excellence initiatives, I talked about our objective of delivering $550 million of run rate savings by the end of year 5. By the end of the second quarter, we have realized already about $125 million of this run rate savings. We'll update you on our scorecard each quarter, and overtime, you should expect to see the results of these actions in improved earnings and returns.
So before we take your questions, I wanted to offer some additional perspective as we look forward. We continue to feel good about 2015. The large U.S. harvest should help drive utilization of our storage and transportation assets in the U.S. The large global corn crops, the tight North America and sweeteners balance sheet and continued global sweetener demand should support margins and volumes in our sweeteners and starches business.
As I mentioned earlier, in ethanol, in the near and medium term, we expect demand, both domestic and export, to remain very strong. Production levels should also be robust and industry margins should evolve based on the supply/demand balance as we move through the year. We're intensifying our work on the cost position of our dry mills. Over the medium term, ethanol remains the cheapest octane enhancer in the world, and we're going to work domestic and international demand.
Good global demand for mills should continue to support capacity utilization of our global soybean processing assets. And the WFSI team is well on track to work their cost and revenue synergy targets for 2015. We continue to see great collaboration across all of ADM's business units as we partner to serve a growing customer base.
Overall, we continue to advance our clear and aggressive strategic plan. We'll continue to see contributions from that effort throughout the year and would remain focused on growing EVA.
With that, operator, please open the line for questions.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Farrah with Stephens.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Farrah with Stephens.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you just walk us around the globe for global crush margins, one. Clearly, soy crush margins are very, very strong. How will ADM position itself for that? And can that be adequate to offset the weakness in soft seed margins?
componenttext: Could you just walk us around the globe for global crush margins, one. Clearly, soy crush margins are very, very strong. How will ADM position itself for that? And can that be adequate to offset the weakness in soft seed margins?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So margins in North American continue to be very, very good. Very strong domestic demand. And if you remember, we announced earlier in the year that there are 2 facilities in the U.S. where we have added switch capacity to soybeans, so that's helping
componenttext: Yes. So margins in North American continue to be very, very good. Very strong domestic demand. And if you remember, we announced earlier in the year that there are 2 facilities in the U.S. where we have added switch capacity to soybeans, so that's helping us to offset a little bit the weakness the we expect in softseeds. South American margins continued to be solid. European margins are -- were very solid in soybeans in second quarter. We took advantage again of our swing capacity, and we matched that -- the soybean capacity in Europe. We're seeing now a little bit more softness at more North American -- South Americans soybean meal is arriving. And in China, we saw some recovery of that. It's not where it used to be at the beginning of the year, but it's much better than last year. So overall, we see a strong continued demand, and we foresee good crushing margins for the rest of the year.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And are you concerned about Argentine capacity coming back online this year or early part of next year?
componenttext: That's helpful. And are you concerned about Argentine capacity coming back online this year or early part of next year?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Listen, I think that at one point in time, we will have to deal with that. This is predicated in many factors at this point what the farmer will do in Argentina. There are upcoming elections and all that. But we are very bullish, given the domestic demand
componenttext: Listen, I think that at one point in time, we will have to deal with that. This is predicated in many factors at this point what the farmer will do in Argentina. There are upcoming elections and all that. But we are very bullish, given the domestic demand in the U.S. and the global demand that continues to grow for soybean mill.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Helpful. And just one follow-up. On Ag Services, in your prepared remarks, you'd highlighted that you expect strong performance in the second half from that business due to a good U.S. crop. Could you just share with us kind of what you've seen so far fro
componenttext: Helpful. And just one follow-up. On Ag Services, in your prepared remarks, you'd highlighted that you expect strong performance in the second half from that business due to a good U.S. crop. Could you just share with us kind of what you've seen so far from the farmers are they prepared for harvest? And kind of what you think your elevator utilizations are going to be and how that's going to effect earnings going forward?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so obviously, Ag Services first half was softer than would normally in the second half. We saw it last year. It doesn't surprise us that much. If you look at the performance year-to-date for Ag Services, it's in line with the same quarter -- the firs
componenttext: Yes, so obviously, Ag Services first half was softer than would normally in the second half. We saw it last year. It doesn't surprise us that much. If you look at the performance year-to-date for Ag Services, it's in line with the same quarter -- the first quarter last year. So at last year, as the U.S. comes into the harvest and it becomes more competitive in export, we plan to move a very strong harvest through all our facilities. So we expect a very strong second half. We expect the U.S. to become more competitive in export. We haven't been so far, but we expect that demand to come to our elevator very fast and be able to increase elevation margins towards the end of the year. So at this point, we have very bullish second half for Ag Services.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Samuelson with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Samuelson with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe a little -- the first question in ethanol. And Juan, I heard you expressed some confidence that the margin outlook would improve from here. And I guess I'm trying to reconcile supply demand with exports where they are seems reasonably balanced, alth
componenttext: Maybe a little -- the first question in ethanol. And Juan, I heard you expressed some confidence that the margin outlook would improve from here. And I guess I'm trying to reconcile supply demand with exports where they are seems reasonably balanced, although it's not clear stocks are actually going to draw as you move into the second half. But with the sharp decline in oil prices, how do you see -- do you become incrementally concerned about the pricing of ethanol relative to gasoline about domestically and overseas just keeping that margin kind of contained over the near to medium term?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think. Listen, you have to separate the analysis in certain business. From a demand perspective, we continue to feel very good about ethanol. As I said before, domestic demand with low gasoline prices has increased 3%, and that pattern should conti
componenttext: Yes. I think. Listen, you have to separate the analysis in certain business. From a demand perspective, we continue to feel very good about ethanol. As I said before, domestic demand with low gasoline prices has increased 3%, and that pattern should continue with a normal seasonality we're doing summer and winter in the U S. Export demand continues to be very solid in those countries that are already customers. And we have many, many new countries trying to become new customers, and our team are out there trying to develop those markets. So the issue will become in this relatively new industry, what happened with the supply. And the supply has been strong during -- so far during this year, because we have a very mild start of the summer from a temperature perspective. We expect that right now, we've seen that even in June, in July. Over the last 3 weeks, inventory had been flat or slightly declining for the last 2 or 3 weeks, so the industry can produce that 15 million gallon, but not more [indiscernible] for a very few weeks. And then I would say, it's relatively balanced what do we see right now in ethanol. And even at this oil prices, we are making money in our -- in all our mills. And if you think about the [indiscernible] values, NPV continues to be at about $2.85 versus in ethanol of $1.50, $1.60. And the other [indiscernible] at about $2.50. So we continue to be the most competitive octane enhancer out there. So without even thinking about E15 growing in the background. So I think overall, I cannot call it through the month or through the quarter, because as I said, this is a relatively volatile industry as we grow into our capacity. But I think medium term, we're very optimistic about the balance to turn it to the favor of ethanol.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And then you expressed confidence in Ag Services in the second half, principally in the U.S. Do you, a, was there a loss on the global trading deftly in the quarter that provides some good cushion to the third quarter? And if so
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And then you expressed confidence in Ag Services in the second half, principally in the U.S. Do you, a, was there a loss on the global trading deftly in the quarter that provides some good cushion to the third quarter? And if so, could you quantify it? And second, how do you think about the mix, the breakdown of that Ag Services second half between export volumes against a very competitive South American crop versus domestic merchandising, origination, domestic transportation and the offshore business?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. A complex question, Adam. Let me see if I can split it a little bit. The first part was [indiscernible]? Yes, the loss on the global trade desk. Yes. As you know, June 30 report created a big volatility and basically brought prices up. So when we mar
componenttext: Yes. A complex question, Adam. Let me see if I can split it a little bit. The first part was [indiscernible]? Yes, the loss on the global trade desk. Yes. As you know, June 30 report created a big volatility and basically brought prices up. So when we mark-to-market that, I think the loss was around $25 million there and also maybe not that significant. And the price corrected like by July 2nd or 3rd, they [indiscernible] to, so part of that has already come back in those positions. Regarding second half, I think maybe the export season will start a little bit later this year for the U.S. as North America -- South America continue to extend their window a little bit. But we believe that, that demand outcome to the U.S. and will come all of a sudden, altogether, so that will bode well for elevation margins. We think that are transportation business also will be very strong, and we need to move a very large crop. I think that we're going to see the comeback of the normal carries that we see in the U.S. So we believe that a very strong growth and very big area routes pose very well for our footprint in North America. So I think it's going to be heavy fourth quarter loaded, and I cannot call it whether it all start in fourth quarter or slip a little bit into Q1, but we are prepared to manage a very large crop.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a clarification there on the carries, that corn or corn and wheat or both?
componenttext: Okay. And then just a clarification there on the carries, that corn or corn and wheat or both?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we're seeing both at this point in time.
componenttext: I think we're seeing both at this point in time.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll of Citi research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll of Citi research.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Cornell Burnette on with a few for David Driscoll. I just wanted to give a few on ethanol. Just wanted to see what was your take on where export rents would be at the end of 2015. It appears vast that the number could be something greater than 1 b
componenttext: This is Cornell Burnette on with a few for David Driscoll. I just wanted to give a few on ethanol. Just wanted to see what was your take on where export rents would be at the end of 2015. It appears vast that the number could be something greater than 1 billion gallons. So putting that together with the fact that you're seeing somewhat of an oversupply currently in the ethanol market, just was wondering kind of what prevents margins from continuing to be soft, if that is indeed the case?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we expect the balance to be like 1.8 billion. I think i said it before when I answer to Adam in the ethanol. It's difficult to call it in the short term. In the short term, there are risks to our forecasted in the Brazilian ethanol could be coming in
componenttext: Yes, we expect the balance to be like 1.8 billion. I think i said it before when I answer to Adam in the ethanol. It's difficult to call it in the short term. In the short term, there are risks to our forecasted in the Brazilian ethanol could be coming into the U.S. But we continue to see markets being developed outside the U.S. and the U.S. domestic market being robust. Consider this, and I think we said it before, Kordell, that out there, at least 6 billion gallons of MTBE capacity that we're working very hard to replace, and these products again ethanol is the most sustainable and the lowest-cost octane enhancer. So I like to be positioned in a product that is there sustainable and lower costs than their alternatives. So there is a big market out there, and we were going through ups and downs through all these regulations. Again, I said it before, its relatively new industry, an industry that started in 2007 and is to go through phases of consolidation. We're going to have great capacity. Some producers will become better producers, more cost efficient, then will push some of the marginal producers into more trouble worker. That will, to a certain degree, modify the industry. So we're working this industry development. But at this point in time, we continue to be very excited about the potential. We find in our own plants improve our competitive advantage and the potential for this market to grow in front of us.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up demand over the remainder of 2015, we're looking at, on a thesis market, slowing [ph] prices under $50 a barrel and there's some concern that there might be some oversupply in the market. When you talked about kind of the e
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up demand over the remainder of 2015, we're looking at, on a thesis market, slowing [ph] prices under $50 a barrel and there's some concern that there might be some oversupply in the market. When you talked about kind of the ethanol profitability perhaps strengthening going forward from what you saw in the second quarter, was that predicated on seeing some type of rebound in petroleum and that kind of what levels petroleum do you think you can get there?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, at this point in time, I'd refrain from  forecasting oil for obvious reasons. But I would say in the current environment, when I make this comment are in the framework of the current oil price and the current corn prices, if you will. So I'm not
componenttext: Yes. No, at this point in time, I'd refrain from  forecasting oil for obvious reasons. But I would say in the current environment, when I make this comment are in the framework of the current oil price and the current corn prices, if you will. So I'm not forecasting that it's going to go anywhere.

componenttext: Juan, just in general, it looks like the first half came in below internal expectations for the year. And judging from what you're saying that the mark-to-market trading benefit would only be $25 million in third quarter, it just looks like the your as a whole is going to be below what your internal expectations might have been. And I just kind of want to get a sense from that -- a sense of that from you. Is there still a chance that you can hit kind of your internal targets for the year as you set them?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me walk you through the different businesses, Rob. Oilseeds is way ahead of last year, and we continue to see upside in oilseeds, granted we come in against the strong comps that we have in Q3 and Q4 last year, but also it's coming very strong on
componenttext: Yes. Let me walk you through the different businesses, Rob. Oilseeds is way ahead of last year, and we continue to see upside in oilseeds, granted we come in against the strong comps that we have in Q3 and Q4 last year, but also it's coming very strong on very strong demand. So that's ahead of last year, and that should continue to be over the year. Ag Services, as I told you, is online for the first half. And last year, we had a second half that allowed us to deliver in the range of 850 to 900, and we see this year again the possibility to be in that range if we can repeat the second quarter -- the second half. And with these kind of crops, we had the potential to do so. So I would say this businesses are on par or ahead of last year. WFSI is having very good performance. We'll keep within the range, so that's an addition of last year and then we're having sweeteners and starches that are going very, very strongly, and it need to offset the weakness in it ethanol. I think ethanol was obviously started the year very bad, very soft in Q1. It improved in Q2. It had improved a little bit over the last 3 weeks. So I think the issue is we have 1 business that we think it will deliver, which is Ag Services. We have 2 business, WFSI and oilseeds, that will probably outperform and that need to offset a little bit the softness in ethanol. So all in all, at this point, we still believe -- we still feel good about 2015.

componenttext: Okay. So from a returns perspective, Rob, when we feel good about our ROIC, our ROIC focus, and we continue to be running our plants pretty aggressively, managing invested capital. componenttext: Don't forget, Rob, that when we divest cocoa and chocolate, when you consider we are 9% ROIC today, we are divesting basically $1.2 billion of invested capital. That for us represent very, very low returns. So our increase in the return, when and all that is gone is going to get the boost.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, given the pace that you've seen in the first half of the year, we've been fairly aggressive especially when our stock pullback. So I'd just say that we're probably in the higher end of the range there for sure. And our balance sheet remains strong, so we've got a lot of capacity to buy back shares.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure. There is some seasonality in this business, as you know, because there's a lot of juices and there's a lot of products that are sold in the summer. So the second quarter is slightly higher from a seasonal perspective than Q3, if you will. Margi
componenttext: Yes. Sure. There is some seasonality in this business, as you know, because there's a lot of juices and there's a lot of products that are sold in the summer. So the second quarter is slightly higher from a seasonal perspective than Q3, if you will. Margins continued to be very strong in the high teens EBITDA margins for this business. The ingredients growth that we continue to see are in the range of 3% to 5%. And when you take natural products, natural flavors products are more in the 5% to 6% range. We feel very excited about the reaction of our customers have had to our product mix into the segments, and we've been expanding the customer base to make our business even much robust. Just to give you some example, the number of customers driving 80% of sales have increased by 47%, which showed the robustness of our pipeline going foreword and as I so in my prepared remarks, the pipeline of new wins or projects that the customer -- that composer revenue synergy portfolio have had a quantum leap of 75% from Q1 to Q2. So all the prospects, all the products are on trends. Those trends are strong, and customers are reacting very well to innovating with us, so we feel very good about.

componenttextpreview: Yes, to be honest, Michael this is such a new business for us. This is a combination for us of 9 different business that we group together, so we don't a have strong comps, and we don't have a lot of history to. And since a lot of this growth are the prod
componenttext: Yes, to be honest, Michael this is such a new business for us. This is a combination for us of 9 different business that we group together, so we don't a have strong comps, and we don't have a lot of history to. And since a lot of this growth are the product of combination of new synergies of new solutions for customers that it's difficult to put the target. We know we are ahead of schedule in terms of synergies, and we know we're going to deliver the accretion as next year. We just haven't developed the robustness of comps going forward since this is a new business for us.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: There are 2 things, and that everybody says brings excitement to our lives in the grain business. One is weather, the other is government intervention. So we are very used to follow that, to track that. It also presents opportunity before discontinuity. O
componenttext: There are 2 things, and that everybody says brings excitement to our lives in the grain business. One is weather, the other is government intervention. So we are very used to follow that, to track that. It also presents opportunity before discontinuity. Obviously, we hear the rumors that China is finding it more difficult to sustain the subsidies to the farmers, but we don't know at this point in time. And I'd rarely bet against the Chinese government, they seem to be very strategic about their moves. So we just paying attention. Obviously, a release of inventory or a drop in price could mean a decline in prices for corn. That would probably bode well for our business.

So the theme remains very flexible. I guess what we wanted to say is that we try to maximize earnings into our business that it depends during the quarter, we may move from 1 position to the other. So I wouldn't make a statement for the full quarter at this point.

componenttext: So one of the key things in Ag Services is the rate of experts and how competitive the U.S. is. componenttextpreview: Well, the cost savings program. Yes, we are, at this point in time, $125 million run rate of that promise of 500 in 5 years. I would say that we have probably identified enough opportunities that we know already that we can implement that are close to $38
componenttext: Well, the cost savings program. Yes, we are, at this point in time, $125 million run rate of that promise of 500 in 5 years. I would say that we have probably identified enough opportunities that we know already that we can implement that are close to $380 million to $400 million of those 500. And since we are 1 year into this 5-year program, we feel that we are ahead of schedule. So we continue to find -- you heard me saying about our intensifying focus on dry mills. The wet mills are larger and older so rightfully so. When we started this program, we focus of about more energy there because we saw the opportunity was bigger. Now when you look at the difference we have in costs between the wet mill and the dry mills, we feel there are opportunities there whether it's enzymes or mills or things like that. We continue to fined ADM is a large company. And as much as to be cut costs, we continue to find new technologies that bring us new promises.

componenttext: Return to ethanol. You highlighted E15 as a positive driver, and I know that in your term, it's hard to forecast. But I think flex fuel vehicles currently about 6% for 7% of the total vehicle fleet. I was wondering how does going over the long term? And how quickly do you see us going there?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. When we started with the E15, we said that we would expect the implementation to take about 5 years. And it's -- I think at the end of the day, we with -- we would like to thank Secretary Bill for making available some funds to invest in infrastructu
componenttext: Yes. When we started with the E15, we said that we would expect the implementation to take about 5 years. And it's -- I think at the end of the day, we with -- we would like to thank Secretary Bill for making available some funds to invest in infrastructure. The industry has around that and together and many and is putting together projects to be able to participate in this program. And at the end of the day, there's going to become a tipping point and I didn't know exactly how -- when to call it, but we think that by 2017, 2018 that this will become a more meaningful part of our fuel supply, and we feel very good what that will do to supply/demand balances for the ethanol industry.

componenttext: Okay. And just a shift to biodiesel. Can you tell us how you're thinking about your near- to medium-term outlook? And do you see further opportunities to reduce your dependency on biofuels in Europe? Or have you already desperately needed to do on that front?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I would say first of all the in the medium-term situation is tough for biodiesel. In the absence of a more clear RFS, biodiesel will struggle, no doubt. I would say in our strategic intent to reduce the dependency in biodiesel, we are just getting sta
componenttext: No, I would say first of all the in the medium-term situation is tough for biodiesel. In the absence of a more clear RFS, biodiesel will struggle, no doubt. I would say in our strategic intent to reduce the dependency in biodiesel, we are just getting started. You heard us about AUR, which is an acquisition redid in Belgium on a bottle oil producer, so there are 3 elements to our program. One is to crush more soil in Europe that produces less oil. The second is to grow our share in food industry, which AUR one of those elements and the third one is to increase the use of oil into industrial uses and that's going as well. But I would say he not going to feel an impact until probably 2016 from our perspective.
