headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Archer Daniels Midland Company Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.I would now like to introduce your host for today's call, Mark Sch
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Archer Daniels Midland Company Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's call, Mark Schweitzer, Vice President, Investor Relations for Archer Daniels Midland Company. Mr.  Schweitzer, you may begin.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to ADM's Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Starting tomorrow, a replay of today's call will be available at adm.com.For those following the presentation, please turn to Slide 2, the company's Safe Ha
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to ADM's Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Starting tomorrow, a replay of today's call will be available at adm.com.
For those following the presentation, please turn to Slide 2, the company's Safe Harbor statement, which says that some of our comments constitute forward-looking statements that reflect management's current views and estimates of future economic circumstances, industry conditions, company performance and financial results.
These statements are based on many assumptions and factors that are subject to risks and uncertainties. ADM has provided additional information in its reports on file with the SEC concerning assumptions and factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in this presentation, and you should carefully review the assumptions and factors in our SEC reports. To the extent permitted under applicable law, ADM assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements as a result of new information or future events.
On today's call, our Chief Executive Officer, Juan Luciano, will provide an overview of the quarter; our Chief Financial Officer, Ray Young, will review financial highlights and corporate results; then, Juan will review the drivers of our performance of our quarter, provide an update on our scorecard and discuss our forward-look, and finally, they will take your questions. Please turn to Slide 3.
I will now turn the call over to over to Juan.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone, and thank you, all, for joining us today.This morning, we reported adjusted earnings per share of $0.60. Our adjusted segment operating profit was $684 million. Adjusted ROIC of 8.3% was 170 basis points above ou
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone, and thank you, all, for joining us today.
This morning, we reported adjusted earnings per share of $0.60. Our adjusted segment operating profit was $684 million. Adjusted ROIC of 8.3% was 170 basis points above our cost of capital. The ADM team executed well in an environment very similar to the second quarter. Our services were limited by lower margins on volumes of North American exports due to the continued strength of the U.S. dollar and ample crop supplies, particularly from south America. In corn, we continue to confront very weak industry ethanol margins while sweeteners and starches results remain solid amid tight supplies.
In oilseeds, good global meal demand again supported soy crushing results and solid origination volumes contributed to our South American operations. While continued weak oil demand, particularly outside the U.S., weighted on our softseed business, and in WFSI, the impact of microeconomic headwinds, weaker demand from some emerging companies and the strong U.S. dollar, was greater than we've expected. We continue to execute our strategic plan. Among other actions, we closed the sale of the global copper business, acquired Eatem Foods and closed the Eaststarch transaction. We're also making a strong progress in driving operational efficiencies, which will further enhance our cash position, and we remain committed to our balanced approach to capital allocation for our shareholders.
I'll provide more detail on our scorecard activities later in the call.
Now I'll turn the call over to Ray.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Juan. Slide 4 provides some financial highlights for the quarter. Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $0.60, down 30% from the $0.86 last year. Excluding specified items and also excluding net timing effects, adjusted segment operating profit was $68
componenttext:
Thanks, Juan. Slide 4 provides some financial highlights for the quarter. Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $0.60, down 30% from the $0.86 last year. Excluding specified items and also excluding net timing effects, adjusted segment operating profit was $684 million, down $257 million. The effective tax rate for the third quarter was 31% compared to 28% in the third quarter the prior year. Our tax rate was higher this quarter due to some discrete items that impacted us for the quarter, mainly the finalization of some international tax returns. Our calendar year 2015 estimate for the effective tax rate remains at around 28%. Our trailing 4 quarter average adjusted ROIC of 8.3% is down by 40 basis points from the 8.7% at the end of the third quarter last year. The 8.3% adjusted ROIC is above our 6.6% annual WACC for 2015 as well as our long-term WACC of 8%, as reflected in the graph on Slide 19 in the appendix. Our objective remains to earn 200 basis points over our WACC.
In the third quarter, our trailing 4 quarter average EVA was $428 million based upon the adjusted earnings and the annual WACC, down $178 million from 2014.
On Chart 18 in the appendix, you can see the reconciliation of our reported quarterly earnings of $0.41 to the adjusted earnings of $0.60. For this quarter, LIFO represented a $0.07 share after tax credit. We had gain from the sale of the global chocolate operations net of expenses of $0.04 per share with a charge related to buying back U.S. debt of $0.19 per share as part of a series of transactions to issue a lower-cost Euro denominated debt. With asset impairment charges of $0.06 per share and we had some restructuring and pension settlement charges of $0.04 per share.
Slide 5 provides an operating profit summary and the components of our corporate line. Before Juan discusses the operating results, I'd like to highlight some of the unique items that impacted our quarterly results. In the Corn Processing segment, we had $33 million charge related to the partial impairment of our Brazilian sugar processing assets, and oilseeds recorded $32 million gain net of expenses related to the sale of our global chocolate operations in the third quarter. As a reminder, our cocoa business remain part of our segment reporting result in the third quarter. We closed on the sale of the business in October and the sale will be recognized and recorded in our fourth quarter results.
Our new fourth business segment, WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients, or WFSI for short, includes the 2 businesses we acquired in 2014, namely WILD Flavors and Specialty Commodities, Inc. as well as certain specialty ingredients business that were previously reported in the ADM's 3 other segments. With purposes of comparison to prior results, the year-ago quarter segment operating profit for ag services, corn and oilseeds removed to earnings of the businesses that are now reported in the WFSI segment. To issue with your analysis, we've included a chart in the appendix that recapped the 2014 segment quarterly results to the new segments.
In the corporate lines. Net interest expense is down due to lower interest rates, an unallocated corporate cost of $113 million were within the $110 million to $120 million guidance that we provided to you last quarter. Our run rate in underlying corporate cost is consistent with the prior year excluding the special product costs, such as the implementation of our ERP program.
Also like to comment on our GAAP net revenue number that can be found in the appendix. GAAP net revenues for the quarter was $16.6 billion, down from last year's $18.1 billion. The significant reduction was mainly driven by large declines in commodity prices and foreign exchange translation by these factors also impacted our cost of goods sold as our input costs were lower. I also want to highlight that the GAAP statements for this year and last are not entirely comparable due to some significant transactions over the past 12 months, including fertilizer, chocolate, WILD and SCI.
Turning to cash flow statement on Slide 6. Here's the cash flow statement for the 9 months period ending September 30, 2015, compared to the same period the prior year. We generated $1.5 billion from operations before working capital changes in the first 9 months of this year. Total capital spending for the 9 months was $819 million, up from the prior year. Our CapEx guidance for the calendar year was $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion, and based upon our run rate of spending, it's likely will finish up the year at the lower end of the range or below that range. Given the more challenging business conditions we have encountered in 2015, we had been even more cautious in our capital spending.
We acquired several businesses this year including AOR, The European Bottle Oil company and our remaining interest in the Romanian Court totaling $83 million. In the other investing activities line, mainly reflects the proceeds from divestitures, such as our global chocolate business and the sale of our stake in our Port in Northern Brazil less the increased investment in Wilmar in the first quarter.
During the 9 months, we spent about $1.8 billion to repurchase about 37.5 million shares towards our 2015 target of repurchasing $1.5 billion to $2 billion worth of shares subject to strategic capital requirements. Our average share count for the first 9 months was 627 million diluted shares outstanding, down 31 million from this time 1 year ago. At the end of the third quarter, we have 607 million shares outstanding on a fully diluted basis.
For the 9-month period, our total return of capital to shareholders, including dividends, was over $2.3 billion. You should expect that we will complete about $2 billion of share repurchase by the end of the calendar year and finish up with about 600 million shares outstanding on a diluted basis.
On Slide 7, shows the highlights of our balance sheet as of September 30 for 2015 and 2014. Our balance sheet remains very strong. Operating working capital of $7.9 billion was down $0.3 billion from the year-ago period. Total debt was about $6.8 billion, resulting in a net debt balance that is debt less cash of $5.6 billion, up from the 2014 net debt levels of $0.7 billion. In part, reflecting the 4 quarter cash outflows related to our acquisitions of WILD and SCI as well as the issuance this year of Euro $1.1 billion of debt or roughly 1.2 billions in U.S. dollar terms and the subsequent repurchase of about $0.9 billion of U.S. debt. Our shareholders' equity of $17.9 billion is $2.4 billion lower than the level last year due to its share buybacks and with the cumulative translation and count down about $1.1 billion due to the strength of the U.S. dollar. We had $5.3 billion available global credit capacity at the end of September. If you add the available cash, we had access to over $6.4 billion of short-term liquidity.
Next, Juan will take us through a review of our business performance.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ray. Please turn to Slide 8. In the third quarter, we earned $684 million of operating profits, excluding specified items. Compared to the second quarter, market conditions in the third quarter were fairly similar with weak industry ethanol margin
componenttext:
Thanks, Ray. Please turn to Slide 8. In the third quarter, we earned $684 million of operating profits, excluding specified items. Compared to the second quarter, market conditions in the third quarter were fairly similar with weak industry ethanol margins and a competitive U.S. exports. So not surprisingly, our operating profits were in line. On a 4 quarter trailing average basis, our ROIC of 8.3% was above our annual WACC of 6.6% and our EVA was $428 million.
Now I'll review the performance of each segment. Starting on Slide 9. In the third quarter, ag services results were similar to last year's but reflected the starkly different set of market conditions. Overall, despite robust global demand, we saw a general lack of merchandising opportunities as the global markets was well supplied. Last year's third quarter, saw merchandising and handling results, driven by the normal seasonal July, August decline in exports and then normal uptick with the harvest in September, driving near record volumes out of the goal. This year, ample global crop supplies, particularly from South America and the strong dollar kept the North American exports, particularly corn and wheat, largely out of the global markets for the third quarter. However, we did see some soybeans exports pick up later in the quarter because of weaker global demand for U.S. exports due to the strong dollar, elevation margins at our export terminals were significantly lower this third quarter compared to last year.
You'll also recall that, that the second quarter global trade results reflected the late quarter market shift that negatively impacted some merchandising positions, and we were able to recognize the benefits of these positions in Q3. However, our global trade desk results were slightly down from last year due to lower margins from a more competitive global supply environment and global customer delaying some purchases in declining price environments.
In transportation, lower U.S. exports reduced barge freight rates. Milling and Other results again increased due to improvements in product margins, mix and strong merchandising results.
Please turn to Slide 10. Corn processing results declined from the year-ago period. In sweeteners and starches, we continue to see strong sweetener demand, supporting both margins and volumes. Across the subsegment, domestic shipments were flat, while exports, particularly corn products, were limited due to the low export demand for CPGs in July and August and the impact of our strongest dollar on the competitiveness of corn products exports. And as our new sweetener plant in Tianjin works to commercialize its capacity, we've had to absorb the fixed costs for that operation, and in valued products, ethanol earnings were lower. Industry ethanol inventories throughout the third quarter were higher than last year and industry production levels were also higher, both in ethanol margins to be considerably weaker than the prior year despite increases in domestic demand. Our ethanol profitability reflects third quarter ethanol EBITDA margins estimated at around $0.18 per gallon.
Slide 11, please. Oilseeds have yet another solid quarter. In crushing and origination, strong demand for milling in the U.S. and many of our traditional export destinations throughout Latin America, helped support good volumes and margins in our North American soybean crushing operations. Likewise, in Europe, good meal demand drove soy crush utilization. Weak global demand for vegetable oil reduced softseed margins on volumes around the world, particularly in Europe where rapeseeds crushing results were down significantly. This was another reporting, which our switch capacity paid off, and as the large Brazilian corn and soybeans crop combined with the weak real to encourage farmer selling, origination volumes increased significantly and margins rose, contributing to stronger year-over-year South American crushing and origination results.
Refining, packaging, biodiesel and other's results declined mainly on the absence of biodiesel blender's credit we recorded last year. However, North American refined oils have the best third quarter ever from good domestic demand and the results were offset by weaker demand for refined oils outside of the U.S. and also weaker overall biodiesel margins. Results from Asia rose, primarily on Wilmar's improved performance.
Slide 12, please. In their third reporting quarter, the WILD Flavors and Specialty Ingredients business unit earned $70 million. It was a tough quarter for the team. As I've mentioned, the strong dollar and weakness in some emerging economies affected results across a number of product lines, and while these factors are largely beyond our control, we're focusing on the levers we can boost to deliver results to strengthen the business. We're seeing improved gross margins on some key product categories, including flavors, polyols and protein. We're seeing U.S. Domestic business generating good results from solid demand.
We're seeing improved volumes in our polyols business. We're addressing some inventory management issues in our Specialty Commodities business and this issue should be behind us by the end of the year, and our synergy work is paying off as a result of benefiting from margin expansion, cost savings and mix.
The team remains laser-focused on our synergy work. That's resulted in steady customer and pipeline growth. We have delivered 81 new wins and have an active pipeline of more than 675 proceeds. As a result of this effort, we are seeing many new RFPs for SCI, for WILD Flavors and for ADM, and as I mentioned, we continue to see strong interest in our offering on lots of product launches.
Since the WILD acquisition, the team has implemented about $30 million in annualized run rate cost synergies, and we are on track to reach about $40 million by the end of this calendar year. We remain confident that the team will deliver EUR 100 million of run rate synergies from the WILD acquisition by the end of Year 3, which is 2017, and we're still on track toward the lower end of the $0.10 to $0.15 per share first year accretion for WILD Flavors.
Now on Slide 13, I'd like to update you on how we're strengthening and growing our company. This is the scorecard we presented at Investor Day in December. It lists the actions we're taking to help grow our business, our earnings and our returns. We've highlighted some of the areas in which we made significant progress. I'll discuss a few.
In ag services, we expanded our destination sales operations, opening offices in El Salvador and Guatemala. In corn, in July, we acquired Lyrco Nutrition, an animal feed business that serves, primarily the baby and swine market in Québec, and yesterday, we closed the Eaststarch acquisition, enabling ADM to better serve growing the European demand as the EU lists is artificial cap on serial-based sweeteners. In oilseeds, we closed the sale of our global coco business to Elan, we closed the acquisition of AUR, the oil bottling company based in Belgium. This is allowing us to better reach the Continental European retail and food service markets and enhancing our ability to export value-added products internationally. And we're having soy switch capacity to our rapeseed processing plant at Strobin, Germany, and in WFSI, we acquired Eatem Foods, a leading developer of savory flavors, having deep expertise in savory flavors and ethanol cuisines and broadening our capabilities in the food service and private brand channels.
We announced the construction of the state-of-the-art flavor lab and customer center in Clambory, New Jersey. We located the new Information Technology Support Center and existing building of the WILD campus in Erlanger, Kentucky. We remain on track to deliver synergy targets, and we continue to advance our construction projects in Brazil, China, Germany, India and the U.S. And we have made great progress in the area of driving operational efficiencies. We have targeted $550 million of run rate savings by the end of Year 5. In fact, we have already identified a pipeline of more than $700 million. We'll update you on our scorecard each quarter, and overtime, you should expect to see the results of these actions in improved earnings and returns.
So before we take your questions, I wanted to offer some additional perspective as we look forward. We have a large U.S. harvest in front of us and crop will eventually move to the world markets, which will benefit our Ag Services business. In corn, the sweetener balance sheet should remain tight, while ethanol industry margins will move based upon supply and demand dynamics. In oilseeds, global demand for processing remain strong and we're working Asia powerment solving oil production and Brazilian biodiesel legislation, which could improve the global vegetable oil balance sheet, and WFSI continues to capture synergies related to the WILD acquisition, and integrated recent acquisitions, such as Eatem Foods.
As you saw moments ago, we continue to make progress advancing our plan, and as I mentioned earlier, we remain committed to our capital allocation framework that was set out at the end of 2014 in terms of a balanced approach for our shareholders.
With that, operator, please open the line for questions.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: You might have kind of alluded to this in your comments, but I think you said that U.S. farmers will eventually commercialize their grain. Can you give us kind of a little bit more color on the degree to which their unwilling to commercialize at today's p
componenttext: You might have kind of alluded to this in your comments, but I think you said that U.S. farmers will eventually commercialize their grain. Can you give us kind of a little bit more color on the degree to which their unwilling to commercialize at today's prices? And what does that mean for your fourth quarter and kind of end-year EPS estimates, guys?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob. Yes, certainty. U.S. farmers don't like these prices, and at this point in time, they are holders of grain. If we look at their normal pattern of commercialization before the harvest during the harvest and postharvest, this year, we've see
componenttext: Thank you, Rob. Yes, certainty. U.S. farmers don't like these prices, and at this point in time, they are holders of grain. If we look at their normal pattern of commercialization before the harvest during the harvest and postharvest, this year, we've seen that in corn, they probably sold about 30% of the new crop, while normally they will be about 45% by this time of the year. If we look at beans, they probably sold about 35% of the new crop and normally, they would have averaged about 60%. We still believe that our Q4 earnings in ag services will grow versus Q3, but we probably see more commercialization of grain either in values that will depend probably on the weather event, whether there is concern about eventually South America maybe later on in December or something like that or with the regular cash flow maybe during 2016.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful, and another question. I've heard rumblings about what the election in Argentina could mean with a new leader coming in, it might lead to reduction in tariffs or export duties, and I want to know what -- how do you think that mig
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful, and another question. I've heard rumblings about what the election in Argentina could mean with a new leader coming in, it might lead to reduction in tariffs or export duties, and I want to know what -- how do you think that might play out? And how will it affect your business if Argentina suddenly commercializes a lot of soybean mill?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Obviously, there's going to be a runoff election in November 22, so we're hearing from both candidates on their proposals, and there are rumblings about potential -- a reduction in export restrictions or the licenses that they have applied today or m
componenttext: Yes. Obviously, there's going to be a runoff election in November 22, so we're hearing from both candidates on their proposals, and there are rumblings about potential -- a reduction in export restrictions or the licenses that they have applied today or maybe export taxes and/or potential evaluation. I will qualify the following way of I think is as Swan of the largest exporter of grain in Argentina, our reduction in restrictions and licenses will be positive for our ag Services business, and if you think that is going to be more soybeans coming to market and more crushed than in Argentina, then maybe potential negative for the competitiveness of U.S. meal exports out of the U.S. and it might impact a little bit there the situation in Europe. So I would say positive for ag services, potential negative for oilseeds.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you think it's a net positive for ADM overall? Or is that just kind of neutral?
componenttext: Do you think it's a net positive for ADM overall? Or is that just kind of neutral?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- it's interesting because the ag services impact is a direct impact. We're going to get to export more and our exports from Argentina have been subdued over the last couple of years. The impact in oilseeds, it could be a little bit more indire
componenttext: Well, the -- it's interesting because the ag services impact is a direct impact. We're going to get to export more and our exports from Argentina have been subdued over the last couple of years. The impact in oilseeds, it could be a little bit more indirect and since it depends on other issues and this is more substitution, so I can't quantify more than that at this point in time, Rob.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kenneth Zaslow with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kenneth Zaslow with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Patrick Chan for Ken. Just another question for ag services. I guess that $850 million to $900 million number so at risk? Is there structural risk given the farmers hold grain longer, especially in light of the consecutive large crops?
componenttext: This is Patrick Chan for Ken. Just another question for ag services. I guess that $850 million to $900 million number so at risk? Is there structural risk given the farmers hold grain longer, especially in light of the consecutive large crops?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me give you some perspective. We do believe that the range is relevant for ag services. Given the conditions and given where we are in Q4, we know that Q4 will be better than Q3, but will be, will fall short of Q4 last year. So probably this year
componenttext: Yes. Let me give you some perspective. We do believe that the range is relevant for ag services. Given the conditions and given where we are in Q4, we know that Q4 will be better than Q3, but will be, will fall short of Q4 last year. So probably this year, we may end up lower than that range given the conditions of the U.S. dollar and the very strong crops in South America, but let me give you some perspective. If we look at the last 8 years, ag services has that range at 7 of the last 8 and the only the year in which it didn't because of this 50-year draught that we had. So I would say at this point in time, we continue to maintain that, that's a fair range for ag services in the future.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Just switching gears a little bit to ethanol margins. When would that industry margins recover? It seems there are a lot of headwinds right now, you have ethanol trading on a premium to gasoline. The weak real improving Brazil's pricing covenance a
componenttext: Great. Just switching gears a little bit to ethanol margins. When would that industry margins recover? It seems there are a lot of headwinds right now, you have ethanol trading on a premium to gasoline. The weak real improving Brazil's pricing covenance and also China supposedly closing its portion for SV, I guess, how much cost savings can you realize in your plans offset some of that?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. You got it right. The main thing that we can do to help ourselves certainly is continue to work on the cost of the plants, and we are evaluating that is a constant process for us to see how much we can help ourselves into that. Granted maybe is a lit
componenttext: Yes. You got it right. The main thing that we can do to help ourselves certainly is continue to work on the cost of the plants, and we are evaluating that is a constant process for us to see how much we can help ourselves into that. Granted maybe is a little bit more limited in our ability to get savings and maybe a larger than we continue to work on that. I will say the dynamics at this point in time, as we see, but with our -- there has been some good news in this quarter about China getting into the export destination roster, if you will. Some of the plants have maybe came back a little bit later from their maintenance, which provides us a little bit of time. But as you said, medium-term, we continue to trade premium to gasoline, which will have some impact in certain export destinations. That's why we continue to call the net exports about the same even in China it is coming into the export destination roster. So it will be -- it will continue to flow depending on how much the industry will produce. We are positive about the demand. Demand is up in gasoline about 3% this year and maybe it's going to be up 1% to 1.5% for next year. Exports continue to be robust. Ethanol is growing very, very fast in Brazil and now with the increasing gasoline prices in Brazil, ethanol has become a little bit more expensive. Petrobras is in strike today, so they are not producing that much oil maybe they need a little bit more ethanol. So I would say at this point, we had to cut that, that is a bit like the margins we have today going forward, and with hopes into the global domestic demand and keeping those export markets.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes of the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes of the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Tom for Ann. Can you talk about your increased stake in Wilmar and the strategic rationale behind that investment?
componenttext: This is Tom for Ann. Can you talk about your increased stake in Wilmar and the strategic rationale behind that investment?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. Well we have opportunistically acquired shares of Wilmar in the open market recently, and I'd say opportunistically because obviously, they were relatively low with regards to their book value and certainly, the single for dollar also was very
componenttext: Sure, yes. Well we have opportunistically acquired shares of Wilmar in the open market recently, and I'd say opportunistically because obviously, they were relatively low with regards to their book value and certainly, the single for dollar also was very convenient for us to make that investment. You heard us before, Wilmar is a strategic partner and one of our largest customers and we continued to be very committed to this relationship, to grow in this relationship. Wilmar gives us a window and an exposure to tropical oils, to China oilseed crush, to consumer packaged products in China. So it's a great way for us to participate in that, and we believe in our relationship, and we will continue to grow it over time.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and also, you mentioned with WILD Flavors facing demand headwinds in Q3. Can you expand on this especially in light of the expectation that the world will have to be less volatile in other segments?
componenttext: Okay, and also, you mentioned with WILD Flavors facing demand headwinds in Q3. Can you expand on this especially in light of the expectation that the world will have to be less volatile in other segments?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say, listen, the trends are intact. We continue to see big push from a pool of customers in terms of the pipeline that we have. The pipeline continues to grow. We fight restriction beyond 75. Project in the pipeline at the end of October. Tha
componenttext: Yes. I would say, listen, the trends are intact. We continue to see big push from a pool of customers in terms of the pipeline that we have. The pipeline continues to grow. We fight restriction beyond 75. Project in the pipeline at the end of October. That number is like 8 05. So it continues to grow. The segment is composed of many products and some of those products, as we -- you heard that we're building a plant in Brazil of specialty protein. Well, at this point in time, we sourced everything from the plant in the U.S. Certainly, with the strongest dollar, our ability to export to the world has been reduced. There are some countries that have some issues of importing like in Venezuela, for example, even if our customers want to get their product. Some key markets -- key emerging markets have been soft, whether it's called Middle East, whether it's Russia, whether it's China and in some of these products like emulsifiers or hydrocolloids are used in oil field drilling and, obviously, you see that the rig count going down in the U.S. with less drilling going on as oil prices have declined. So several factors, I would say none of the fundamental have changed into this business. We continue to be excited. We continue to be building capabilities. We have bought 3 companies in the last year with WILD, SCI and Eatem Food. They are all on trend. They all on target. So we continue to feel very strong about it. It's a long-term play that we're building a great company for ADM here, and as long as synergies are on track and products are getting the pull from customers, we don't worry that much about these short-term headwinds.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Farha Aslam with Stephens.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Farha Aslam with Stephens.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Juan, could you give us a color on soy crush margins, kind of around the world, and what your outlook is going into the fourth quarter for that crushing and origination division?
componenttext: Juan, could you give us a color on soy crush margins, kind of around the world, and what your outlook is going into the fourth quarter for that crushing and origination division?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So crush margins continue to be very solid and very positive in the U.S.. So we're still running hard. Certainly, the U.S. has the best crush margins in the world followed by soy crush margins in Europe. There's still good demand in Europe and
componenttext: Yes, sure. So crush margins continue to be very solid and very positive in the U.S.. So we're still running hard. Certainly, the U.S. has the best crush margins in the world followed by soy crush margins in Europe. There's still good demand in Europe and even if some soy mill from South America has started to show up, we still remain more skewed towards soy crushing than rapeseed crushing in Europe. South America has recovered a little bit and is doing better this coming third in the quarter, if you will, and then, logging in China, we still have good demand for meal in China, but it's more hovering into the breakeven territory, if you will. So going into Q4 and that being halfway through Q4, if you will, as I said the crush margins remain in decent stated and maybe you're going to see a slight decline of Q4 versus Q3 for oilseeds in general, but still very solid.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, and then, through your comments and a strong U.S. dollar. Is there opportunities for ADM to reprice its products? Anything -- any actions you can take to make on a more competitive given that the U.S. dollar likely will stay strong for som
componenttext: That's helpful, and then, through your comments and a strong U.S. dollar. Is there opportunities for ADM to reprice its products? Anything -- any actions you can take to make on a more competitive given that the U.S. dollar likely will stay strong for somewhat an extended period of time?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say, that the big issue is sometimes not that much the U.S. -- the strong U.S. dollar that we can, as you said, we can commercially offset some of the. The issue is whether some currencies are very weak versus the dollar, whether you call it
componenttext: Yes. I would say, that the big issue is sometimes not that much the U.S. -- the strong U.S. dollar that we can, as you said, we can commercially offset some of the. The issue is whether some currencies are very weak versus the dollar, whether you call it the real or whether it's the ruble and that makes other origins much more competitive. Think about how competitive has been Brazil in the world market where Paraguay with the same weather, with the same climate hasn't been. It's not that Brazil is any different competitive advantage than Paraguay, it's just the real has devalued significantly versus what the Paraguayan currency have done. So 2 things, they ebb and flow and we profited from our origination in Brazil. Our volumes in Brazil are like have exploded versus last year and we see parts of that reflected in ag services. So at the end of the day, the good thing is that there are large crops everywhere and we're going to commercialize those crops, but it certainly affects the timing of all thus far and we're going through that period.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Piken with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Piken with Cleveland Research.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to dig a little bit deeper into the ethanol side of the business. And specifically, I just wanted to get your sense in terms of what you think our total industry capacity is today and out into 2016. It looks like in the last couple of months
componenttext: I just wanted to dig a little bit deeper into the ethanol side of the business. And specifically, I just wanted to get your sense in terms of what you think our total industry capacity is today and out into 2016. It looks like in the last couple of months, total production have gone down a little bit.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This and, probably total capacity is in the range of 14 8, something in that range. The industry, Michael, has normally take 2 shutdowns for maintenance. One before the driving season. One post the driving season to get the plants back in shape. Obviously
componenttext: This and, probably total capacity is in the range of 14 8, something in that range. The industry, Michael, has normally take 2 shutdowns for maintenance. One before the driving season. One post the driving season to get the plants back in shape. Obviously, you have this corn dynamics in which corn is more plentiful or basically lower in the rest of indent in the East so some of the East plants might have taken on at the bit longer to come back from maintenance just because it was difficult maybe to get corn, and I think at the end of the day with this lower oil prices, domestic demand has been strong and what -- with the -- with exports, net exports stay in this range of maybe 750 gallons million, and that's kind of where we are seeing this year and maybe for next year. We see the balance is pretty similar to what we see now. Again, I think the 2 positive side could be if we get another 1%, 1.5% domestic demand growth and then we see ethanol in Brazil be more requested internally and China, China went from like 3 million gallons last year of imports to maybe 60 million gallons this year. So what that's going to bode well for 2016. Those are probably positive. On the negative side, capacity utilization in the industry continues to be in maybe 2%, and it should go a little bit higher to see margin expansion.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, shifting over to the other side of corn processing. It looks like there's been some favorable news on the HFCS pricing in the 2016 maybe you could talk a little bit about when we might start to see some of those benefits roll throug
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, shifting over to the other side of corn processing. It looks like there's been some favorable news on the HFCS pricing in the 2016 maybe you could talk a little bit about when we might start to see some of those benefits roll through and have you seen any sort of order of magnitude from those favorable contracts?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're still finalizing some of those contracts. So I will refrain from making any specific comments about that. Normally, we clarify what happened at the end of the season in our next call. And I will say from a P&L perspective, we see the impact kin
componenttext: Yes. We're still finalizing some of those contracts. So I will refrain from making any specific comments about that. Normally, we clarify what happened at the end of the season in our next call. And I will say from a P&L perspective, we see the impact kind of February to February, so starting in February. So It rose into our P&L, probably at the end of Q1. That's kind of things to happen, but we see the industry being tied so the industry is running at above 90% and our volumes have been strong.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Adam Samuelson with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Adam Samuelson with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: A bit of a longer term question, and I want to think about the current environment today relative to the $4 medium-term EPS target that you've laid out. The last 2 quarters have had EPS but on $0.60 and there's also some global line noise in there, but yo
componenttext: A bit of a longer term question, and I want to think about the current environment today relative to the $4 medium-term EPS target that you've laid out. The last 2 quarters have had EPS but on $0.60 and there's also some global line noise in there, but you think about getting to a $4 EPS number from here and understanding seasonality, 3Q is usually a seasonally softer quarter for you guys, you probably need to see something on the order of $175 million, maybe $200 million of quarterly operating income and permit here. It's going to be moving pieces within the businesses that's of what's performing well cyclically, but help us think about how we can bridge to that kind of level of performance over the medium-term? And are there particular part of the portfolio that really has the step of the performance, the cyclically or operationally? The future benefits from cost actions, future capital allocation, just help us think about the moving pieces.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you, Adam. Thank you for the question, actually. Listen, I would believe that on the medium-term earnings range of $4 to $4.50, that we shared with you before, has not changed. Although we faced certain headwinds, we have looked at these in the
componenttext: Yes, thank you, Adam. Thank you for the question, actually. Listen, I would believe that on the medium-term earnings range of $4 to $4.50, that we shared with you before, has not changed. Although we faced certain headwinds, we have looked at these in the of stress tested. Actually, with 2 scenarios recently, and we still believe that we are on track to deliver that. It may not happen exactly the way we have described it to you before in 4 orderly packets of $0.30, but let me walk you through some of those issues. We certainly had a little bit higher ethanol margins in our original projections, and we have had those ethanol margins and eyes I said, when we stress test it the more levels we have today. We also look at what if the U.S. dollar continued to be strong and ag services will remain in this kind of range? And then, we looked at the positives and there are some businesses in certain portfolios that we are recovering, that we haven't highlighted to you because it was not a need to invest this business from a portfolio much, but those businesses are businesses that have specific actions to recover, and we feel strongly about being able to achieve that over the next 1 year, 1.5 year. Then we have operational excellence and operational efficiencies and as I described in my remarks, when we started to look at this target of $550 million in 5 years and having the $0.10 per year out of that, we are already after the first year, Adam, we have unveiled a pipeline of $700 million, and we continue to find more. So we have programs to accelerate that, to bring them faster into the program. We'll also continue to deploy our cash into these bolt-on acquisitions and as we did, Eatem, we have more in the pipeline and when we put all of those things together, again, the recovery of some of the units, some of the operational efficiencies, some of the M&A and we also have the ability to maybe been accelerated the buybacks as we mentioned of the will be in the upper side of our range this year. Again, we have stress tested, and we looked at 2 different scenarios, and we always come back within that range. So happy to report that at this point in time, we continue to see ourselves on track for end of '17 or early '18 deliver on that range.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful, and then maybe just a short-term question and an update on your thoughts on the biodiesel market, both thoughts in Europe and in the U.S.. What do you think the likelihood that we actually can get a producer tax credit passed through
componenttext: That's very helpful, and then maybe just a short-term question and an update on your thoughts on the biodiesel market, both thoughts in Europe and in the U.S.. What do you think the likelihood that we actually can get a producer tax credit passed through domestically by Congress?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is obviously important because we've been carrying the crush based on meal and I think the creation of an oil story is an important to bring more strength and more, yes, more strength to the overall crushing area, but I would say, we've seen bot
componenttext: Yes. This is obviously important because we've been carrying the crush based on meal and I think the creation of an oil story is an important to bring more strength and more, yes, more strength to the overall crushing area, but I would say, we've seen both the U.S. government and the Brazilian government a little bit more proactive to be supportive of biodiesel whether we're going to have the different RBOC with the U.S. which is, I guess, at this point, but that's kind of seems to be the rumor and whether Brazil is thinking and increasing from a B7 to maybe a B8. So we feel positive at this point in time that in my speculation is probably as good as yours, so at this point, we don't have an inside information, but we seem to see signs in the market that again, both governments maybe more positive towards biodiesel and supporting biodiesel programs.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citi Research.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Cornell on the line with a few questions on behalf of David. I just wanted to start off on the WILD Flavors segment. I believe, earlier, it was mentioned that in the company's still looking for that business to kind of come in line where previousl
componenttext: This is Cornell on the line with a few questions on behalf of David. I just wanted to start off on the WILD Flavors segment. I believe, earlier, it was mentioned that in the company's still looking for that business to kind of come in line where previously thought it would for the full year. However, it looks like the results in the quarter really so I think $70 million or so has done a lot but from what you did in the second quarter. I know that 2Q and 3Qs are supposedly the seasonally strong quarters for that segment so it seems like that segment significantly underperformed the quarter. One, Is that true? And any that's it is, what maybe the offset going forward, that would keep the full year guidance intact?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you, Cornell. Let me clarify to you, and we're learning on this business obviously, it's because they are new to us, but Q3, we're expecting to be softer in Q2. This business is heavy on the summer season because it's all about beverages and th
componenttext: Yes. Thank you, Cornell. Let me clarify to you, and we're learning on this business obviously, it's because they are new to us, but Q3, we're expecting to be softer in Q2. This business is heavy on the summer season because it's all about beverages and the summer in Europe is very important, and so the preparation for that summer is important. After that, the business have the lower seasonality. So there was some, as you described, underperformance, but part of the normal seasonality. So the other performance that I described before, specialty proteins is we export everything at this point from the U.S., so we're still building our plant in Brazil and the strong dollar some of the exports. Some of the destination markets have issues I described before, whether it was Venezuela, whether it was Brazil, whether it was Russia. In the WILD Flavors, there was some softness in some accounts that are large produce that they came a little bit softer in Japan and in China. Nothing that is structure ago nothing that we were we significantly above, and we saw also in the specialty proteins and some of these products that are soy-related, customers actually these talked because they saw the pricing of soy beans all that coming down and there was not a lot of incentive for them to Q&A 12 forward both in any of that. So we saw a little bit of a de-stocking. So their fundamental indicators about the strength of this business have not changed. The full from customers, the number of projects, that extent of the solutions haven't changed. So I would say, just, it's just an adjustment in terms of de-stocking and emerging market softness,  if you will.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Cornell, also just again I think it's fair to say that we're all learning about the seasonal pattern of this business year, and so you just expect that the second quarter we've always be the strongest quarter for WFSI. After the second quarter, you will s
componenttext: Cornell, also just again I think it's fair to say that we're all learning about the seasonal pattern of this business year, and so you just expect that the second quarter we've always be the strongest quarter for WFSI. After the second quarter, you will see declines. Third quarter will come down, and that's the seasonal pattern, and in the fourth quarter and the first quarter, generally, with the lowest quarters in terms of profitability for WFSI. So I think once you've kind of gone through 1-year, you'll start understanding the seasonal pattern of this business for modeling. The second point I want to make is, as Juan reaffirmed, and we are WILD Flavors, we're still on track for the first year accretion. We provide guidance and the -- we did $0.10 to $0.15 a share. We're still on track despite the headwinds that we've seen in terms of foreign exchange, in terms of the weakness of certain markets around the world. We're still on track towards the lower end of that range for WILD Flavors. And then, thirdly, if you recall, I did provide some guidance earlier here in the WFSI segment. I said it will be somewhere above $300 million, $340 million for the calendar year. We're still on track towards the lower end of that range. So I think it's fair to say, the team has done a very good job in terms of confronting the headwinds that we've seen in the business, yet I'm still very, very comfortable that the financial results for this segment as well as for WILD Flavors, are still consistent, again, on the lower end of the range, we're still consistent with what we're tracking in terms of helping this business actually move towards supporting our $4 to $4.50 earnings power over the medium term.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, very good and if I could just ask one question, if I may, about ethanol. Just kind of mentioned earlier, you're looking at near harbor ethanol prices at about a $0.35 per gallon premium to gas and it seems like a very wide premium and obviously, his
componenttext: Okay, very good and if I could just ask one question, if I may, about ethanol. Just kind of mentioned earlier, you're looking at near harbor ethanol prices at about a $0.35 per gallon premium to gas and it seems like a very wide premium and obviously, historically, you've gone through net of discount. Going forward, you believe that there could be some risk there just on the pricing front as you get deeper into the fourth quarter and some of those ethanol plants that are down, starts to come up and so you see production tick up and presumably in source tick up in the industry?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Cornell, there's always that risk that we face that's why ethanol margins have remained at this level. I think that the -- I think exports have been resilient and that gives me a lot of comfort. If we look at the Top 12 export destinations of U.S. ethanol
componenttext: Cornell, there's always that risk that we face that's why ethanol margins have remained at this level. I think that the -- I think exports have been resilient and that gives me a lot of comfort. If we look at the Top 12 export destinations of U.S. ethanol, year-to-date, even with that -- within this dynamic, only 2 are down versus last year. 10 of them are up or 3 of those 10 are actually new destinations. So there is a lot of dynamic into these and as some customers are looking at these and saying, okay, it's more expensive like gasoline. I don't export anymore or I don't import from the U.S. anymore. We're going to see other customers coming to the market. Remember that ethanol continues to be the cheapest concessionary and all the others are in the range of $2.50 even at these oil prices. So there's always going to be an opportunity for ethanol to replace other something. So -- but with all intention, how much capacity runs and how much capacity runs at full capacity so.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from the line of Evan Morris with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your last question comes from the line of Evan Morris with Bank of America.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question for you, just on ethanol and a lot of the sort of operational question, but just bigger picture, I mean, ethanol has clearly been very volatile and your stock is at times and certainly for the better part of past year has been trading base
componenttext: Just a question for you, just on ethanol and a lot of the sort of operational question, but just bigger picture, I mean, ethanol has clearly been very volatile and your stock is at times and certainly for the better part of past year has been trading based on oil prices in the ethanol outlook. I mean, internally, I know you can exit ethanol in it's entirely given sort of the wet mill, dry mill balance, but how much thought have you guys put into internally looking at why maintain the dry mills and why not just sort of shift some of that ethanol production in the wet mill, should away from ethanol in the wet mill side, just to reduce your exposure going forward? What's still the reason to be there and the size and capacity that you are?

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the question. Listen, it's something that we obviously think about very sequentially. Our focus is to improve the competitiveness of our 2 dry mills. You understand they're in very different dynamics between dry mills and wet mills. So obv
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question. Listen, it's something that we obviously think about very sequentially. Our focus is to improve the competitiveness of our 2 dry mills. You understand they're in very different dynamics between dry mills and wet mills. So obviously, that's where we're looking at improving the competitiveness. Naturally, if we get to a point in which we cannot improve our cost position to the point of differentiation, if you will, for whatever reason, and if we believe that they can not compete in a more challenging U.S. ethanol environment, we will naturally look at various alternatives to maximize shareholder value. At this point in time, we haven't found the end of that, and we continue to find opportunities, and we want to see, listen, it could be that the ethanol dry mill cost curve is very flat and even if we improve, we don't get the point of differentiation. And in that sense, we would like to probably need to make a decision. At this point, we are not there yet. We are still finding opportunities to differentiate our dry mills, but I'm not surprised with your question or your assessment. We constantly are reviewing them.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then just a broader sort of acquisition strategy, someone asked earlier about the incremental investment in Wilmar and there's been some speculation regarding potential grain crop in Australia, being able to potentially complete that deal with a
componenttext: Okay, and then just a broader sort of acquisition strategy, someone asked earlier about the incremental investment in Wilmar and there's been some speculation regarding potential grain crop in Australia, being able to potentially complete that deal with a new Prime Minister and other of that exit and if you could just -- I think you've talked about having the capacity to do $5 billion to $6 billion or so in terms of an acquisition. Can you talk about as you're thinking about it, now your acquisition strategy, the strong dollar, some of these opportunities may present themselves again, sort of bigger versus smaller if you think about the acquisitions.

headline: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we are very comfortable and confident in our strategy. Our strategy at asking for the large M&A. Our strategy at this point in time includes for certain businesses, bolt-on M&A's. Bolt-on M&A so that actually what they do is that process opportuni
componenttext: Yes, so we are very comfortable and confident in our strategy. Our strategy at asking for the large M&A. Our strategy at this point in time includes for certain businesses, bolt-on M&A's. Bolt-on M&A so that actually what they do is that process opportunities to Craig platforms for ADM to continue to move this product into a more stable and higher earnings. So obviously, if there is an opportunity that is too hard to pass, that is somehow inexpensive out there, I mean, we will look at those things, but that's not the main thrust of our story, of our strategy here. So I would say, regarding all the other comments, obviously, we don't make comments on speculation and it's been enough speculation. You're going to see more of us doing this kind of Eatem or Eaststarch in which will continue doing to strengthen our businesses as they need some platforms to continue to grow. Eatem provides an excellent culinary expertise and excellent savory platform that we didn't have before. We will continue to do so. Very large M&A, again, is not something that we are seeking at this point in time. We might stumble into something, which is very convenient and will provide big shareholder value creation, but we're not seeking them at this point.
